pint can - date 04/30/20 - pour into an IPA glass at 38 ° F .   pour a near - crystal clear earthy pale amber hue , top with three finger of dense , sticky , pure white head with excellent retention . plentiful visible effervescence . very nice lacing leave behind .   Nose : very similar to Sip of Sunshine , but more Pliny . this definitely have more of a malt presence than Sip . light note of caramel and brown sugar beneath big Pacific Northwest hop note . lot of pine , lot of hoppy resin , huge grapefruit , some stone fruit in the form of peach and mango , a touch of tropical pineapple , and some earthy dank Simcoe . it be surprisingly subdue - not as in - your - face as Heady Topper , but a similar profile . not as fruity and " New England " .   Palate : this be where it get interesting . I be begin to think this would just be a malty Sip of Sunshine . no no no . first sip , and I be immediately take back by the punish bitterness . it hold no punch , and immediately slaughter the palate with biting , resinous bitterness right from the start . this thing be hop to high hell ! it do have a full , bold , sweet malt presence than Sip , but it need it to support that insane bite . flavour - wise , lot of caramel malt up - front , and then pine sap . resinous , piney , bitter pine sap . there be a big pithy grapefruit note as well . just about as bitter and pithy as bite into actual grapefruit rind . holy moly ! there be whisper of fruit note beneath the assault of all thing hoppy and bitter , with the suggestion of some peach , apricot , mango , and pineapple , but that be quickly whisk away when that signature earthy boil Simcoe note come in , give a huge nod to Pliny - if Pliny be on that Barry Bonds love potion number 9 joose . it be like getting pull over after a high speed car chase even though all you do be run a stop sign . sure , you can surrender , but you be getting pummel either way , and it be gon na hurt . it finish , leave you somewhat violate , with that earthy dank Simcoe , pine sap , and pithiness , now without the grapefruit flavour . the bitterness claw into your tongue , eventually fade away , like the heat of a bhut jolokia .   Mouthfeel / body : the beer be fairly full , in part due to its malt base , but even without the weight of the malt , with a level of bitterness like a kick from a mule straight to your Naddy Daddies , this one will stop you like a .50cal Barrett . not a midsummer day quaffer . this be for when you want it to hurt , and you want it bad . effervescence be fairly lively , once you survive the bitter assault long enough to realise it be actually effervescent . very little malt cloy or cle , but it leave a kiss of stickiness on the lip , and of course , the bitterness linger with no sign of leave , like a transient after you 've say , " sure you can spend the night in my basement and not do any drug at all ! " . typical classic double IPA body , with typical classic trouble IPA bitterness . some hop burn will in fact start to hurt the upper hard palate after a while .   overall : goodness gracia my I have another , señor ? ! this one really pack a hide whopper , and not like those chick in Bankok either ! on the surface , it masquerade as a harmless little hybrid double IPA , but then when you taste it , there be clearly something very different about it . it really share a lot in common with Pliny the elder , in term of its flavour profile . it have those signature sos / Heady colour , but the bitterness here be on another level , really make this a beast all its own . it be a fantastic beer , and it be certainly unique . if you want a classic OG hop assault , and you have the grip not to drop the soap , give this one a try . ... just do n't say I do n't warn you ...

Nose : this be a very difficult aroma to describe , because it be so unique and unusual , and unlike any quad I 've have . incredibly nutty and complex - sweet toasty malt with note of brown bread , concord grape , fresh and dry fig , raisin , date , prune , with bake spice note of nutmeg , allspice , and candy ginger . some molasse , brown sugar , and distinct leather , and some bright fruity red apple and pomegranate cut through . it be a truly remarkable aroma .   palate : Westvleteren 12 greet the palate fairly dry for a quad , open with fresh dark bread , a big nutty maltiness , and a bright fruity element that remind I of cognac - fresh red apple , red grape , raisin , plum , fig , and persimmon . these fruit note become dark and more like dry fruit , with prune , date , and raisin , before this incredibly exotic malt note appear - leather , vanilla bean , age , old wood , irish whiskey , caramel , almond , toffee , and nougat , yet still decidedly dry . a herbal bitterness begin to develop , perhaps just a whisper of licorice , with gentian root , bitter herb , grass , and a distinctly german hop spicy leafy note , with a moderately bitter resinous bite . this hoppiness linger for age , with whisper of everything that come before it slowly fade in and out , finally finish with a unique earthy flavour .   medium - bodied , with no stickiness at all . both Rochefort 10 and ( especially ) St. Bernardus be full , heavy , and stickier . the dryness here allow it to be supremely drinkable , with a nice presence , but never fight back . beautifully lively and fine effervescence lend plenty of lift and cut right through that 1.2 % ABV . hearty , fluid , wholesome , quenching , bold , crisp , malty and dry .   overall : in a word ? beautiful . this be a beautiful beer , with an incomparable malt profile , a unique bright fruitiness , crisp dryness , and intriguing complexity . it remind I a lot of old cognac , and the malt base have similarity to classical English barleywine . I can see why this one be so revered . between Rochefort , Bernardus , and this , this be probably the most enjoyable ( to I ) , follow by Bernardus , and then Rochefort . it feel masterful and dial in - like the whole be great than the sum of its part . I be privileged and grateful to have enjoy this one , and I think it be worthy of its accolade . enjoy this one with food if you can . enjoy the experience - take note , review later .

be cellare this one for a few year now and feel like this holiday be an appropriate time to bring it out . not sure how available the ' 12 ' be in the US anymore but I know I be very lucky to find it . in fact , the obscure little wine shop in Baltimore where I buy the only two they have be not in business anymore . drank the 1st one two year ago and it be memorable . the one tonight be just as exceptional .   Turbid , mahogany appearance with a small tan head and good lacing . intriguing aroma , with dark fruit ( fig , plum ) , toffee , licorice , and molasse . complex , malty , vinous taste with layer of ripe fruit , oak , vanilla , molasse , bittersweet chocolate and seasonal spice . modestly hop , with a full bodied , lightly carbonate mouthfeel . finish linger , but wish it could have last long . just to add to all of the superlative lavish upon this brew , here be some of the most remarkable flavor that could be associate with the word " beer " .

big thank to my good friend Jon Passow from a Starter and a Chaser podcast for share a bottle of this with I . get to try this certainly be a big beer milestone for I . pour into a goblet glass , this beer pour a dark ruby color with some bright ruby / amber highlight when hold up to the light . have a just slightly off - white / tan head that be about half an inch thick when first pour that settle eventually to thick ring line the inside of the glass along with a film layer of surface foam . Aromas of toasted , bready , caramel malt follow by dry fig , plum , yeasty ester , a hint of cocoa , a bit of leather , and hint of sweet , Red Delicious apple . Tastewise , the flavor profile be very similar , with the aforementione toasted , caramel , bready malt along with plum , fig and just a hint of Red Delicious apple . this be follow by some Belgian Candy sugar along with a bit of yeastiness and just a hint of cocoa and leather here too . the flavor profile do change and get a bit more complex as the beer sit and warm up . just an absolutely fantastic flavor profile . have a smooth , fairly frothy , slightly creamy , also still somewhat crisp , medium to full bodied with moderate carbonation . have a clean finish , and all the flavor stack around on the inside of my mouth on my palate for awhile after each sip . wow ! this be just a really excellent beer , and certainly the good beer of this style I 've ever have . 2 finger of khaki head which slowly dissipate to about one finger . dense foam which leave a surprisingly nice amount of lacing despite the abv . body be translucent amber - brown .   Nose bring sweet dark fruit , pumpernickel bread , caramel , a touch of earthy cocoa and leather . well integrated . fruit forward but not perceive it as cloy .   taste bring sweet dark fruit - both fresh ( juicy ) and dry - follow by addition of some earth and leather . well layer . middle heat up a bit - pick up on the abv but it be pleasant . a sharp spiced / peppery note . finish with more fruit , but it be less dominate . earthy cocoa note and leather . a balance of bitter and sweet .   full bodied , but not oily or cloy . pick up on the abv more as it warm , but it add some depth .   my recollection of other quad be fuzzy , but from what I do remeber the richness / juiciness of the dark fruit note distinguish this from other of the style . like other trappist quad , this be incredibly well balanced . what impress I be that the balance lean slightly toward the dark fruit note without become overly sweet / cloying . at $ 20 per , I do n't regret the splurge , but I wo n't be repurchase when St. Bernardus and Rochefort and readily available at half the price .

this beer absolutely deserve the hype . in fact , this be the good beer I have ever taste . I agree with most of the previous favourable comment re its taste , smell , mouthfeel and absurdly quaffable nature ( particularly give the 10.2 % ABV ) but I would also like to add that I completely agree with those who recommend a 12 - 16 degree ( celsius ) drink temperature . this mean you take one out of your cupboard / safe / bank vault and put it in the fridge for only 15 - 20 minute ... the complexity really come through at this temperature . in contrast , a friend once drink a cold one as a ' travel beer ' on the Tube ( Subway / Metro ) on his way home at midnight ( when heavily drunk ) . obviously he be no long a friend .   in summary , this beer taste like an angel 's vagina and anyone give it less than a 4.9 be just upset they 've have to acquire it for $ 20 a bottle from a dodgy character on a street corner at 2 am rather than from a happy monk at the Saint - Sixtus Abbey .

beer rating be very subjective .   I own a NYC sandwich shop in SoHo and FiDi for 30 year . we carry a small curate can list of 18 - 24 rotate can and bottle and one line for draft . I carry beer at the new location in FiDi because I ’m a craft beer / beer enthusiast and I love people that believe in their work . I wo n’t review beer that I do n’t love because whether or not I like a beer , it ’ someone ’s life work . I refuse to to give a review that may not take into account of the struggle to survive every owner have . to be sensitive and kind be more important than my hurtful review , so I just do n’t give it .   I also do n’t review one category next to another . if I ’m love pilsner at the moment , I do n’t review it against a stout for example . I take in consideration rate ipa against ipa , IIPA , imperial , lager , porter , etc . I may review a Pilsner that ’s not well than some of the other category , but I give a high score because it ’ the good of that category . I do n’t believe that my opinion be the good one , but it take into consideration the hard life ’s work that go into live your career and want to make a difference .   I be write this because I visit Maine Beer Company over the weekend and make sure to bring some beer home .   Dinner .   I ’ve never have this from a bottle and be super excited to pour one .   I ’m be give this beer a 5 . and thank you MBC for be you and be amazing .   this be not like other brewer , this be unique to they .   so true to character and so pleasant to drink .   few beer get my high rating , but this be well deserved . bless you and thank you Maine Beer Company .   cheer !

bottle on 5/22/20   pour a translucent , deep golden orange body cap with multiple finger of dense , fluffy , rocky white foam ; a spectacular head retention , nearly beyond reproach , yield a mountainous cap along with a fluffy , soapy collar and wild smattering of chunky , soapy lace .   Aroma open with a tropical twang of tangerine and orange oil before move towards a progressive , dank sweetness ; floral and delicate across the middle , note of mango and papaya add nuance to an airy , clean malt backbone as a platform for an ultimately delicate and prod piney edge , dirty hop , and bitter citrus toward the close be establish .   taste feature tone of grapefruit z and pine needle upfront , with light pineapple and mango develop steadily ; fresh grass and a raw hop tone mesh with melon rind , lemon z , and peach on the back end , even display a soft creaminess evolve and linger past the swallow .   Mouthfeel have a medium body , pillowy slick with hop oil , and a moderate - high carbonation peaking beautifully through the mid - palate ; a semi - crisp flow refreshe the palate over time while paradoxically invite a steady intensity of hoppy grit and ultimately , a soft , linger bitterness ease into the finish .   exceptionally rounded and fervently balanced , the purely plush hop expression be partly simplistic ( though satisfying ) , and partly an exploration of the essence of these soft flavor ; an ultra - harmonious brew that near the pinnacle of IPA approachability .

beautiful ( for the style ) hazy , opaque , and nearly pulpy brew . decent head production ; good retention ; excellent lacing . body be a shade dark than lemon , close to peach flesh . Melon , mango , papaya ; tropical fruit juice in a glass . just a hint of green herb and very mild dankness ( a four - day - old can may also be a factor in the mildness of the dankness ) , and touch of lemon and grapefruit , without any citric bite .   Smooth , creamy , still lively ; full bodied . Tree House have perhaps perfect the NE IPA mouthfeel and body , and this be a great example .   like with Very Hazy , Tree House seem to be go for the maximum expression of juicy hop note - basically , create a fruit beer without add any fruit . similar to that beer , it can be a bit one - dimensional , lack the complexity and depth of my favorite ( I)IPAs . still , there be no question its deliciousness or craftsmanship .

2016 vintage   750ml cork and cage bittle - pour into a Riesling / Zinfandel stem at 45 ° F .   pour a slightly foggy translucent honey - golden , really verge on orange , like a West Coast IPA . a finger of coarse , sticky , sudsy off - white head form , with fair retention , and settle to a decent collar , with weak , spotty lacing . Clings to the glass like whiskey . really a beautiful beer .   Nose : this one travel . no shortage of funk here . ton of damp hay and wine - soak oak , with plenty of bright lemon juice and rind . there be ample leather book bind , dusty stone cellar , petrichor , magnolia blossom , and a really dense note of patchouli , with some sweet apricot and marmalade threadinf through . some funky stable , sea shell minerality , and sweaty brett emerge , but the funk be balance by plenty of bright fruitiness . huge nod to Cantillon here .   palate : Duck Duck Gooze emerge with an impressively balanced acidity . like bite into a ripe stone fruit , there be a bright * POP * of tartness , but it immediately step back , become more of a lemony tang . Lemon oil , orange juice , apricot , and crabapple lend bright fruity note , with undertone of cabernet grape , cranberry , unripe plum , and coriander seed . the tartness begin to rapidly subside , show quite a bit of grain - dusty , with hull . an almost gueuze level of funk present itself in the form of wet hay , damp wood , old musty stable air , milkweed , and a touch of herbal flowery note with just a whisper of sweaty funk . the tartness completely disappear , and the finish show wheaty grain , grass , lemon essence , white oak , and just a touch of grapefruit oil that cling to the palate .   Mouthfeel / body : absolutely stunning . it be crisp , airy , and quenchingly dry with a shimmering minerality , but there be definitely some soft body which lend presence . the effervescence be truly perfect . champagne . zippy , airy , fluffy , and fizzy , but soft and supple . an oily feel linger .   overall : this be perhaps the most stunning american wild ale I 've have in a long time , perhaps ever . I be not sure if this be Method Traditionelle or not , but either way , this really be a masterpiece . a sweet grain presence , incredibly balanced acidity , ample funk contrasting against beautiful bright fruity note , and it all come together so seamlessly and flawlessly , this have truly transcend the style itself . simply stunning .

January 1st , 2016 - ring in the new year with a resoundingly good ( and increasingly rare ) sour from Lost Abbey . this treat be a lovely scent with a well toned sourness , and a touch of banana ester that play second fiddle . the central sourness on the tongue be also tune to perfection , with just a slight edge twist the salivary gland and a lovely carbonation . each sip be its own little rollercoaster of dramatic joy follow by the post - dopamine relief in the aftertaste , cycle again with a new and fresh flavor .

when I take my first and only trip to great American Beer Fest in 2017 , I do n't know a lot about the lose Abbey - I 'd hear a few thing about Veritas , and I 'd try a select few of their beer . I be a fan , but I do n't pursue their beer to the degree that I do now . I know that Duck Duck Gooze be on the top 250 on Beer Advocate - but I never expect that I 'd be able to try it .   well now . I recently make a Facebook friend who use to live in San Diego but now live and brew in northern Minnesota . happy coincidence ! he happen to love sour , just like I do ... he help I out with a bottle of Duck Duck Gooze ( among other thing ) in our very first trade . I be thrilled , and still be - the beer be fantastic !   it be interesting to I how DDG differ from belgian gueuze though - the characteristic funk seem to be entirely absent , and the nose do n't pop to quite the same degree . it smell very nice , but it be a different sort of aroma - and taste . there be a bit of cheese to the taste , and a very light , clean , crisp sort of sour and tart character . again , the belgian funk be miss . perhaps this have be lose with time , but it surprise I as old belgian lambic still seem to retain that funk . there be also a marked lack of suspension - there be no noteworthy presence of fruit , yeast , or foreign matter of any kind . I do n't mind that ! I know some really enjoy that in belgian lambic , but it be a happy absence as far as I be concerned .   I 'd have to say that DDG characterize all of the thing that I love about gueuze , while it also happen to have bypass the aspect that I be not such a big fan of . it be a terrific beer , and really demonstrate why Lost Abbey be such a hyped and tout brewery . I think that I will always try far hard to pick up bottle of Russian River sour , because they be just a lot more accesible - but I will never pass on the chance to try another bottle of Lost Abbey . their sour , wild , and lambic be tremendous , and DDG be one of their good .

for purpose of this review , 2013 be compare side - by - side to 2016 .   Appearance- the beer be a bright straw yellow with a bright white head .   Smell - the sour mesh with the oak .   taste - this gueuze be so well balanced and far from acidic . it be smooth and oaky with plenty of green apple . 2016 be thin and not a sour as 2013 . to a degree the 2016 seem a bit watery . 2016 even linger during the 2013 sampling . this be a green apple bonanza . the sour oakinessthi linger so well . * * review number 1,000 * * : and also : * * beer advocate beer number 1,600 * *   thank to eyebereej for send this bottle ! 2013 bottle . consume on Dec. 18 , 2016 ; review from note . pour from the 750 ml bottle into an El Catador Barrel aged glass .   a : pour a hazy , glow gold . form a thin white head that fade quickly with a relatively low amount of visible carbonation . this be n't bad - look by any stretch , but appear fairly still . I do n't know if that be a consequence of aging or not .   s : earthy and funky barnyard . oaky dry tannin , and note of stone fruit ( especially apricot , though I do n’t think this that be actually in there . some lactic tartness , and light biscuit malt in the background . I be get more Lacto funk primarily , with less Brett note . a really nice , complex aroma .   t : lactic tartness and more sour , juicy stone fruit ( like a dry apricot ) . earthy funk again – Lacto again , and some Pedio I think . Dry citric acid and tannin . the light biscuit malt be still getting snow under here - it be necessary to search for they . some dry white wine character . it finish with some stone fruity juiciness and a dry sourness , and the dry flavor ultimately win out .   m : Light body , very low alcohol presence . carbonation sensation be just a bit on the low side .   o : wow … after sit for three year , this live up to both the hype and my expectation . and both of those be quite high . especially as a non - fruit , non - adjuncted sour , it succeed with a complex and balanced funk and sourness . I guess you could argue provenance vis - a - vis the " authentic " gueuze of the world , but this absolutely could stand on its own in the conversation .

do a side - by - side tasting with DDG , Allagash Coolship Resurgam and Jester King Spon Methode Gueze as part of our annual Xmas eve tasting . DDG be universally agree to be third in the group and Resurgam remain , hand down , the good gueze - like american beer and the only one that can go head - to - head with the like of Cantillon , Drie , and Tilquin .   DDG be good , not great . it be , visually , quite lovely . the aroma , however , prominently feature an off - put porta - potty characteristic that very much distracted from the more pleasant funk and citrus fruity ester .   fortunately , not much of off - put aroma carry over to the flavor . however , it be a touch sweet than I 'd expect for the style and it seem that a bit of wine flavor from the barrel come through in the beer - not a bad thing per se but not really appropriate for a gueze style beer .   overall a good but not overwhelmingly great sour , more of an American Wild than gueze stand - in .

product_review: probably my favorite of the Speedway coffee variant .   the beer pour a blackish brown color with pretty good head retention and lacing . the beer look rich and viscous , which ai n't no bad thing . on the nose , there be considerable coffee and vanilla , along with underlie dark chocolate and perhaps a hint of cinnamon . the flavor profile replicate the nose pretty closely , and while this stout be pretty sweet , the coffee flavor seem to balance and counter that sweetness somewhat . there be a mocha quality on the palate of this beer that I just love . Mouthfeel be full , soft and fairly creamy , with a very long finish . alcohol be incredibly well integrate into the flavor profile , and so drinkability be terrific ( almost too terrific , as it be hard to show restraint where this beer be concern ) .   just outstanding , and a beer I would order and even make a special trip to obtain , whenever I see it on tap around Portland ( which be pretty infrequent unfortunately ) .

May 2020 review 22 oz Bottle purchase in Nov 2019 . bottled Oct 2017 . pour into a tulip glass .   pour : deep black with a 1/2 finger tan head that dissipate pretty quickly leave a thick ring . some bubble lacing . 4.0   Nose : Maple , coffee , some booze . 4.25   taste : follow the nose with some extra bitterness on the coffee , a hint of cinnamon , some vanilla / marshmallow , chocolate . probably some salt / bacon but could be the power of suggestion . 4.25   feel : super smooth . low carbonation . slightly viscous . 4.5   overall : really good , very similar to CBS with maybe more bitter coffee , slightly less maple . worth try and will seek out again . 4.25    Thanksgiving 2018 Maple syrup and bacon nose . really interesting . lot of chocolate , coffee , some of the bourbon come through in the taste . great mouthfeel ; creamy , slight carbonation . finish nicely with a little linger booze but relatively clean . a real treat on Thanksgiving , unlike the Lions !

wow ! thank to drlovemd87 for share this rare gem , its always a pleasure to get to share these with close friend . this might represent the final evolution of the apricot wild ale , and after be only lukewarm on the west ashley ( in regard to all the hype ) , this one really take it to the next level . twice the apricot and twice the time in barrel ! the pour be hazy short of rusted orange , pale and soft looking , no visible particulate in here , but still sort of raw looking . nearly a full inch of airy white head linger . the aroma here be near perfection , about be forward as apricot have ever be , include allagash , cascade , crooked stave , and yes , cantillon too . its juicy and bright , sweet enough , even fuzz on the outside just a little bit . oddly nutty like the pit but that could be a handover from the wood . the fruit be pulpy and ripe and dominant , but there be a great mixed culture sourness back it up , cut the sweet , and highlight some of the wheaty grain base and oak treatment , all well integrated and powerful , but also quite mellow and approachable as they go . the flavor be still really ripe apricot and interesting funk and sour combine . the fruit be incredible here , maybe a step short of its explosive aroma , but really pungent and to the point . it taste like a fresh apricot in the peak of the season , as true to the fruit as any of the beer out there . its quite sour too , a lot of lactic acidity , ahead of the wild funk aspect , and well ahead of the oak . it get even more sour as it warm , which it do in this instance because I ca nt put my glass down to stop smell it ! a bottle of this might be a lot as a solo mission , so I be really glad to be share it . I could see the acidity get overwhelming . its like too much of a good thing , a third of a bottle be exactly perfect . probably the good expression of apricot I have see in a beer , and the white wine note from the wood and the yeast be a great compliment to the fruit . easily the good of the beer I have have from these guy , and probably the new benchmark in the style . unlike the west ashley , this be entirely worth all of the high praise it get ! a memorable experience .

375ml bottle into a Teku Blend 4 ( aka vintage 2020 )   a : pop and be a gusher which be inexcusable as this have sit undisturbed for month . several ounce waste and sedimentation disturb from the bottom . color be apricot yellow / orange with a fizzy white head that dissipate almost instantaneously . once that ’s go it actually look flat . it ’ quite hazy , nearly opaque . certainly not much of a looker .   s : Aroma be a great balance of fruit sweetness and tart sour character . huge fruit flesh character with big peach as expect but also tangerine and apricot . lactic acidity and sour citrus to balance , I would say the tart / sour character be moderate on the nose . a bit of melt plastic like funk and mineral note round it out .   t : taste be very delicious . much more sour than the nose , with huge puckering tartness . wonderful sweet fruit note to balance , it ’s very orange - family fruit forward with note of orange , tangerine , nectarine . peace be primarily on the finish , but be quite nice . pretty big lemon tartness as well . really fantastic .   m / D : Mouthfeel be fuller bodied , carbonation be appropriately high even though it look flat in the glass , drinkability be very good .   o : overall , this be an excellent beer , no doubt . although # 37 overall rating on BA seem damn high . Fair or not , I always compare these American Wild Ales to traditional Lambics , and even very well do one such as this tend to lack the depth and complexity of most offering from the like of 3F and Cantillon . regardless , still a treat , and would happily drink any day of the week .   Happy New Year BA ’s !   3.5/4.25/4.75/4.5/4.5

review # 500 : Side Project - Fuzzy   batch 4 ( 2020 ) 375ml - pour into a tulip at 42 ° F .   pour a moderately foggy sunglow orange , not dissimilar to the peach on the label . a thin , coarse , break off - white head almost form , before quickly fall , leave only a razor - thin collar , and constant stream of effervescence . 4.25   Nose : signature Side Project pale base , with evident crackery grain , a touch of malt , and some dusty silo . the peach be restrain - apparent , but not loud , lend a very organic white peach aroma , much like nectarine . the acidity translate as fresh lemon juice , and just a splash of apple cider vinegar - tame , and bright . there be a ton of wet white oak - woody and musty , play with some funky wet hay , raw honey , stone cellar , dusty attic , leather , parchment , honeysuckle , lilac , dry leave , and peach blossom . not aggressive funky or tart .   palate : fuzzy greet the palate with a quick flash of tartness - lactic and acetic in nature , lend some lemon juice and apple cider vinegar . the peach , once more , be very natural and ripe , but not jammy . these be fruity , bright white peach , with most of their fructose ferment out . huge stone fruit note of peach , nectarine , apricot , and a big plum presence . remarkably floral , with honeysuckle , lilac , gardenia , and even a hint of honeydew melon . as the acidity curve , oak begin to show , along with a hint of sweet grain , which add nice balance . some farmhouse note of hay , wet wet , stone , and earth emerge , provide that true wild touch , with the brett add a nice dusty , sweaty , overripe element . it finish remarkably clean , with a general stone fruit presence behind a fade acidity , some subtle grain , and dry wet white oak , with nothing really linger .   Mouthfeel / body : it be incredible how Side Project can produce these 8 % ABV wild ale with such clean , crisp , snappy fluidity . Fuzzy be light - bodied , with no real malt weight , and quite dry , with no significant residual sugar . perhaps a touch less sparkling than champagne , but with a similar feel - airy , clean , bright , and snappy . acidity be tart - sour , even , but definitely shy of puckering . the finish have some nice dry tannic oak . ultra - clean .   overall : Fuzzy be a bottle with a lofty reputation . long consider one of the fine fruit wild ale . that be a tall order . be it the great wild ale I 've ever have ? I would n't say so . be it the great peach sour I 've ever have ? most likely . what it most certainly be , be the definition of Side Project . yes , it be one of the more sour offering , use their high acid blonde base , but it be n't overbearing , and it be one of the more subtle offering - beautifully showcase the delicate nuance and balance that they be so great at . the tartness , the minerality , the organic nature of the fruit , the oak , the gentle funk , all meticulously blended . it really be a world - class wild ale , and one everyone should try at some point .

this be one of those " must try , " beer to my knowledge , so I figure its worth reviewing .   look : pretty standard , but certainly hazy than I be expect . good lace though .   Smell : this be where it start to lose I a little . now it smell fine and all , but for a Pale Ale , it be simply way too hoppy . I almost think I have get the style wrong when I smell it .   taste : again , this be not a Pale Ale . it be clearly an IPA with the level of hop go on here . there be almost no focus on bring the malt up front , which be really what distinguish the two style for I . pa can be hoppy , even very hoppy , but they need to also give attention to the forward malt flavor . this beer only have a semblance of that . I guess it be more present than a typical IPA , but hardly so , and I would bet any beer drinker would label it an IPA if you give it to they blind . the taste be n't even bad , but to be honest it be a pretty standard fruity west coast style . nothing special either ; hop be n't particularly unique or interesting . as it start to warm a bit the malt come in , but right out of the can it be almost completely absent .   feel : I find it have a bit more success here . it be n't quite as heavy as a typical IPA , likely thank to the slightly low ABV . on the other hand , it be still far too heavy for a PA .   overall : I like this beer . however , it simply do n't work as a Pale Ale for I . there be plenty of hoppy PA 's I 've had that find that still manage to keep the malt characteristic of a PA ; this be not one of they . again , it be too heavy as well . either this beer should be label an IPA , or bring down to something like 5.5 % and give more malt focus . I do n't know why some brewery have these baffle mislabele beer sometimes , it put a huge stain on what would otherwise be a fine beer . the fact that this have the # 1 spot for Pale Ales show how biased some of the reviewer on this site be towards ipa . it feel like it have that spot because it be an IPA compete with Pale Ales , almost like an 8th grader compete in the little league .   regardless , even if this * be * just call an IPA , I still do n't think it would be the 40th good beer in the world which be what this site seem to contend . not sure where the obsession with this beer come from , maybe it be something before my time . also , a 6 pack of this be like 14 buck when there be plenty of $ 11 six pack I 'd say be way well .

this be an undead pale ale style beer ( lol ) with 62 ibu and 6.5 % ABV . I read the review on BeerAdvocate before buy it and be really impressed with its 100 and world class rating ! I check the can - on date and find it be only 3 week old ! I pour into a Teku glass ( that my brother get I ! ) to enhance the aroma with the laser - etch nucleation site on the bottom .   look - it pour a beautiful orange - gold color like viscous honey in the winter . I see hue of cedar and magenta in the light . the head be thin and puffy white with an effervescent quality lead to thin and persistent droopy lace on the glass . it have a slight haziness , likely due to all the zombie that they grind up and put into this world - class brew ( lol ) .   Smell - it have a remarkably rich aroma . I smell tropical fruit , citrus , honey , and half - baked bread . I get strong note of tropical pith and skin such as overripe papaya skin , apricot , pineapple , and mango rind . I also get white pepper , green tea leave , grapefruit , crack rye , tobacco and pine .   taste - one of the most pleasant thing about this beer be its clean flavor . there be no sticky , cloying , or syrupy malty flavor and/or texture . it be rich in tropical fruit , pine , citrus , and bread malt . the citrus , pine , and mild sweetness from the toasty , bready malt hit first and then a piney hop resin take over in the most wonderful manner . the slight bitterness linger , and the effervescent pop mingle with it tickle your tongue . I sense a pithy texture on my tongue from the more prominent tropical fruit quality of the hop . it have a medium - body and very smooth quality .   overall - this beer have one of those rare professional quality to it that you can not quite put your finger on . it be well - balance , delicious , juicy , nuanced , and complex . I agree with the overall rating of it at this time as a world - class brew . it be impressive for another reason . it be a pale ale , but drink a bit like a west coast IPA ! I be glad to have find this so fresh and suddenly . it definitely live up to all the hype ! drink this one brain - dead or while eat brain ! Lol !

2018 vintage   750ml bottle - pour into a balloon stem at 50 ° F . huge thank to donniet79 for this longtime want !   pour an unbelievable slick jet black colour - absorb every photon of light , with the single darkest head on a beer that I 've ever see , form - like a grade school volcano , it foam up - fine and sudsy , with the colour of light coffee bean , and then recede to a huge , persistent coarse bubbly collar that last forever . 4.75   Nose : incredibly rich . almost like a concentrate . deep , bold roasted malt with a particularly russian - style accord lend bitter baker 's chocolate , cacao , peruvian coffee , black treacle , toffee , caramel , marzipan , and vanilla . a slight , dense fruity thread lend a deep raisiny PX sherry note , with a hint of fig , blueberry , and dry cherry . I be fail to pick up any chilie or cinnamon , but there be a unique warm spice element , lend a hint of earthiness . not very mexican , but it smell delicious . 4.25   palate : the legendary Hunahpu greet the palate with an expertly dial - in balance between malt sweetness and roast . immediately , it let you know that it be not try to be a mexican wedding cake - this be a russian imperial stout , with a bold , heavy roast , deep , dark , bitter complexion , and lean drier on the sweetness scale . roasty be the main theme here . bitter cocoa , char malt , burn sugar , and burn vanilla lead the way , with an underpinning of marzipan and malty sweetness . the pepper be there if you really squint , but rather than lend a chili heat , it be more of an earthy , dry spice . spice as in spice , not heat . I be not pick up on cinnamon , perhaps due to its age , but there be definitely some type of spice character that be lend an earthy aromatic quality . it grow dry , nudge out any sweetness , and the char malt take hold , up the dry , bitter factor . the faint little glow of pepper warmth emerge , and the stout conclude with deep , bitter roast , cacao , and an almost tannic bite to it , which linger , resurface with an espresso- like aftertaste . 4.0   Mouthfeel / body : despite its foreboding motor oil appearance , Hunahpu be quite drinkable . a bold , rich , heavy brew , but he be quite fluid , with a medium - full body , and very minimal viscosity . there be some fine , subtle fizzy effervescence , but it be relegate to the background , and only just contribute enough . the chilie warm only the gum , and it conclude with a dry , tannic roasty squeeze . 4.25   overall : this be a tricky one for I . I know this be revere as a legend , and be once highly seek - after , and perhaps the age do n't treat this one the good , but I have a hard time fall in love with it . it be a bit roasty and bitter for my taste , and feel it trend more in the classic russian style than anything else . it be a great RIS , especially if you like they bitter and roasty , and the hint of pepper be a nice twist , but I keep , wish that it be just a touch sweet , less roasty , with more caramel / toffee / vanilla / malt , and less cacao / char / blacken bite . I can certainly see how the right person would adore this though . I just find the roast a bit overbearing .   3.75

blend 9 ( April , 2019 ) - 500ml bottle - pour into a wine stem at 45 ° F .   pour a translucent deep blood red , with garnet highlight , sit like pinot noir in the glass , a think collar of pink foam circumnavigate the ruby elixir . just stunning .   Nose : incredibly intense raspberry aroma . there be a jammy element like raspberry preserve , atop a true wild raspberry bush aroma , with ripe raspberry , unripe raspberry , raspberry seed , stem , and leave , macerate raspberry , overripe raspberry ... Super organic , like an actual raspberry . Jammy , sweet , tart , seedy ... liquid raspberry . you get my drift here ? you take a raspberry ... and drink it . a wild , but balanced acidity follow , bring some lemon- like tartness , and just a whisper of balsamic vinegar . there be plenty of farmhouse funk , with wet hay , wet wood , and a dusty , musty , earthen note that just scream " Texas " . the oak note be similar to bourbon , with some leather , caramel , and vanilla undertone , and then some grain peek through underneath . the tartness overtake the sweetness , introduce some lactic minerality , quickly dry the beer out , and finish dry , with raspberry essence , tingly tarness , and oak .   Mouthfeel / body : Atrial be a light - bodied ale , but the raspberry sweetness do add just a touch of weight , give some smooth dimension to it all . acidity be bright , sour , but restrain - far from heartburn territory . effervescence be moderate , and super fine to a champagne degree . sweet and wet to start , finish nearly bone dry , and quite clean .   overall : this be a special beer . there be a reason it be so respected , and I fully understand it . there be other amazing raspberry sour out there , and I 've have several of they , but Atrial Rubicite be in a league of its own , and be without a doubt , a world class wild ale , and one deserve of praise . if you be read this and wonder , stop wonder . get the bottle .

pour an almost entirely opaque brown with tinge of light come through at the edge , with a big , light tan head that dissipate slowly . ' 20 batch .   Maman 2020 be a blend of 2 distinct thread . the first consisting of base stout age 22 month in Heaven Hill barrel , this comprise 80 % of the blend . the remain 20 % be base stout age 27 month on Weller barrel . we taste through a couple dozen barrel to find a blend that well exemplify our beloved barrel age stout , Maman . Oak , maple , marshmallow , and caramel all dominate the aroma , with wave of rich brownie batter fudge and Heath bar wrap up the palate . we always strive for a balance of flavor in our beer , and we feel the nuance and surprising drinkability make this vintage of Maman something we ’re immensely proud of .   this one pour a very dark black color , with a small head , and not much lacing .   this smell like high quality chocolate truffle , cookie dough , brownie , vanilla , spicy oak , caramelly bourbon , english toffee , marshmallow , heavy roast , and light smoke .   this have be high on my list of " must - try " for a long time , and it really do meet my expectation . it be a pure expression of the power of barrel - you could tell I this have chocolate or vanilla or caramel add to it , and I 'd believe you . there be very little booze here , and there be great oaky complexity on the back end helping keep thing balanced . there be some definite roast and bitterness - it be not just pure pastry here .   this be medium bodied , not the thick stout ever , but that honestly help here - keep it light on its foot and very drinkable . there be barely any booze to this .   it be hard to find much to fault this one for . it be truly excellent - barrel aged chocolate marshmallow chunk brownie , essentially .

I have to say I be blow away by the flavor in this . deep dark fudge bourbon goodness . it ’ a showcase of what the barrel alone can bring to the party . and what a party it be . thick . Velvet smooth , vanilla , chocolate swirl . wonderful .

Maman 2018   pour a truly oily , coal black color with a fluffy , beige head , receede to a small ring of lacing .   smell of profound bitter chocolate , baker chocolate , campfire and a gentle , yet profound bourbon aroma . relatively straight forward on the nose , yet equally intriguing as for its complex bourbon and chocolate interplay .   drink surprisingly easy , thick with a full body , its booze be perfectly soak up by the luscious chocolate flavor profile . this feature almost a flat level of carbonation , while the beer‘s mouthfeel be that that thick , that it benefit tremendously from the lack of potentially mineralic effervescence , highlight its multi layered chocolate decadence .   taste of rich milk chocolate , soothe by layer of whip cream and oaky , slighty warm bourbon barrel . warm up even more with a rustic barrel presence , soothe by the incredibly smooth and silk mouthfeel , accompany by bitter chocolate and slightly spicy licorice . finish a little sweet , reminiscend of a rock sugar cocoa blend , tie together by tobacco and even more whip cream , more licorice and a little bit of charred malt , top off by a long last , spicy bourbon aftertaste .   this be astonishtingly complex while the beer drink incredibly easy at the same time . also this offer the most incredible mouthfeel , smooth and soft , caress the tongue in the most pleasant way , while handle the 13 abv playfully . on the one hand this be a pretty straight forward chocolate imperial stout , on the other hand this open up the palate to a plethora of finely nuance flavor , result in a truly complex tasting beer . what a treat , this be a clear winner due to its emphasize world class mouthfeel , allow the flavor to shine like in no other beer .

enjoy side by side at a share with Beer : barrel : time . my expectation be sort of turn on their head as BBT be the clear loser between the two ... and for some reason , I 'd expect Maman to spice in some way . not so . 2017 vintage   Smell : the Barrel be the star of the show on the nose . the whiskey that come through be so smooth and strong it ’s singe the nose hair in the good way . there also a little bit of spice come through as well a touch of vanilla , coconut , tobacco , oak and leather . also there be some underlie chocolate note . dark chocolate , and coco powder . this beer smell like a grade a whiskey with beer attribute . this smell so strong and so damn amazing .   taste : right upfront the beer hit with big chocolate note . dark chocolate brownie batter and dusty coco powder . the beer transition to the mid palette where your hit with some dark fruit . plum , fig , raisin as well as a touch of vanilla . the barrel start to make an assertive presence as well . Whiskey , oak , coconut , leather , tobacco , maple syrup , rye spice , and a touch of dark cherry round out this beautiful beer . the whiskey and barrel note linger in the aftertaste .   feel : full body with a fair amount of carbonation . the beer be smooth but drink big . this be definitely a classic example of a sipper .   overall : this be a wonderful beer that highlight everything a whiskey barrel have to offer . if you do n’t like whiskey you probably wo n’t enjoy this because it be the start of the show . the whiskey barrel be really smooth and present but it never get to hot and still allow for the beer to be there in the background . overall this be a 100/100 to I , but be it worth the high trading price tag probably not . barrel aged sump be just as good if not well in my opinion and it go for a lot less . still this be an amazing beer ! that be worth get if your willing to pay the price of admission .

l : Hazy yellow with a thick , creamy head and good lacing .   s : bright , pungent tropical fruit , grapefruit , a small amount of dank , pine , and a touch of spicy booze . some subtle pale malt in the background as well .   t : firm but mild bitterness upfront , move into a huge wave of citrusy tropical fruit flavor . a piney resinous edge to the flavor as well as some peach note . the malt flavor be surprisingly full and provide a good base as well as a bit of sweetness to support the hop flavor .   f : full bodied but still a dry finish .   overall : a full on juicy hop experience with surprising complexity for a single - hop beer . everything work perfectly to create a supremely balanced and drinkable ale .

pick up a 6 pack of this at the source in late October . what a fun day that be .   pour a cloudy yellow with 1/3 " white head . good retention for style . have the nice Galaxy smell , pineapple definitely the most prominent tropical fruit note .   taste be easy like Sunday morning , below average bitterness , below average hop burn / acidity . above average tropical fruit note , still lead by the pineapple quotient . while the side project wild beer have certainly be tend more acidic over the least year or so , in some instance , I think the high acidity really work , and this be a great example of that . another one of the fruit fermi beer , up there with my favorite in the series , the plum , the cherry , and the blueberry , and I think the clean sourness that ramp up towards the end be part of what make it . there be a lot of fruit in here , and a serious jammy sweetness be contribute by the raspberry , so the sour almost work to enhance and balance it , and with all the oak this have on it , along with the lemony funk , the dry cereal grain base , and the obvious maturity , its a complex and balanced brew that deliver what it seem to promise . blend # 4 .   this one pour a very thick - look and murky dark brown , nearly black , with a very small head , and no lacing .   this smell like caramel , leather , chocolate , oak , sherry , port , spice , maple , toffee , bourbon , and tobacco .   this be truly excellent stuff . it be get a lot of barrel , and it be much dry and more nimble than some of the absolute saccharine beast you get in this style . there be a dry toasted oak thing , and the bourbon come across swinge leather belt across the face . there be some spice and vanilla from the barrel , too . the base be more caramel and toffee than some of that dark dry fruitiness you often get from the style , but I do get a kind of dry sweetness , almost like sherry or port - that honestly could be some pleasant oxidization . the beer be in barrel for two year , so it be very possible .   this be medium bodied , creamy , and very rich and thick , with absolutely no booze character to it . this be 14 % , and the booze be hide just so well - it be a miracle in malt flexing .   it be easy to see why this be so well - regard . it be really one of the good barleywine I 've ever have .

Viscous , almost syrupy , yet silky smooth , Anabasis b3 kick off with dark fruit and Reisen before a sudden , surprisingly woody barrel presence . it be a little splintery at first , and quite mature , before develop some note of decadence with time , such as nutty nougat , maple , and hint of caramel apple .   quite delicious , but maybe a little too woody , so I have a few other preferred favorite in this category . frankly , I be still surprised by the lofty pedestal that barleywine like this be place while brewery like Cigar City just casually put out banger on the regular that be at LEAST just as good .   ---   share a b5 bottle with friend mid - May 2021 , I be find it to be surprisingly chocolatey . while there be a ton of bourbon barrel on back end , it be simultaneously less woody overall , allow room for the dark malt to really edge this ever close to stout territory . the charred oak add classic nougat impression , but also some unexpected marzipan quality .   it be overall less astringent and hoppy than I remember b3 , and as such , I be enjoy it even more , even if it be drift far away from American , or even english # life . as such , I be hesitant to alter my already fairly high score .

I have long be try to track this one down , and I be stoke to finally have get the chance to enjoy it , blend three , an awfully fine example of the style , adjunct free if I understand it right , and truly want for nothing . it certainly be a beast of a beer , not just at this strength , but also with this amount of oak and sweetness , its a lot of everything , and its a proper sipper to say the least . deep deep caramel in color , reddish in the right light , neither murky nor clear , someplace in between , with just a short frothy khaki color layer of foam on it from the bottle . the nose be crazy , an awful lot of bourbon and oak , I think it be heaven hill barrel they use for this , and two year in they ! heavy vanilla , wet tobacco , and english toffee abound there , some light tannin from the wood , as well as some oxidation when I taste it , something I never really mind in the style , and really be a sign of its maturity . the malt be huge , sweet like brown sugar and maple , and carry that vanilla tune pretty nicely though the whole drink , a ton of body on it and a long linger even with the abundant alcohol at the end , its persistent . oxidation meet a robust english yeast strain too , bready and doughy even , add a lot of depth . no hop really to speak of , although overall this somehow have some balance between all the element at the end . whiskey for mile , boozy and sweet , dense and even chewy , but also fully wintery , warming , and satisfy . something to be share for sure , but a prime example of the style and what extended barrel age look like . impressive and worthy of be celebrate . that say , not the most interesting barleywine I have ever have , not the most dial in I do nt think either , but a special beer without a doubt !

there be two thing that most craft beer nerd get wrong about Anabasis :   1 ) the pronunciation of its name 2 ) the perceive G.O.A.T status of this beer in the realm of barleywine   it take nearly four year to track down a pour of this legendary beer , but only a fraction of that time to realize that I -along with the majority of the craft beer world- have be deceive by the Hype - Lords of the American Midwest .   Anabasis be a largely one - note barleywine that deliver on mild licorice flavor with a prominent bourbon barrel character on the front of the palate and little else . it miss the mark on what a truly great barleywine should deliver in term of taste . there be no depth of flavor or complexity to this beer ( on the palate ) , fall far short of the flowery " taste note " description that C. King offer on the label of the bottle .   perhaps the save grace of this beer be that it be remarkably thick , relative to other barrel aged offering in this style . to this end , Anabasis resemble more of a stout than a barleywine , which sit well with the mouthfeel chaser of the hobby .   if you be a true fan of the barleywine style , Anabasis be sure to disappoint , give the incredible amount of hype surround the beer and the overall underwhelming flavor profile it present . if , however , your flavor preference lean more towards simple stout , this may be the beer for you ; the mouthfeel and barrel character that envelop the base beer be world class and worth visit if the cost of entry be low .   the letdown of this beer remind I of my first Hill Farmstead Ann experience . a combination of low bottle count , high trade value , exorbitant secondary value , and craft beer FOMO lead to an artificially inflated expectation of the beer , one which ultimately detract from the overall enjoyment of the drink in my glass .   there be many other barleywine that can be acquire and consume with far less effort than it take to land a bottle of Anabasis that likely will yield a more enjoyable tasting experience . I assure you , the rarity of this bottle and its secondary value do not contribute in any way to a more enhanced flavor or a great overall enjoyment of this beer .

2018 batch - can 8/10   8/23 : I could understand the hype , but it be way too dank for I . it pop up in the mid palate and wipe everything else out , except for the greenness . otherwise , it be excellent on the initial attack , with soft tropical fruit .   9/20 : I be now part of the hype . the dankness and greenness have mellow out to allow more of the tropical fruit to pop up . dankness be still heavy , but come through prominently in the finish with a medium bitterness . a month 's time have do this wonder , and I like it significantly more than I do when fresh .

headroom have be a wishlist beer for a couple of year now - as with other trillium offering , I 've only sporadically be able to nail down trade . we be only talk about ipa here - but they can still be confoundingly difficult to locate .   Headroom , strangely , fall in to my lap via a friend . this 2018 release can be a very pleasant surprise .   the beer pour a light orange - the nose be soft and fruity and very pleasant . Mouthfeel be rich - in a blind test , I might very easily misidentify this beer as a milkshake IPA . it be surprisingly , really - it be just super thick and yeasty and malty . it be also tremendously sweet and soft , which I think may be the unfortunate source of the slight linger and unpleasant aftertaste . it could definitely use a bit of a clean finish . I 'd also have to add that it be just a bit boozy - the ABV be n't really discernible per se , but it be certainly a little hot than your standard 8 % IPA . I like , and do not like , this about the beer . I 'd really like it to be a little more sessionable .   but , that be my personal bias , and I have n't factor that in to my rating .   Headroom be a fantastic beer - I 'll admit that I 'd prefer a lot more DDH Fort Point in my life , but lack the option , I 'd very definitely take some headroom !

cable car 2014 on 180617   pour a bright golden - yellow color with a small , yet stable white head .   offer a mineralic apple sweetness , which gets balance by old cheese , cellar funk and a lovely hay softness . atop of this settle lime z , make this quite sour on the nose , together with lot of old leather and some malt sweeten moldy woodbark . this be definitely more funky than acidic with an unforseen richness of aromas , due to the well enveave malt sweetness , ampe everything else up by a few notch .   unusually full bodied for a sour beer with lot of flavor batter down the palate at the same time , soothe by a mineralic effervescence . this bring a stony quality to the palate , make this highly refreshing , while never loose its true goal , of create a multi layered sourness .   Yupp this be sour , not your typical awa in - your - face acidity , but a very well nuanced , matured and balanced tartness . this come along with blue cheese , dry mushroom , green apple peel , tangerine pulp and a note of spiced cucumber . after this first impression , the beer settle down a little , allow sweet wheat and a subtle note of toffee to cut through , enrich but mellow the omnipotent sourness at the same time . there be even more funk after the swallow , now accompany by a bright mineralic effervescence , push the sourness a bit more into the background , unfold old cream cheese and dry garden herb . finish almost calm , aqueous with a linger apple - lemon tartness and soft , sunbathe wheat .   Stunning . this beer want to get discover slow and carefully , since it simply need time to adjust to the offer complexity . it be a very rewarding process though , exhibit the most perfect unfruited awa I 've have so far . the beer hit every mark you could expect from a world class sour , so sit back and enjoy the ride .

the listing say this be retire but Cycle have it on tap at Barrel Aged Day March 13 , 2020 . it be available at both tap station and it do n't last long . I get one from each station and it seem slightly different .   Look- a dark black with a coating of beige head that cling to the edge of the glass . 650ml bottle , of the 2016 release . serve in a snifter glass .   pour a with a dark black oily flourish , one finger thick white head , very good retention and film ; bit of lacing . Smell and flavour be really loopy here . first off , the smell seem to be strawberry vanilla , with vary component of the two depend on when you be smell it . not sure what it be , sometimes it smell like strawberry milk ( like a Yoohoo ) , other time it smell like vanilla and bourbon , and in the background be a vary amount of chocolate and cocoa . it be strange , but damn , it be wonderful and make you want to keep go back for more . Flavour be similarly shifty ; it be delicious but difficult to nail down one flavour at a time . Strawberry milk , vanilla bean , vanillin from the barrel , oak , a good bit of bourbon sweetness but not heat , dark chocolate and fudge from the bourbon . wonderful and actually a very complex flavour to it . Mouthfeel be full bodied , creamy and luscious , appropriately carbonate , and it be really difficult to put this down . you really do find yourself want to drink more after each sip . a very damn tasty beer that somehow work despite the high potential for the adjunct to completely fail and make this undrinkable . this be a beer I could have drink all to myself over the course of a hour . while the strawberry be more of the Yoohoo ! variety , I think that work well in a beer like this than the light natural strawberry flavour that one initially think of .

got this one from desp59 . cheer !   from a bomber into a snifter Described as Neapolitan flavor beer ice cream   appearance : jet , opaque black pour yield a 2 + finger , medium look , slightly fizzy , dark tan head with good retention . a little noisy this one be , but good color . pitch black body with no carbonation evident . Head slowly fade to a full foamy cap . Splotchy wisp remain with fall dot of lacing . good color and a dark head for the style .   smell : bourbon , oak , sweet vanilla cream , milk chocolate , butterscotch and some strawberry note . really candy - like aroma . the vanilla and strawberry combo do indeed give off the impression of boozy ice cream , but not at all in an artificial way . pretty entice .   taste : candy flavor up front with strawberry , vanilla cream and boozy bourbon up front . plenty of bourbon at the swallow with booze and candy sweetness as well . a bold and linger finish of bourbon , alcohol , strawberry flavor , sweet vanilla cream , some milk chocolate and sweet toffee as well . plenty of sweetness here and the barrel be bold and boozy as well . pretty tasty treat .   palate : fuller body with slightly low level of carbonation . creamy and weighty on the palate , go down fine with a good scratch at the swallow and finish quite sticky . a good amount of heat linger . love the thick , silky feel here . slick . Awesome .   overall : great stuff . this have all the right element in all the right amount . the strawberry flavor work great and do n’t overwhelm the beer , leave plenty of space for the vanilla , chocolate and barrel character to add flavor and layer to the beer . the look and feel be top notch as well . really glad to have be able to try this one and would gladly drink another . cycle never cease to impress with its adjunct and barreled stout . highly recommend . thank again desp59 !

it be finally about to happen ... year I 've dream about this bottle . year it have elude I . now , on my birthday evening , I be stare face - to - face with Aaron - prepare to crack he open .   I be ready   2015 vintage - Bottled May , 2017 - pour into a shifter at 45 ° F .   pour out with a glug , glug , glug , sit a ruddy , rusty red - brown hue - cloudy , but do let some light in . a partial loose tan head bubble , before quickly dissipate to a thin tan collar . 4.5   Nose : as soon as the cap come off , the aroma fill the room . english barleywine to a T. Sweet malt , raisin , toffee , brown sugar , caramel , Werther 's original , leather , varnish , maple , cherry wood , pecan , maraschino cherry , candy date , black grape , prune , and a kiss of molasse , all wrap up into splintery white oak , with a beautiful bourbon presence , lending vanilla , and more caramel . a whisper of roast , some musty old rackhouse , and age . time . maturity . 4.5   palate : Aaron greet the palate with a big sweet hug of toffee , caramel , date , dry fig , dry cherry , raisin , vanilla , plum , pecan , and maple . rich , decadent , and bold , yet not cloy , as a second wave with oak , bourbon , and ton of dark fruit wash in and cut into the sweetness . the dark fruit be very prominent , lend a subtle fruity tart kiss , which be crucial to provide balance . a round , malty nuttiness follow , with pecan , walnut , and that almost fatty element to they . the woody oak presence grow , and with it , some malt milk , vanilla creme , and just a dusting of cocoa , before the bourbon finally emerge , flow into the finish - dry now , with splintery white oak and just a shadow of barrel char .   Mouthfeel / body : this be near - perfection . Aaron be rich , luscious , smooth , thick , and a bit viscous , yet avoid ever be syrupy , cloy , or overbearing . the oak and dark fruit brightness cut in just enough to thin it out , and the 9 % ABV ensure it be n't pure glue , but world away from thin . restrain , but respectable effervescence for the age , size , and style , and finish with an incredible oaky dryness .   overall : Aaron be the number one rate english barleywine on BeerAdvocate , and for good reason - however , this go beyond superficial rating . Hill Farmstead instill magic in all of their hoppy and farmhouse ale , and Aaron be no exception . it be a beer with an identity , from a brewery with an identity . I be not sure you could brew a well english barleywine if you try . yes , Aaron be hard to get , but if you can get he fairly , you 'll be reward .

a near perfect example of an english barleywine , this one aged two year in bourbon barrel and also bottle condition . its the saison and wild beer that get all the attention from these guy , but this be as good as anything else in the game in this style , and seem gentler , more subtle , and more mature and drinkable than other over the top , barrel heavy offering with lot of residual sugar , firestone walker come to mind there , this be just a wonderful cold weather sipper , and honestly the essence of the style as far as I be concern , big thank to my buddy for share this one ( among many other ) , in an epic session over the weekend , I have be want to try this forever . this have a deep matte mahogany color to it , a tall tan head creamy and thick , and no visible sediment at all , look well clean up and mature . the aroma be rich barley malt , some sweet long boil and toffee character to it , chestnut , maple , and toast bread . its immediately not that sweet , full of earthiness , and enormously layer . the bourbon have some vanilla and honey note go on , but do nt interfere with the base beer , it enhance , sweet oak in the mix as well , raisin , and fig . the flavor be amazing , really about the barley malt , very enlgish to I , no hop at all , maybe some maris otter in here with some dark crystal , definitely a concentrated richness to it without decadent sweetness weigh it down , and the booziness be minimal for the style , although this be a bit low anyway , I like it not be a focal point in the taste . the bourbon and oak be smooth and not too forward , and there be a wonderful depth and body to this , well and well as it warm too . the perfect balance of all the element here , some yeast character through most of it , and a curiously clean finish for the style . near perfection here , no frill barleywine as it should be . a wonderful drinking experience !

375ml bottle - date 121218 - pour into a classic tulip at 48 ° F .   Cork immediately push upward as the cage be loosen , abd as I let go , it hurt out with a huge , forceful percussive * pop ! * - fly several yard away . some cork rot be visible .   pour a clear ruddy deep reddish copper - brown hue , top woth a finger of coarse pinkish - brown head that quickly reduce to a thin collar , feed by stream of effervescence climb the glass wall .   Nose : absolutely stunning right from the start . Bold , intense aroma of lightly toast grain bring a gentle caramel sweetness , big musty cherry that have begin to lose its battle with age , warm , fruity red wine note , with just enough oxidation to lend some sherry and brandy characteristic , and a panoply of stew dark fruit . there be a present , but balanced brettanomyce influence , lend the perfect amount of musty funk , forest floor , dusty cellar , petrichor , and this sort of morning - on - the - lake aroma . and it be all hold together by a splintery oaken halo , which provide some leather , varnish , and old parchment . beautiful .   palate : supplication greet the palate drier than the aroma would lead one to believe . the grain peek through just a touch , with a hint of dustiness , while the cherry , with all their sugar ferment out step up with big funky , mushy skin and pit note . interestingly , the wine character lack all fruitiness , and reveal itself with dry , tannic , soak cask note . as it open up , a plummy dark fruit note emerge midpalate . acidity be mild to moderate , with a quick twinge upfront , and quickly extinguish by the dry , tannic , splintery white oak . there be plenty of musty , dusty brett funk , reminiscent of overripe apricot pit , but there be also this subtle earthy , almost mold - like funk that may very well be from cork rot . the finish be exceedingly dry , with plentiful woody oak .   Mouthfeel / body : the ale be light to medium - bodied , bright , snappy , and exceedingly crisp for nearly 8 % ABV . the grain to lend some soft texture , and the fruit addition , while dry , do lend additional body . effervescence be lively , zippy , and foam up over the palate . tannic and dry .   overall : this be a very nice , classic fruit wild ale . I love the jammy stuff as much as the next person , but there be something beautifully rustic and raw about these one . every ounce of sugar have be ferment out , leave a seriously musty , funky , fermented cherry flavour , rely on that touch of grain to give it body . the funk be very earthy , but play well with the cherry , and the wine translate as mature , funky , wet oak - and lot of it . the subtle plummy note be tasteful , and it all come together to show the ale 's depth and character . a fantastic offering .

* pour into a Teku glass from a 375ml bottle *   this beer pour an orangeish - brown ran color , a bit murky . there be an initial two finger thick white color head to it , but it almost immediately disappear as soon as it be pour into my glass . the head leave a razor thin white colored lace around my glass .   Needless to say , this beer be super funky , probably the funky beer I 've have so far . Upfront , I get note of leather , oak , pinot , and generally just funky horse blanket . in the back - end , I get a bit more note of sour cherry , but the fruitiness that be present be n't nearly as prominent as the earthy and funky aroma that I get in the front .   as expect , this beer be very sour forward and funky . I get big note of acetic acid upfront along with a nice funk from the brett , both be couple with prominent note of oak and pinot . the sourness mellow a bit towards the middle and end , where the beer showcase more of its sweet / tart cherry note in the middle , follow by a slight but noticeable bready malt character in the finish . truly a nice balance between the flavor of the cherry , barrel , and brett / lacto / pedio .   this beer be medium bodied and have a medium amount of carbonation to it . the beer also leave a little dry sensation in my mouth . obviously this be super sour and puckering , but I still think that this be relatively drinkable . I probably would never chug this down , but still really drinkable .   overall , this be a very good wild ale . this beer be very balanced , showcase nice note of its barrel character as well as the cherry and note of the bacteria . I be not typically a big fan of sour , but I definitely enjoy this one and would definitely buy this again if give the chance .

this be a funky one .   l : Amber with a soft white head that do n't stick around too long . not much lace on the glass .   s : pretty good preview of the taste . lot of funk with a mix of cherry , red wine , oak , and floral element .   t : Middle of the road tartness with a lot of sour cherry . there be definitely a strong red wine backbone with some oak flavor too . mostly sour cherry , which be not my personal favorite . be n't overpower like some sour cherry beer I 've have , but definitely dominate the flavor .   f : Thinner mouthfeel . pretty dry and decently carbonate .   o : Cherry beer be n't my favorite , but this be the good I 'd have . I feel the beer be well when it be cold , and as the beer warm it become a little drier and more of the red wine and oak flavor come out . I think this give the beer a pretty complex flavor , but sour cherry with red wine be a little much for I . felt more sour as it warm .

smell wonderful ! it ’ truly a fine Belgium inspire brew that any fine monk would enjoy . amazing how the taste of the Pinot noir enhance the taste bud when I be usually adverse to wine alone . just outstanding !

it look beautiful with light carbonation remain after a pour . the smell be a bit muted but you can smell a bit of funk . there be so much happen in the taste . the carbonation be spot on . 375 ml cork and cage , bottle on 9/2/2016 .   my friend bring back two bottle of this from the brewery for I a few year ago . I drink one fresh and the other after cellare for 3 year . wow time 5 ! an explosive pop of the cork announce that you be in for a real treat . appearance : wow , it ’ a beautiful red - orange color . it require a gentle pour to prevent the head from escape the glass . aroma : wow , this could be a good sell man ’s cologne ! musky , musty , earthy , funk , cedar , wine & a lot more than I can identify . taste : wow , there be some much go on here . a fascinating blend of t bitter , tart & salty . add cherry , vanilla & alcohol to those list in the aroma to make one of the most complex flavor profile I ’ve ever taste . feel : wow , it ’s the perfect blend of viscosity , carbonation & alcohol . it make the mouth happy . overall : wow , this beer be incredible ! pair with a good cheese like an aged emmi , you get a double dose of earthyness . oh , no ! my class be empty , 12 oz be not enough . why do n’t I buy 4 or 6 ?

product_name: A Deal With The Devil - Double Oak-Aged
product_review: Caramel apple , fruit leather , and a wave of oak w/ hint of orchard rot on the finish . when cold , what it lack in complexity it gain in its expression of candied fruit , which evolve from a bold apricot - like sweetness to a dry apple skin / orchard rot / barrel tannin character on the finish . although it be n't aged in Cognac barrel , the fruity quality and heat on the finish give the impression of Cognac or at least some fortify wine .   when it warm , though , it shift gear : fruit leather base tone blend with gentle mid tone of toffee cookie , molasse , and brown sugar .   almost go into B4 K brown butter / crispy pancake edge territory , but instead veer into a wonderful fruit leather zone . Delicious

product_name: A Deal With The Devil - Double Oak-Aged
product_review: 2020 wax can release .   a : pour a deep , red - tint cola color with foam that dissipate immediately . a bit murky looking . no lacing but extensive alcohol leg .   s : Butterscotch , dark red dry fruit , leather , bourbon , a bit of vanilla , oak , cola , coconut , and ethanol burn . pretty flavorful .   t : Rich caramel , vanilla , red fruit , bourbon , a bit of chocolate , coconut , and oak , finish with dark cherry and cognac on a long , elegant finish . medium - high sweetness with a touch of tannin to offset it .   m : medium - full bodied , roundish , with a mild alcohol burn . mild carbonation .   o : big , sweet english barleywine . great red fruit , caramel , and barrel character , though the sweetness limit the drinkability quite a bit .

product_name: A Deal With The Devil - Double Oak-Aged

product_name: A Deal With The Devil - Double Oak-Aged
product_review: burn mahogany brown with a short mocha head that fizzle out audibly to a silky coffee black surface .   first whiff be salt caramel , and first taste be Heath bar -- both association come across as instantly recognizable .   sweet but delectable , it be get a sherry like oak that bring with it that signature nougat character . charred barrel emerge more and more as it warm , also with more heat , yet never too much .   the medium body be fine yet lightly syrupy sticky , but its firmly dense carbonation come into a nicely woody dry , gullet warming finish . while it seem like it might be a bit sweet than I remember batch 2 in 2014 being , there be not one single off - note .   ---   I be not sure why or when these entry be merge , since the vintage go through different treatment , but the above review be for the upside down , black wax pint can . in July 2021 , I finally get my hand on a 2017 red wax 12 ounce bottle , and find it to be fully deserving of all its laurel .   the oak be actually still really assertive . the overall expression be peppery whiskey , mature port and cocoa - dust date all envelop by an excellent char that be far more forward and bold than I have expect , without be overbearing or unpleasant . it be a dichotomy that do n't often occur , or even make sense , as the body here be n't particularly thick or dampening , and such a bold barrel presence can often become too spicy , boozy , burn or woody . however , here on exhibit be a magical convergence of fortune .   I can see how this rocket Anchorage to its lofty hype status , but I be not sure they 've ever quite achieve such height again . such be the peril of transcendence . as such , I be not go to increase my score , opt instead to keep the more recent , but still excellent , vintage as precedent .

product_name: A Deal With The Devil - Double Oak-Aged
product_review: 2017 vintage : a bit of malt , molasse , caramel . sweet . light brown color , translucent , not much head . plenty of barrel . fantastic .   2020 vintage : this can be quirky , but okay - point for novelty . lot of caramel , raisin , and barrel . very , very sweet - near pastry level . slightly thick and more opaque .

product_name: A Deal With The Devil - Double Oak-Aged
