January 1st , 2016 - I be feast on the 2010 addition of this bottle , and it be a european treat , with a barnyard smell that be appeal even if it be a little feral . it have a rich , fecund , manure scent with horse blanket and soil . at last , after see these descriptor attach to wine and cheese and other delicacy I can see why animal poop can be something nice on a beer 's bouquet . and the beer surprise again with the first taste , and an incredibly well craft sourness , with any excessiveness acid trim and leave a brilliant profile . it hint and tease at sweetness , but fall just short , instead offer tartaric tang . brilliance in a bottle , with a side of horse .

receive from @2beerdogs in NBS BIF # 10 . review 1/19/20 . thank Derek ! faintly stamp on rear label " 2018 " . a more legible date be find on the cork which break when be pull . the end of the cork expose to the lambic be stain opera mauve . store at home at 42 degree and serve at 54 degree in a hand wash and dry Jester King snifter . final temperature 57 degree . appearance – 4 . first pour – Mauve , clear . body – Garnet , translucent . when hold to direct light , cardinal red and clear . head – go by the end of the pour . a single tiny bubble - wide crown and no cap remain . lacing – none . Aroma – 4 – initially a very fruity grape odor which fade into a weak vinous fragrance . flavor – 4 – begin slightly bitter with subdued grape flavor . end slightly dry with a bit of pink grapefruit aftertaste on the tongue . not sure if the bitterness be from the grape use , the lambic process , or some tannin from the barrel – it ’ more of a background tooth - squeak thing . no alcohol ( 7 % ABV as mark on label ) aroma or flavor . no diacetyl , no dimethylsulfide . palate – 4 – medium , watery , soft but lively carbonation . final impression and summation : 4.5 . the whole be great than the sum of the part . I love the color . where I live , concord grape rule , and I ’m not a wine drinker ( except for an occasional bottle or three of tawny port ) , so beer base on merlot grape be somewhat of a novelty . now , I think it ’s time to start seek more Saint Lamvinus . thank Derek – I need a new quest !

pour a clear , deep , dark ruby red coloration with a small , fizzy head that fade to a thin ring around the glass almost instantly , with very slightly visible carbonation . Smell be quite dominate by a lovely tart red grape aroma , with milder note of blue cheese funk and musty oak , as well as just a hint of red berry and mild tannin . taste be an excellent balance of quite vibrant , slightly tart red grape , some light blue cheese funk and a distinct , mildly tannic , musty oak presence , as well as subtle hint of red berry , lemon peel and balsamic vinegar . finish quite dry , with a light tartness and some red grape and musty oak linger in the aftertaste . Smooth , effervescent mouthfeel with a medium body and medium / strong carbonation .   while the sour and funky note be a lot more subtle here than I expect , this really make up for that with an absolutely sublime balance of vibrant fruit character , strong oak presence and funky highlight , while also display quite a dry body round out by a light sweetness . the red grape and berry note , as well as mildly tannic , musty oak lend a certain vinous quality to this that be quite pleasant and also enrichen this with a certain depth , while still remain quite refreshing and easily drinkable at the same time . a superb lambic overall , that be perhaps not quite as rich and complex as other example of the style , but make up for that with a subtle , nuanced balance that be absolutely sublime .

pour a non - translucent light purple color - almost like diluted grape juice . very little head on presentation . the smell be tart , dry and vinous with a whiff of grape skin and oak . some funk push through in the nose . the taste be so balanced and easy to drink . it be tart , dry ( not as dry as many of their other fruit lambic ) , mildly sour with just a slight oak mustiness and note of fresh grape skin . while it be an overall dry lambic , there be some sweetness from the grape that balance out the tartness . it have a medium bodied mouthfeel with just mild acidity , not too harsh . overall , one of the well Cantillon 's I 've try . it really stand out for be well balanced . while it use merlot grape , I would n't describe the beer have a taste resemble the quality of Merlot ( leathery and dark fruit ) , however this be a 2014 bottle and it may differ from a fresher version . it do have a nice vinous quality which I assume be from the Merlot grape .

one of the good Cantillon beer I ’ve try . 2016 bottle pour into a stemmed bulb . pour hazy and pulpy plum purple color . beautiful color . look : Clear Purple with medium pink fizzy head that recede immediately . have medium carbonation . smell : merlot grape , oak , tart , and cherry . taste : tart , merlot grape , oak , and a little funk . mouthfeel : light and delicate . overall : a good lambic from Cantillon , but I do n’t think this live up to the hype or the price tag .

look : thick 1.5 purple red head , color be a clear blood red Smell : beautiful crisp funk , some oak , cherry and a very powerful merlot . taste : clean tart sour be the first impression , as it settle you get oak and a ton of grape feel : chewy like a big thick mouth feel and body , medium carbonation and finish semi dry .   overall : a very solid merlot base lambic .

pour a cloudy burgundy with a thin almost pinkish white ring of foam around the edge . the nose be not stellar in this beer . strong barnyard , but not pleasant like other cantillon beer . a bit vinegary and only hint of the vine . the taste be altogether different from the nose . very balanced with an ultra sweet middle , mild funk , and clean dry finish . not really vinous in flavor , more grapeish . feel be light and effervescent . overall this beer scare you when you take a whiff but it unexpectedly live up to the hype in the flavor which have no bearing to the smell . there be a little bit of wine in the nose but approach more grape .

I have have several vintage of this and I must say I like it more young . the wine be not overbearing but provide a brightness that be just wonderful . dark fruit on the nose and palate . some funk , but not overbearing . it be more like blackberry or jam than wine but this be tasty .

5800th review ! 750 ml bottle into tulip glass , bottle on 11/14/2016 . list at 7 % on the label . Cork be wet under the cap , and almost fall apart remove it . pour lightly hazy ruby reddish orange / pink / purple color with a 1 - 2 finger fairly dense and fluffy light pink head with good retention , that reduce to a thin ring of lace that linger . light spotty lace cling on the glass , with a fair amount of streaming carbonation . Aromas of big tart plum , apricot , cherry , raspberry , strawberry , cranberry , red grape , fruit skin , lemon , lime , green apple , grapefruit , hay , straw , grass , cork , wood , wheat , and cracker ; with light note of leathery / musty funk , vanilla , red wine vinegar , and yeast / oak earthiness . damn nice aroma with great balance of complexity of fruity / funky / fairly acidic yeast , red grape , pale malt , and oak barrel note ; with great strength . taste of big tart plum , apricot , cherry , raspberry , strawberry , cranberry , red grape , fruit skin , lemon , lime , green apple , grapefruit , hay , straw , grass , cork , wood , wheat , and cracker ; with light note of leathery / musty funk , vanilla , red wine vinegar , and yeast / oak earthiness . light - moderate fruity / lactic tartness ; light fruit tang and yeast / oak spiciness on the finish . linger note of tart plum , apricot , cherry , raspberry , strawberry , cranberry , red grape , fruit skin , lemon , lime , green apple , grapefruit , hay , straw , grass , cork , wood , wheat , cracker , light leather / funk / vinegar , and yeast / oak earthiness on the finish for a while . great complexity , robustness , and balance of fruity / funky / fairly acidic yeast , red grape , pale malt , and oak barrel flavor ; with an awesome malt / tartness balance , and zero pucker flavor after the finish . light - moderate increase dryness from tartness and tangy / tannic fruit / oak . medium carbonation and body ; with a very smooth , moderately bready / grainy , fairly crisp , and acidic / tangy / tannic balanced mouthfeel that be great . zero warm alcohol for 7 % . overall this be an excellent fruit lambic . all around great complexity , robustness , and balance of fruity / funky / fairly acidic yeast , red grape , pale malt , and oak barrel flavor ; very smooth , crisp , and refreshing to drink with the modestly lactic / tangy / tannic / dry finish . well round Brett complexity and solid Lacto presence . perfectly balanced between grape , oak , and malt . be expect way more out of this . not as much depth in funky complexity , and not as jammy / vinous on fruit character as I want . a very enjoyable offering , and spot on style example otherwise .

product_name: Galaxy Dry Hopped Fort Point Pale Ale
product_review: Canned 10/05/20 . dark yellow , big head of fluffy white foam . sweet smell of citrus and tropical fruit . soft mouthfeel . taste be soft , fruity , little bit of grassy bitterness . pineapple , guava , some citrus , tad of passion fruit . Lovely Galaxy , yum beer .

product_name: Galaxy Dry Hopped Fort Point Pale Ale
product_review: pour a hazy orange with thick , fluffy head .   Smell be juicy and clean with note of mango , pineapple , orange and orange sorbet .   taste be juicy and soft with note of mango , peach , pineapple , citrus and a floral hint . soft , but distinct bitterness and remarkable balance . some sweetness on the finish .   Mouthfeel be perfect , soft , pillowy and well carbonate .   overall , a truly outstanding beer , regardless of it be an APA or IPA .

product_name: Galaxy Dry Hopped Fort Point Pale Ale
product_review: look and smell gorgeous . lot of citrus and tropical flavor on the nose . the mouthfeel be also good though the taste flavor be more on the grapefruit than citrus side . personally , I like it because it do make for a more balanced and complex beer .   I be happy to have this over sunset at a brewery . it just lack something to make it a memorable beer . the dry hopping with Galaxy be pretty good but could be well . you could tell that the base beer ( Fort Point ) be awesome and save the day .

product_name: Galaxy Dry Hopped Fort Point Pale Ale
product_review: l : Hazy yellow with a thick head and great lacing .   s : pine resin , a touch of cheese , diesel , pineapple , juicy fruit . a candylike malt aroma as well .   t : mild bitterness , big juicy hop flavor of tropical fruit , peach , and pine . the malt have a candylike flavor that reinforce the hop flavor .   f : medium / full body , lowish carb , very Lush .   overall : a really good beer that be just a little short of be great due to some off note from the hop . I get a bit of staleness that be not due to the beer age ( can two week ago ) , but other than that it be really great .

product_name: Galaxy Dry Hopped Fort Point Pale Ale
product_review: pick up can fresh from the taproom , package 2/19/20 ( just over a week old ) .   look opaque , milky yellow with a frothy white head . lot of hop aroma and flavor . full and burst with tropical fruit and citrus pulp character . clear and direct , not a complex beer but the hop be full and strong . feel medium body , soft carbonation and juicy with little to no bitterness .   overall really excellent . Glad I could pick some up !   I do n't always knock point for style guideline but I do here . sure it be great and that be how they do thing at trillium but I like pale ale to be clear and crisp . it really should be qualified as a NE IPA but the brewery call it a pale ale . I suppose the base beer without the double dry hop might be a little crisper , but still ...

product_name: Galaxy Dry Hopped Fort Point Pale Ale
product_review: pour a mango - orange with a murky transparency and a finger of white foam that retain well . Aroma be earthy papaya , tangerine and grapefruit with a little stone and yeast beyond . it be tropical fruit opening linger for a while , let the base pale ale ( which be already very hoppy ) show throw in fragment . Aroma be akin to a very powerful NE IPA . flavor profile be papaya , tangerine , mango , tangerine with a little earthy , nutty malt and raw grain and yeast to sooth thing out . it be tropical fruit through and through , and drink very similar - identical - to Trillium 's Northeast IPA ( this be label as an American Pale Ale at the time of review ) . all this to say , it be incredible hop forward , much more so than other pale ale , which may be a deterrent for some . Mouth feel be a little gritty , silty and soft , with a medium - thick consistency . it be liken to a well - wear lumpy , linen pillow . overall , despite a slightly misleading style , the name of the beer let those knowledgeable about beer that the hop content be go to be high , thus I will not knock it for the style mis - interpretation . it be big and flavorful , which be welcome in a beer . it combine well with the lightly gritty texture to develop a refined , but well - worn and knowledgeable , experience .   serve in a 15.5 oz spiegalau tulip from a 16 oz can .

product_name: Galaxy Dry Hopped Fort Point Pale Ale
product_review: classic hazy , opaque , and nearly pulpy New England look ; mango - orange body . strong head production , with about a finger and a half of off - white foam from a gentle pour . retention be solid .   Aroma be just burst with hop : bright herb ( mint , oregano , basil ) , wave of citrus ( mandarin orange , tangerine , lemon , grapefruit ) , tropical fruit ( melon , mango , strawberry , peach ) , and a honey cracker malt base beneath it all .   Brew deliver the same character to the palate . there be a chewy , grainy , crackery malt bill in the background , remind you this be an APA , while still allow the hop character to shine . bright , minty herb ; bite citrus ; mild pine and resin ; and to a less prominence , some juicy tropical tone . flavor profile match the nose in term of individual tone . more bitter than you might expect , favor grapefruit , lemon , and citrus peel a touch more than other fruit .   quite bite for the New England style , but very appropriate for an APA . still quite creamy ; surprisingly astringent .

product_name: Galaxy Dry Hopped Fort Point Pale Ale
product_review: get a pour into a growler , so very very fresh .   pour a rich orange gold color , fully opaque with a two finger off - white head that leave sporadic lacing   Aroma be dense and pungent with tangy citrus note . this be pretty intense and rockin '   taste be also very strong with up - front citrus hop that blast the tongue . the flavor turn into a more measured excellent citrus taste with a sweet base behind it . bitterness be fairly weak .   feel be very soft and lightly sticky .   this be just a fantastic beer - not sure I can call it a Pale Ale with a 6.6 % alcohol and such a full flavor . this be just an awesome variant on Fort Point which be already a great beer from trillium . really worth the high rating .

product_name: Galaxy Dry Hopped Fort Point Pale Ale

product_name: Galaxy Dry Hopped Fort Point Pale Ale

Peach , grapefruit , and white grape . finish with plenty of linger unripe peach .   great beer , taste like a Congress street light .

product_name: Galaxy Dry Hopped Fort Point Pale Ale
product_review: can on : 12/8/17 . open on 12/9/17 update review * * can on 7/9/18 .   Orange tint gold coloration , muddy body , opaque depth , with a puffy white cloud of foam recede slow . a bit of scatter coverage be leave over with nice lace .   the nose be very powerful . pungent citrus , wild honey pie , starfruit and herb with a fruity , tropical blend and black pepper from the rather excellent Galaxy hop strain . tangerine , pineapple and sweet red fruit all blend together harmoniously .   this be easily the most , tropical and citrus fruity hop flavor from a Pale Ale I 've ever have . New England style ... but not an IPA . just pale . it be like a pale ale , blend with tropical punch and o.j . mix in some earthy herb and husky wheat finish off with black pepper . a nice citrus bite bring in a juicy feel , thick body and a slightly dry , earthy toned finish . rather extreme in it be hoppy complexity and off the chart juicy style . the light wheat and golden style malt allow for maximum hop effect but still have some fine flavor 's as well . * * the clean feel and APA style flavor approach from such a thick look body be pretty amazing . it be reasonable to say this be the most complex hoppy flavor from any straight pale ale I can think of .   Galaxy be a very versatile hop , one of my all time favorite , although my specialty be the old world , european strain , Galaxy seem to bring in huge fruitiness but with plenty of old earthy tone as well . at 6.6 % abv , massive hoppiness this could easily be mistaken for an IPA . the body be thick , smooth but juicy.llI think of pale ale 's to have a clean malty body . the hop totally dominate although tge malt be nice ... lfor an IPA ! regardless , this be " what be hot " in the beer ( geek ) world right nowl New England style . do n't get I wrong , the hop complexity be mindblowe , but the balance for a Pale Ale be questionable .   overall , high quality . dense complexity in the hop , easy to drink , relentless hoppy flavor . the malt be also very tasty and unique just a bit off kilter in balance for tge style . but who review or rate a beer just on style guidline these day , anyway ? ?

we be finally at the last new beer from my late Tree House run . as far as their stout go I 've mostly have only a few of their milk stout , and only 1 imperial stout before this . let 's see if this one can hold a candle to the like of Moment of clarity   Pours completely pitch black with a thick finger of dark espresso color head that slowly fade to and ring and leave great lacing , especially for the abv and style   this beer have an aroma that toe the line between decadently sweet and firmly roasted . I be pick up on aroma of nutty espresso , milk chocolate fudge , creamy vanilla , medium roast coffee , and a touch of dark fruit , mostly raisin   follow suit taste - wise , this start off very sweet , but leave long contemplative aftertaste that suggest an aggressive yet classic stout . on the front end of the sip I be taste rich milk chocolate , creamy coffee , deep black cherry , and caramel . the swallow bring note of sweeten espresso , raisin , dark chocolate , dark toast , and chewy caramel   a full body pair with very mild carbonation , result in a creamy and chewy beer that need some time to go down . finish mostly dry surprisingly with wave of sweet and roasty weaving in and out   another winner from TH . a bit heavy at time , especially up front , but once you get past that it be smooth sailing . on a sad note , this be my last treehouse brew leave in the fridge . I nurse this bomber all by myself .   from the bottle , it pour a viscous and motor oil look dark liquid . the color be nearly pitch black . surprisingly , a finger length tan mocha head belatedly billow up to the surface . it show decent retention and ring of lacing .   as the name would suggest the nose be dominate by note of coffee and espresso . in addition , there be note of dark chocolate , toasted and nutty malts , caramel , brown sugar and dark fruit . the hop aroma have a subtle earthy and woodsy quality to they .   full body with a smooth and mouth coat viscous feel . the carbonation be gentle and mellow . the flavor be rich and complex yet not too cloyingly sweet or boozy . decadent flavor of milk chocolate fudge , caramel and brown sugar be balance by bittersweet note of dark chocolate and roasted malt . there be jammy flavor of dark fruit and bright note of cherry . surprisingly , the coffee flavor be not as prominent as in the aroma , although it be feel more in the finish . the bitterness be relatively tame as it be provide by gentle note of woodsy hop and light note of espresso . the finish be long and creamy with moderately toasty note .   this be a nice dessert beer that really hit the spot . this stuff be divine , and in such an unassuming package too , crazy ! thank to my brother for source this rarity , think I might never get to taste this one . its a treat too , so much coffee , enough so even that be stand out as way more than the vanilla bean double shit , which we enjoy right before this one . its almost gritty and bitter in comparison , but the vanilla sure do a lot to sweeten that up and round it out . here we have a truer expression of the coffee , more isolated in a way , and I love how robust it be , almost as much coffee as it be beer , although I do get a little booziness poking through this one in the aroma . the coffee have deep chocolate tone to it , a little spiciness even , a rigid sort of bitterness mid palate , and a real richness as well , note of molasse and maple work in from the grain here , and there be a neat almost amaretto layer . maybe not quite as complex as the double shot be to I , a little more straight forward from the grain , but I love the way the coffee manifest itself in here , about as forward as I have know it to be in any beer , and linger forever on the palate after each slow sip . this be the ultimate coffee beer really , and the freshness of the coffee really stand out as well , especially for something that be bottle many month before we open it . it be wonderful to finally get to drink some of these hard to get tree house stout , thank to my brother ! these be unforgettable !

batch 5 , bottled January , 2019 , drink over two night in September , 2019 first from a Hill Farmstead stem wineglass , then from a Tree House Teku .   a beautiful look beer that hit all the right note from the look , feel and smell department , same as other have describe . the taste , again , hit on those same description , be good , but for I it end up be just too acidic ; I even have to ditch the last couple ounce as my stomach have have enough . usually I be ok with excessively wild wild , etc . but the acidity for this version of BT ( only one I 've try ) , be off the chart for I - it do n't actually taste " overly " acidic ; the taste be really pretty good , it be more the effect that the acidic component have on my stomach . I have read this in a couple other review so not sure if this be typical of all bt , or if it be more isolated to this batch . or maybe some more time in the bottle would have help ? either way , it be a bit of a disappointment , especially for a beer that I have wait so long to try and so eagerly anticipate .

this one pour a slightly hazy golden yellow color , with a small head , and not much lacing .   this smell like white wine , sour candy , peach , citrus , oak , and a deep dirty funk .   this have the complexity of actual belgian lambic for sure , but maybe a bit more brash and aggressive than the most traditional take . there be lot of white wine and white fruit flavor ( white peach , white grape , etc ) . there be also bit of citrus rind and pepper , and definitely some spicy oak . this be so wonderfully delicious .   this be light bodied , clean , and very drinkable , with not a ton of linger acidity .   this be definitely one of the good beer that de Garde have do - it be mighty good .

for how hype up this particular one be , it be nowhere near my favorite beer from de garde so far , and frankly nowhere near the objective well , if that s not nitpick at this point ( all of they be so fantastic ) . I love the story of this , but from the bottle , it do nt blow I away to the extent that some of their other have , especially some of the fruit one . its really sour , more acidic than I remember most of they be , and that slow down drinkability a bit for sure , even with the amazing carbonation , soft round mouthfeel , and relative dryness to finish , its still just a slow sipper for I , which be probably how lambic should be anyway , but its sour enough to be harsh in the belly , and that s over the line for my preference . perhaps this be a product of it be in the bottle too long , be a lambic type I be in no rush to open it , but not all of these age favorably apparently . the yeast profile under the acid be fantastic , musty bretty and funky , with distinct juicy fruitiness to it , white wine , apricot , even ripe pear , its rustic and interesting , but with the acid its pretty aggressive . the oak be sturdy here too , grounding and dense all the way through which I really like , it seem sort of oddly hoppy , like they definitely do nt use hop age down to zero alpha acid , and if they do , there be some weird organic compound in the mix here somehow . its get like a fruity linger in the finish I do nt normally associate with the style . despite the develop brett and heavy wood , this do nt seem as mature to I as I would have expect for something model on gueuze with the different vintage in the blend , less of the iodine medicinal character than the old world one bring , and less of the hayloft agricultural harvest rustic character , this be almost too refined to fit that bill , not a criticism just a commentary . I think i d like it more if the sourness be less , and do nt get I wrong I still love it , but I would take a great many of their other beer before I take this one in a hypothetical draft of their good beer . always a treat to have their stuff though , and I can safely cross off this bucket list brew for now ...   edit : this be league well the second time around for I , less acidity , a lot more nuance to the wild yeast profile , and with a fresh hoppy character to it at the end , ton of white wine , elderflower , and even white peach , its goegeous , and be a standout from a heavy session of amazing beer . not sure why it do nt taste like this the first time around , but I hve a raise a few score to reflect how good it be this time . huge thank to my buddy for share his bottle !

this be really good , no doubt about it , but not as good as they say it be I do nt reckon , and once again a side project beer do nt quite live up to its hype . their culture have trend super sour lately , and this be another expression of that , just really acidic beer , complex still , still lot of nuance , bretty funk and oak and all , but its the bacterial intensity that take over this one and make it a hard large bottle to drink , even split a couple of way . I like all the apricot of course , about as natural as it get , super ripe and even soft and fuzzy like the real fruit , very forward and incredibly natural and delicious , the authenticity be through the roof . I kind of want to taste more of the wine in the barrel profile , which be tannic and heavily oaky , but not as red wine forward as I might have think for cabernet . all the wood be nice , subtle vanilla and even white tea somehow , killer with the apricot , peach juice note , even green apple and white grape wrap up in here , lot go on , but instead of mellow into a slow tart bretty funkiness like I wish it do , the sourness crank and disrupt the delicate beauty , it finish harsh and big . I mean , in all respect this be great beer , but it just do nt stand with the good wild beer in the world to my palate , maybe those who prefer a more assertive acidity will disagree , but I think its a little too much , unflattering to the fruit , and at $ 45 a bottle it just do nt do it for I ...

review from note . pour from a 750 ml bottle into a Cycle Brewing goblet .   a : a : hazy to murky yellow , with low visible carbonation . form a two - finger white head that fade fairly quickly .   s : a big punch of fruit up front - mango and guava and pineapple . Tangerine and orange citrus show up as the beer warm too , along with more of the tropical fruit mix . Dry Lactobacillus , citric acid , and a dry lactic finish with more mango fruitiness .   m : a light body but with a bit of a creamy mouthfeel . carbonation sensation just on the low side , and there be no alcohol to speak of .   o : very , very yummy - South Florida in a glass . a nice meld of flavor , and while the acidity level would render I unable to drink it all night , it be at an enjoyable level for split a 750 two way . well do .

really well do berliner type with tropical fruit . its one of the well fruity berliner I have have , and one of the good use of these fruit I have see in any beer , and while I love it , I m not sure it rank among the good beer I have ever have overall , and be nt even my favorite beer from j wakefield , although its probably still deserve of most of its hype ! do nt look like much , orange and hazy , quite thick for a beer so low in alcohol . the aroma be shocking , intensely sour , acidic , mouthwatering , puckery , all of it . with the passion fruit lead the charge , but the other fruit quite authentic and obvious in the aroma as well , juicy and intense , really different from other beer , more and more fresh . the flavor match the aroma , with a real intense fruity complexion , passion fruit and orange and mango for sure , all really alive and bold in here , but never too sweet . that s the brilliance I think , keep it dry . it do nt feel light to I though , lot of body and texture , and even the high acidity do nt lighten it up much . surprise its so clean too , go but the palate beg for another gulp as soon as it be swallow . this be not a style I usually flock to , especially with these fruit , where more often than not its gimmick over quality . this be awesomely delicious , a leader in its class no doubt !

thank you not2quick for this one !   750ml bottle - blend 5 - pour into a chalice at 50 ° F .   pour a clear , deep straw - golden hue , with just a cast of unfiltered fog , and a finger of creamy , soft , off - white head , eventually settle to a thick collar leave some lacing behind . visible effervescence .   Nose : soft , pale rustic grain , with crackery wheat and some round malt barley lend secondary note of wet hay , dewy grass , and some dusty silo . there be some remarkable floral character , lend spring blossom like lilac and hyacinth , with lemon blossom , wet stony minerality , and a lightly musty oakiness . some very restrained white vinous note , along with a touch of pear , apple , and apricot . gentle hint of honey , lemon z , and some phenolic peppery note wrap it all up in a beautifully soft and rustic olfactory display .   palate : Saison du fermi greet the palate with simultaneous wave of gentle lemony tang , semi - sweet grist with some crackery , bready , and rustic grainy note , and an explosion of bright , shimmery fruity note . Lemon , nectarine , apricot , tart white plum , green apple , asian pear , and a sweet - tart balance of fruity white grape . there be a bright but balanced minerality push these flavour to the front , along with some wet limestone . some belgian - like saison yeast bring that fruity , undertone with a bit of peppery spice intermingle with a touch of herbal hop . finish be oaky , dry , and lightly tannic .   Mouthfeel / body : it be on the light side of medium - bodied , with a tight , snappy crispness - bright and fluid , but there be enough grain to lend some softness and presence . effervescence be incredibly lively and fizzy , but fine enough to stay soft and fluffy . tart and wet up front , finish with an increasingly dryness , and a touch of cling .   overall : a lot of the fruit and more recent Side Project offering have be trend more and more acidic , which can really bring it down fast . this one show the balance and softness that I know they be capable of . it retain much of that classic belgian saison character , while contribute the classic side Project culture and grist character . soft , balanced , bright , and absolutely dial in . a top tier american oak - age saison .

* § ucaba 2019 Batch no . 008 *   * pour into a Teku glass from a 12 oz bottle *   * Drank on : 05/18/20 *   look a brown - amber and it be pretty clear when put up against the light , pretty predictable look for a barleywine style . have a brown colored half - finger thick head but have little to no retention to it , but consider the age and ABV , it be pretty understandable .   the aroma be very barrel forward , you can definitely get a big hit of bourbon , ethanol , and oaky note upfront . there be soft note of leather , dark fruit , burn caramel , vanilla , and toffee in the middle and back - end , but the beer be so barrel forward that these aroma be a bit subdued . maybe some age will mellow out the bourbon and alcohol aroma and let the other note shine .   in term of the flavor profile , I feel like the taste follow the nose for the most part . Delicious and complex , I also find that this beer strike a nice balance between the sweet / caramel note of the malt and the boozy / earthiness of the bourbon oak barrel . you get the bourbon and the oakiness upfront , which eventually just dissipate to a bourbon flavor and dark cherry in the middle . towards the end , I get a bit of the burn caramel , toffee , and vanilla character which leave a combination of a sweet and bitter aftertaste , though the bitterness be n't strong at all .   this beer be medium to full bodied with light carbonation . again , this have a sweet and bitter aftertaste which linger for a while , but the flavor be n't super bold or strong .   I feel like this be a very sell representation of a barrel - age English Barleywine style . big malty character of caramel and toffee , but the flavor be balance with the booziness and earthiness of the bourbon and oak . very solid , and will review again after a year !

today be a wondrous day for I personally ! I crawl into the depth of my cellar and pull this five - year - old beer out . I remove the black plastic off the cap . Mouthfeel be just okay after what look like a pretty slick pour . it be a touch messy and could be reign in a bit . for a beer rank this high , I do n't think those be unfair criticism . be it still a good beer ? yes . it be rich , complex , and super bourbon forward ( if you like that ) . but I have a feeling that previous iteration be maybe a bit more solid .   recommendation : maybe well a couple year ago ? but this be still a world - class beer any BA - lover should try .

2020 release , 13.7 % . thank , Brian !   Jet black with no head , this look decent . the nose be decadent . ton of vanilla and coconut be layer on top of rich , bitter dark chocolate . Boozy , a little hot on the finish . fully in body and softly carbonate , flavor of vanilla , bourbon , coconut and chocolate ling in the finish . unabashedly hedonistic , this be n't particularly deep or complex but be really well do . I do wish this have more of a rich , dark chocolate , though .

375ml bottle , 2018 release , pour into a Hill Farmstead oversize wine glass . enjoy on 06.09.18 , review from Tasting Journal .   the beer pour a jet black color , thick and oily , very viscous with a thin tan head that have no retention nor any lacing . the aroma be pleasant , lot of rich maple , sweet and sappy , ton of fudge brownie , light stone fruit , oak , bourbon , toffee , dark grain with a linger marshmallow vanilla fragrance . the flavor be very good , intense fudge brownie , lot of rich dark chocolate with some underlie sweet maple , oaky bourbon with a nice vanilla sweetness , char and roast with brown sugar that play well with the maple and finish warmly with a light fruity acidity . the mouthfeel be great , coat medium / full body , not quite chewy but very smooth and gentle , velvety with an effortlessly easy finish that have nice leg and a warming sensation .   Verdict : a very good barrel aged imperial stout from Hill Farmstead . rich flavor , balance well that be very easy go . the maple add a nice amount of sweetness to the beer but it bring with it some nice depth and complexity .

share with a friend while in Europe , bottle date 2017 , which I purchase in January 2018 .   pour an inky , thick opaque back , with coffee - and - cream head that dissipate relatively quickly . some faint , light lacing on glass .   Aroma be earthy malt and dark bread , hint of molasse . something very vaguely like tequila , which be probably woody character from the barrel aging , but a little spicy than most bourbon barrel stout I 've sample .   Flavour be complex , incredibly smooth and balanced -- hit of dark malty goodness up front , slightly bitter , but immediately follow by a sweet undercurrent of maple and spice , which finish with a hint of licorice . a big difference with this versus other big barrel - age beer I 've enjoy be that even the barrel character seem balanced -- this be a pretty solidly craft brew . no element be over the top .   I be honestly pretty amazed that there be still a slight residual maple flavour here , often the taste of the syrup be lose when the yeast ferment it away .   no indication of its strength on the label , but go on taste alone I 'd say it be well north of 8 - 9 % . my guess be 10 % ABV . the price of the bottle be a bit steep for 375 ml , but this stout be year in the making and I be glad to have share it with a friend .

500mL June 2017 bottle pour into a Hill Farmstead balloon glass . thank Ryan for share this with I .   pour a deep brown body , once it ’ in the glass it ’s opaque and black , thick . small brown head reduce fairly quickly .   Aromas be sweet and fudgy , cocoa and dark fruit , biscotti , vanilla , and subtle maple . on the tongue it ’ quite sweet but not cloy or " pastry”-like , more malty that sugary with rich chocolate fudge , vanilla - maple liquor , bourbon , dark fruit , molasse and roasty coffee on the follow through . maple show up as it warm up . the finish be roasty as well , bittersweet chocolate / char malt stick on the tongue for a bit . Mouthfeel be rich and thick with low carbonation . definitely a sipper .   a fantastically craft beer . more complex than similar stout . the barrel work wonder here .

delicious barrel aged offering here ; the cinnamon be n't overpower or pastry - like , the licorice meld well with the roasty and boozy note from the bourbon barrel character , and the oat lend a wonderfully velvety mouthfeel to the brew   91/100

2021 , 12.3 %   Cinnamon and licorice be two beer ingredient that do n't entice I so I pass on this offering last year . since then I have try a few BA offering from Fremont and they have all be stellar . plus the cinnamon in the b - bomb be amazing , so I take the leap this year .   there be just so much here and no one element dominate . the licorice and cinnamon provide a nice counter punch to keep a sweet , chocolatey stout in check . the smoke and the bourbon barrel bring it all together perfectly . the bourbon note be so damn good , no harsh wood or sharp alcohol . the body be full and rich . just an amazing beer .   Fremont 's barrel program be among the good imo . everything I 've try so far have have such rich , decadent barrel note . they be clearly source freshly empty , top - notch barrel and put they to good use .

pour black and viscous , more like a syrup than a brew ! a thin brown head quickly dissipate into thin ring around the glass . on the nose , cinnamon , bourbon barrel , and dark roast malt . on the palate , lot of cinnamon on the front follow by anise , bourbon , and char . silky smooth mouthfeel enhance by lack of carbonation . overall , the fine example of an oatmeal stout I ’ve ever have .

this be the number 2 rank Oatmeal Stout on this site , behind one of my favorite beer of all time , founder Breakfast Stout , and that ranking be more than well deserve .   what work the most for I be age it on cinnamon . oatmeal stout should n’t have spice or heat , I think , until I have this beer . the cinnamon be premonitory on the scent in a strong way , as it be the strong characteristic on the nose . and then I taste it and I ’d swear it ’s a cinnamon beer . that ’s not a bad thing , because wow ! I do n’t think I ’ve ever have a beer that be this spice forward without overpower everything else . plenty of roasty malt and a strong bourbon presence , but that spiciness make this a unique experience .   medium to big bodied feel , which be surprising , cause I expect this to be a big ass beer . it ’s not , nor be it thick or sticky or oily . it ’ a kind of " medium in all way " type of feel , if that make sense , except it as boozy as hell , which be another turn on for it .   honestly , this may be one of the good beer I ’ve have in a while , and I wish I could order more from Tavour . when you encounter a just about perfect beer , you know it . I ’m not one of those guy who do n’t give perfect score , and maybe this be n’t perfect . maybe if I examine it more , I ’d low it . but with the impression I ’ve get over the last two hour let it develop , I ’m go with 5 ’s across the board right now . I ’m glad I get into Tavour just because of Fremont access .
the combo of brewer 's licorice and the cinnamon be new to my taste bud ( both flavor be noticeable in this beer ) and they go very well with the stout and bourbon . well do !

I do n't have to search for anything . the only knock be the smoke of the molasse carry a bit of acrid taste with it .   the scent and taste hand around at the same level for so long . that be a straight - up accomplishment for any consumable . alcohol be present , but it play pretty nicely with the other thing . it be get a very nice heavy weight without come across as syrupy , but I also have a really heavy flavorful meal , so maybe it be about the competition . ( the gout begin in 3 ... 2 ... ) very fine carbonation be incredibly well integrate , and it take a vigorous swish to get it out , yet there be plenty .   this brew be just amazing . I be wonder if my second ( yet to be acquire ) bottle could possibly be as good . I mean , I really want to find out .

pour close to jet black with a 0.5 " frothy tan have that recede to a thick ring throughout the drink . nose be heavy with dark , chocolatey malt , tannic dark chocolate , black licorice , and cinnamon ; maybe touch of maple sweetness as well . pour a pitch - black coloration with a small , fluffy , dark - brown head . smell of slightly roasted , caramel malt and a huge cinnamon aroma that drown out almost everything else except for a distinct bourbon note , as well as hint of chocolate , vanilla and licorice manage to poke through . taste be a decent balance of slightly smoke and roasted , quite caramelly malt and a huge , sweet cinnamon presence , although the flavor manage just a bit more depth than the nose , with more distinct chocolate , licorice , molasse and dark fruit note of raisin and fig come through here , with a good , not too boozy , bourbon character and hint of vanilla , tobacco and charred oak . finish rather sweet , with a very light bitterness and some cinnamon , licorice and Bourbon linger in the aftertaste . full mouthfeel with a rich body and light / medium carbonation .   after BA Dark Star this be another big disappointment from Fremont for I , which I have also be save for a special occasion , just like the former . similar to BA Abraxas , which I also consider highly overrate , this be a total cinnamon bomb that be way too sweet for my personal taste and just lack overall balance , while the mouthfeel , while very nice , be hardly outstanding either in my personal opinion . although it do make for a very rich brew with a good bourbon presence that never turn quite as boozy as BA Dark Star , the sweetness from the cinnamon , licorice and molasse be just too much and while there be a decent complexity to this , most of it gets drown out by the overly dominant cinnamon character that the lightly smoke / roasted malt and mild bitterness be really struggle against , while the dark fruit and vanilla only add to that overdone sweetness here . I be not say it be a bad brew , be quite rich and with a good complexity , mouthfeel and bourbon presence , just not that well balanced for my personal taste , be way too sweet and dominate by the cinnamon , while I would have wish for the smoke / roasted malt and bitterness to shine through more distinctly here .

pour pitch black with minimal head . Caramel , cinnamon vanilla and barrel on the nose . taste cover all of the aroma with some licorice come through . great mouthfeel and just the right amount of carb for the brew . overall great one from Fremont .

a : the beer be jet black in color . it pour with a quarter finger high dark tan head that leave a narrow collar of tan bubble around the edge of the glass . s : moderate aroma of dark chocolate be present in the nose with note of bourbon and hint of cinnamon . t : the taste follow the smell , except that the bourbon and cinnamon flavor be strong than those of the chocolate and there be some hint of licorice in the finish . m : it feel a bit more than medium - bodied and silky smooth on the palate with a moderate amount of carbonation . o : I find this beer to be incredibly drinkable as any trace of alcohol be well hide from the taste and it do n't really have much in the way of licorice flavor .   serve type : can

a : Pitch black pour with a nearly black head . very fuzzy and loud . head dissipate fairly quickly and with no lacing , likely from the barrel aging .   s : Killer bourbon aroma . ton of burn sugar , caramel and vanilla . notable cinnamon in there too , meld well with the sting alcohol .   t : Goddamn ! stellar bourbon smack you in the face immediately . brown sugar , caramel , oaky vanilla and a touch of toffee . strong and sharp cinnamon flavor along with booziness cut the sweetness nicely . licorice flavor show up in the finish , not quite a star anise taste but similar . really help temper the sweetness , especially with the linger bourbon flavor in the aftertaste . 4 week old can pour into a Teku .   Peach juice color ( beautiful darkwe orange - gold ) , fully opaque but not turbid , with an amazing soapy head of eggshell bubble . nice head retention and fantastic lacing . wonderful creaminess to the liquid .   fairly mild nose , but what be there be lovely . lot of ripe fruit , especially orange , grapefruit , blueberry , pineapple , passionfruit , peach , grape , lemon / lime , and perhaps a little mango . nice dankness , quite grassy , with a lovely floral quality . a little honeysuckle and bubble gum with a slight mineral note . ripe orange come on strong late . attractive and clean .   taste be similarly mild , though here the Juicy Fruit gum note make its appearance . More orange , grass , and bubblegum than anything else , but there be a nice medley of fruit in the background , with berry and grapefruit popping through the most distinctively . mildly sweet but with a strong grapefruit pith to balance it out . quite delicate and clean , but I appreciate it more and more ( and pick up additional nuance ) the long I sip on it . hard to compare to the hop bomb that have take over the hazie world since Tree House first start make beer like this . this one do n’t jump out at you but be excellent for what it be . wonderful , last ruby red grapefruit — pithy and sweet — linger forever .   as it warm , the stone fruit become much more prominent on the nose and tongue . and interestingly it develop a bit of a sharp alcohol bite . pretty surprising for a sub-7 % beer .   feel be soft and silky but a touch thin than the creamy look would suggest . still , incredibly smooth and drinkable .   really fantastic , and clearly incredibly well - craft , but I ’m not sure it ’s world class . so tough for beer like this to live up to expectation , but I would happily drink this anytime I have access to it .

look like orange juice in my glass with a dense pearl - white head that be Saran Wrap go down the glass . bite citrus aroma on the nose , with grapefruit , ripe orange , passion fruit , and that dank note Mosaic and Amarillo hop both purvey .   the taste be an exotic citrus / tropical fruit flavor parade , with the dank grapefruit and orange flavor my favorite . wow , what a flavor ride this be .   if you like hazy , this beer have to be on your " get ta have " list . world class , IMHO .

canned 8/20/20 . taste 9/17/20 . surprising that it be take I this long to procure an Alter Ego . this be a really yummy beer , but it be not as rich or flavorful as many other Tree House offering . some folk really love the smell of Alter Ego , but I find this to be the weak spot in this beer . it be a little murky and sour for my nose . but the taste be delicious , with a nice balance of dank bitterness and sweet / citrus fruit flavor . the feel , while a touch on the light side , be very smooth . the look be a slightly hazy orange - hazy than Bright , but less hazy than most other TH IPAs .

aside from Force of Will , the fine beer in the Tree House lineup , to my taste .   it have the bitterness on the back end that match the roundness on the front end . a tiny bit thin , but nothing to complain about -- it make it easy to reach for another .   a simply delicious beer that make your mouth water for another . rank up there with Focal Banger , Pliny , and Intergalactic Warrior .

review # 8000 , 2015 vintage . this will be a very emotional review . normally for big milestone like this , rudzud would have some crazy beer to share , but that ca n't happen now . instead this be one from our share box that we get from Hoarders , save for a special day . he might not be here physically to share it with I , but he be here in spirit .   pour basically with no head , whisp of fizzy bubble disappear almost instantly , dark murky molasse brown color with no real light come through , and leg for day   Nose bring lot of barrel and bourbon , lot of vanilla oak , a bit buttery oak , fresh bourbon barrel juice , a bit like my nose in a Glencairn glass with some decent bourbon , lot of dark malt under that , some roast and coffee , no char , load of cocoa , dark chocolate , a little nougat candy bar , fudge , a bit of a chocolate syrup as well , a little alcohol   Taste super rich heavy malt and barrel , dark chocolate , raw cocoa , chocolate syrupy again , a bit of a candy bar with light nougat and caramel note , some roast and coffee as well , more like a coffee syrup , barrel bring lot of vanilla again and fresh bourbon barrel juice , a little generic whiskey character but some raw sweet bourbon as well , get fudgey in the middle , some toasted oak character and layer of vanilla , a touch of baking spice , me light bitterness mostly from the roasted malt , some hot alcohol not quite fusel but almost there , finish sticky and coat the mouth , never really go away , linger cocoa , fudge , vanilla and generic whiskey   Mouth be full bod , rich syrupy and really coat the mouth , some hot tingly alcohol , med - light foamy carb   overall quite nice , there have be well bruery beer , but for a Black Tuesday variant add the extra bourbon and barrel be nice , although I think it have drop a bit from what it probably be fresh , but alcohol do n't destroy either as the age probably help there .   I swear I hear a pop sound from my glass while it be rest and I be type . Matt must have take his sip , and I hope he enjoy it . Miss the great bottle share and fun time . this be just one more milestone in my review . I know rudzud always joke about how he would never catch I in review , and I guess he be right . I 'll keep drink beer , but I 'll always have that hole that will never be fill . Cheers Matt !

very good head production , consider the sky high ABV and double barrel aging . quickly fade , as expect , leave behind only a thin ring of foam around the edge . body be surprisingly clear and cola - color . this be for 2018 and review for the way the current stout game be . the old school back Tuesday be a legendary beer that be a game changer for high abv stout . unfortunately compare to stuff now it be extremely thin and way too boozy to be enjoyable . there be some good characteristic of bourbon , sweetness , and fudge . when there be n’t as many option I can see why this beer be great . I do n’t know if my pallet have change or the beer landscape have change , maybe a little bit of both . there be a wide variety of well ba stout in small format that be more enjoyable in all aspect right now to have this again unless it be a really well aged bottle .

got this one from claaark13 a while back . cheer !   from a 750 into a snifter 2015 Edition Imperial stout age in bourbon barrel   appearance : pour out a clear brown and yield a small , loose , bubbly light beige head that quickly vanish to a bubbly ring . Bistre brown body with no carbonation evident . Ring disappears rather quickly leave this one look flat and lifeless until the end .   smell : big bourbon and oak nose on this one . Boozy for sure , with lot of candy - like quality as well . Vanilla , coconut , milk chocolate and molasse come through , with toffee and butterscotch note . a slight hint of roasted malt and pure chocolate behind the onslaught of bourbon and oak all over the place .   taste : Piles of bourbon here . lot of bourbon and oak flavor . really strong and boozy . some vanilla , coconut and milk chocolate up front as well , move into a boozy finish . bold aftertaste of bourbon , vanilla , coconut , lot of wood and spirit , some pure chocolate bitterness and a touch of roasted malt linger on the palate . lot of booze .   palate : medium body and medium carbonation . silky on the palate , go down with a good scratch and burn at the swallow and finish quite sticky on the palate . harsh and lot of heat linger . this feel more like whisky than beer , though it be surprisingly silky and smooth , especially as it settle .   overall : this be close to straight spirit than any other incarnation of this beer . either that or I ’ve become a huge sissy since I last have one of these a couple year back . probably a combination of the two . it seem like the extra barrel aging , which be totally unnecessary in the first place , have make this one even hot and boozier than the base . amazing , but yes , it ’s boozier than the base . I ’m never sure what to think about this bruiser . I admit I find it rather delicious and actually crave it from time to time , but it ’s questionable at well as an imperial stout , and as a bourbon barrel age imperial stout , I often wonder where the stout go . from my note and memory the 2009 original bottling be one of the good thing to ever grace my belly , and unfortunately the successor have n’t quite live up to that heavenly experience . all that say , this be probably the beer I most look forward to imbibe in again . weird . enjoyable for sure , but be ready with an army of the willing at your back , or a solid wine stopper so you can plug it up and enjoy it for a couple week . thank again , claaark ! always a pleasure .

2018 release .   a : pour a very dark , chestnut brown with a half finger of sand - color , foamy head . decent retention , recede quickly to a long - stand ring . no lacing .   s : dark chocolate , vanilla bean , oak , with light roast and cola .   t : prominent okay presence from start to finish , provide some structure and cut directly through the sweetness endemic to regular BT . also , dark chocolate , roast , vanilla , cola , and plum . a long oaky , slightly tannic / roasty finish . More roast than I remember in regular BT .   m : moderate and assertive alcohol heat without the burn . full body with medium - light carbonation .   o : an oaky version of BT . certainly an interesting take . the low sweetness be an improvement , but the oakiness be a toe over the line .

from 750 ml bottle to snifter   a : jet - black and viscous as hell . pour like crude oil - no chance of a head under this kind of weight .   s : all the note of a good barrel - age stout , just ramp - up ... a lot . waft of alcohol volatile push the boozy aromas right to the center of olfactory organ , allow one to parse every scent . Charred oak , vanilla , cocoa , ripe cherry . note of coffee and anise in bitter aspect of the bouquet , caramel and freshly mill whole grain in the sweet . obviously plenty of booze , smell like a liqueur .   m : if this be any more viscous there 'd have to be a molecular phase - change to a solid . bring a knife and fork just in case .   t : the first thing notice at the front of the sip , besides the booze , be that it be not that boozy . not 21%-boozy . I would have peg this 14 - 16 % , and the restrained alcohol render the brew a lot more drinkable than it could have be . also , the high gravity do n't overtake that buttery , bourbon - y , caramel - y aspect that make barrel - age stout so delicious . a perfect balance of sweet and booze throughout the sip , close with a long finish . really long .     just a phenomenal beer . one of the good brew I 've have . I be skeptical when I read this be their big Hoarder 's special last year ; what be disclose about the process lead to a risky end - product - a lot of way this could 've go off the rail . but this be easily the good beer the Bruery have brew ( edit : compare to bottle available to Society member - I be not able to frequent the tasting room that often , so there may have be a one - off gem I miss ) . just wow .

pour a rich bluish , purple with healthy blueberry yogurt head . bottom of cork and nose smell like spontaneous funk with minimal barnyard mustiness but with healthy blueberry aroma . taste be young lambic citric acidic sourness with big tannic presence , a bit of lacto , and slight but real blueberry undertone . bottle . I believe it to be 2015 . pour a ruddy , muddy purple . almost wine like . a purple / pink frothiness that sit atop the beer . beer # 4000 deserve something special . huge thank to docj007 yet again for the crazy beer he share with we all . 375ml bottle from 2012 .   pour deep reddish purple with a one and a half finger tall white head , slowly dissipate down to a light film , leave small webs of lace on the side of the glass .   smell of sweet / tart fresh pick blueberry , the ever present Cantillon musty brewery funk , some mild lactic sourness , yogurt and finally some grain . taste follow the same path with plenty of tart blueberry and lactic sourness up front follow closely by the must and finally the lightly chewy grain . feel be slightly grainy quickly be envelop by plenty of musty sourness and slight sweetness from the berry .   overall an excellent fruit lambic . this be a killer beer , quite deserving of its highly regard status , and a pretty righteous use of maple syrup , but I think I just like their sunday brunch well . appearance : pour a thick , pulpy , pollen yellow . offer up a docile , white foam that exhibit persistent , web lace .   Bouquet : a mid - summer ’s breeze of juicy peach slice , ripe pineapple , and a big , bold burst of citrusy , white grape   feel : a medium body that ’s soft and cushy as a goose feather pillow . silky carbonation .   taste : what ’s this ? a double IPA that ’s floral and fruity and sweet ? that do n’t sear the hair from your nostril and singe the edge of your tongue with a brutal , hallucination - induce , 9 million IBU ? and it ’s brew with something besides just HOPS ?   instead of an eye - watering , oral enema of barbaric hop , cut Tiles present a deeply delicate palate of candied peach , tender nectarine , and a dry , strawberry liquor finish . all wrap up in a woolly blanket of raw , wildflower honey . a meteoric wad of hop , with a scream comet ’s tail of booze heat , crash land with an earth - shake BOOM at the very end ; but the lead up to this crescendo be so sensual and sweet that the normally abrasive blast of hop come across as palate - arouse piquancy .

absolutely phenomenal beer , and my favorite Trillium IPA ( or APA , or IIPA ) to date .   have on tap with lunch at the beautiful new ( ish ) Fort Point location . beautiful , hazy , golden - orange body of pure juice , soft soft , off - white lacing ( almost no head with a to - the - brim pour ) .   Aromas and flavor be absolutely stunning with massive citrus , mango , pineapple , and white grape . fairly grassy but massively juicy with absolutely no astringency or hop burn . the honey send it over the top for I , as I like a little extra sweetness in my big ipa . but there be some honest , resiny , pithy bitterness in the background that keep thing semi - grounded and linger quite nicely along with the fruit juice sweetness . so many bold note at play here , and they come together amazingly . dangerously poundable for an 8.5 % beer .   feel be actually a touch thin for a iipa of this size , but still very smooth and silky .   Absolute winner .

750ml bottle , age in oak barrel , undated , pour into a stemless wine glass .   the beer pour a bright peach color , orange and gold hue , cloudy with a finger of fizzy white head that dissipate quickly leave no lacing . the aroma be wonderful , lot of fresh peach , bright and lightly tart with a nice floral quality , underlie fruitiness , lightly bacterial with a nice funk , soft oak and earthiness . the flavor be great , ton of peach , juicy , fresh , bright and tart with a nice oak barrel , sweet and chewy with a nice mustiness and funkiness while a soft floral bouquet open up as it warm . the mouthfeel be good , coat with a delicate and lively medium body that have a nice tartness and finish with a lightly dry bite .   verdict : a nice wild ale from de Garde . lot of peach , bright , fresh , just a touch sweet that really demonstrate the great quality of the peach .

one of the beer I have be after for a long time have finally become a reality , definitely one I have be keen on , so cool to have beery friend out there ! this be unique in that its not just a peach wild ale , but one age in cognac barrel , really complex and good . its get a high shine and a pale color , bright but less than fully clear through most of the bottle , some little bubble come up , but somewhat unremarkable visually . it smell a bit more sour than a lot of the de garde beer have be in my experience so far , really piquant , slight vinegar character , white wine acidity , clean though , less funky , and I get the cognac immediately , some sweetness and some alcohol warmth to it , with the very natural peach its almost a baked dessert complexion , light vanilla and graham and even tobacco to it , nice complexity but very sour it seem . the peach be crazy juicy and real and ripe , very authentic here , and I know it would be base on the other fruit beer I ve have in the past from these guy , man I wish I have a reliable supply of their stuff ! the flavor here be excellent , again more sour than expect , but its a clean and lightly citrusy sourness , it seem build to balance the sweetness of the peach and even highlight its essence , the peach be bold from beginning to end here . the wood be strong , but the beer itself be quite light , minimal on the grain side , the peach really lead the way . the cognac though be an amazing tough , and I m not sure this would be anywhere near as exciting without it , despite the obvious quality . its nutty and deep than the oak alone , a golden raisin hint maybe , a sweet alcoholic layer , even cigar or something in the mix , just crazy , its amazing with the peach . I get a little less of the de garde funk that I like so much , more generic acidity , so I would enjoy more funkiness , but I ca nt complain . this be awesome overall , different awesome than expect , but great and really distinct with this combination of fruit and barrel . I hate to admit I have a little sinus thing go on and may have not experience this in its full glory as a result , ca nt control those thing and certainly be nt go to pass on it , so I will look forward to hopefully have this again . I love this brewery , its always a joy to drink their beer . this appear worthy of its hype !

semi - clear filling to hazy dark orange with a khaki blanket that fizzle out quickly to nothing .   it be pretty wild how drastically de Garde beer vary from one to the next , even within the same the series .   this one 's ultra funky and oaky up front , then finish quite sour . the funk be woody and a little cheesy , like blue with walnut and cashew , as the bright peach accent bring in some pear and overripe sweaty ass fruit under a hot sun . the prickly medium - light body swallow sharply sour and oaky , finish dry .

review 1656 Double Shot Tree House Brewing Date : 18 June 2021 this be the last Tree House beer ; I have in my Fridge . every beer I have consume thus far have be blow my expectation away . my first stout from Tree House ; when I open the can , a heavy coffee aroma emit . I pour the beer into my fancy imperial stout glass . the pour create a creamy and foamy dark brown two - finger head with excellent retention . the color chart around SRM 26 , dark brown like use motor oil without the highlight .   Coffee be strong and present with the initial nosing . dark roasted malt , toffee , molasse , a hint of smoke , a touch of char , and tobacco . the smell be dominate by the fragrant coffee aroma .   one of the strong coffee - flavor beer next to Oliphant Brewing Coffee Ale . the molasse , caramel , and toffee temper out the bitterness . this create velvety coffee flavor . the dark roasted malt give some char , bready , and earthiness to the beer . I detect   the mouthfeel be creamy , chewy , and bold .   the body be heavy , have low carbonation , and have a robust finish .   the coffee flavor in the beer be rich and flavorful . one of the good coffee beer I have consume in a long time . a must - try for any coffee stout lover .

huge thank to Alan for this one , and plenty of other long time want . this be one of those beer you just have to try at least once , so here I go !   Pint can - date 01/14/20 - pour into a tumbler at 50 ° F .   pour a gleam jet black - no head , until a two finger coffee bean - colour head race up , before race right back down to a still top , look like tar in the glass . like nothing I 've ever see . I 'll give a 5 to that .   Nose : black coffee . some roasty nuance , such as a hint of caramel , brown sugar , vanilla , and even a hint of dark fruit and red wine , but this be essentially sweet coffee .   palate : much like the nose , this be an absolute coffee bomb . it open up quite sweet , with lot of cocoa from the roast , which lend its own coffee character as well . moderate roast , accentuate by the coffee , but the hearty sweetness win over . secondary note of vanilla , caramel , brown sugar , molasse , and unfortunately , lactose . I know there be something unpleasant about this - there be clearly lactose in it . the lactose lend this quick spike of this almost aspartame / artificial sweetener flavour just before the finish , where it also extinguish any sort of roast that may have be . luckily , there be enough coffee for the more roasty note of the bean to come through in the finish , which help to dry it out .   Mouthfeel / body : the beer be full - bodied , and have a slick , oily feel to it . in addition to the naturally full body , the lactose definitely add , some viscosity here , as do the sheer level of sweetness . major stickiness be leave cling to the lip with this one . effervescence be actually quite adequate - low , but very fine and fizzy .   overall : all the component of a great coffee stout be here . the bean themself be clearly primo quality , with zero green pepper or stale note , the base stout be well - craft , but - it be too sweet , and there be just too much lactose . in fact , if there be n't any lactose , I think it could pull off the sweetness just fine , but with both element in place , it do become a bit cloying . I do not think the lactose benefit this beer in any way whatsoever . you can easily get that chewy feel without milk sugar , and it end up taste more natural . it be still good , it be still drinkable , but I 'd either like to see this tame by a bourbon barrel , or just lose the lactose all together .

Drank from a 500 ml ( 1 pt .9 fl . oz ) bottle purchase at Tree House Brewing Company , Charlton , MA serve in a snifter   outstanding appearance . an inch - tall , super tight and creamy , mocha color crown top the oily , pitch black body . the head slowly drop to a clingy collar . large swath of lacing coat the glass and stick around until the drink ’s end .   the aroma be coffee forward but not to the extent I be anticipate . dark roast coffee perhaps . big dark malt note too . moderately roasty . there be an interesting savory quality as well . baker chocolate also come to mind .   the flavor profile be be a total mocha bomb . huge coffee presence . medium roast , cream and sugar coffee specifically . perhaps some coffee ice cream too . hint of vanilla . dark chocolate be also apparent . brown sugar note come through as well . sweet but not excessively so . there be a subtle booziness on the finish .   outstanding soft , creamy , fluffy mouthfeel . medium - full bodied for the style . the liquid contain a fine , fairly zippy , tongue blanketing effervescence .   while many of the Double Shot variant be more impressive than this beer , the original be still so good . perhaps the good way to appreciate the wide range of offering in this series be to occasionally revisit the beer where it begin .

trade for this and a few other bottle from Tree House this week , as I never have anything dark and heavy from they before . although the Vanilla Bean take on this be well , this be a solid beer that feel like sensual coffee in a bottle . if you like your beer to be roasted , slick , and complement by appropriate flavor , then you 've find your match right here !   of course , this pour quite dark like coffee with plenty of bubbly , tan head to top it off . that take a while to settle as there be plenty of clingy , sudsy lacing leave behind from the moment I take the first sip of this . fresh - roasted coffee , vanilla bean and extract , rich chocolate , and tangy blood orange fill the subtle nose as white chocolate sweetness , espresso bean , and soft cream come in to take this beer to the next level . like it be other iteration , this come across as an " Imperial Breakfast Stout " , if one be to actually exist . Roasted Malt somehow emerge through all of these flavor and enhance this beer , as it give it depth without make it feel dry or typecast in the process ...   amazingly , the booze in this be present enough to be feel but understate enough to let the other flavor take hold , from the get - go on out . a tiny presence of plum and dark fruit take hold before I finish this off as the acidity from that and the blood orange presence be enough to elevate this from the chocolate - coffee - vanilla threshold that hold so many beer of this type back . like their more famous IPA 's , this be a beer from Tree House that be worth seek out or trade for - ca n't recommend anything in this series highly enough !

black in color with no penetration to light . there ’s a fingernail of brown around the rim and and cover a third of the top . the aroma be of chilie , rum , and coffee . I ’m taste chilie , vanilla , cacao , and rum . the mouth be warm from the chilie and otherwise chewy .

12 oz . bottle , mark 07/27/19 , sample 05/09/21 . a little long to wait , buy it off the shelf 3 week ago , so the brewer take any hit on aging , they leave it there for purchase .   appearance : black glass , thin halo of tan bubble , no lacing .   aroma : heavy vegetative chili note , burn barrel , some underlie malt sweetness .   taste : medicinal alcohol , green pepper , some sweetness come in deep into the taste , a little coffee in the finish . hard to get many " beer " flavor out of this , even imperial stout flavor . some pepper burn long after the swallow that build a bit . on tap at Cardinal Pub & Bar , Stavanger . pitch black colour , low tan head . aroma first of fusel alcohol , then molasse , rum oak cask , vanilla , coconut , chocolate and roast malt . rich and warming mouthfeel . outstanding flavour , medium sweet and roasty , no sign of fusel , otherwise all the delicious note from the aroma be repeat and strengthen here . nice chili heat in the finish . perfect !

pour black . brown head . Aroma be a combination of vanilla bean and Chile pepper coffee . taste be the same . silky smooth . Rum barrel round everything out . overall delicious with that spicy punch .

on tap - this be the July 2019 batch , so 15 month old .   pour jet black with a super thin tan head around the circumference of the glass . no lacing .   Smell be rum and chocolate upfront , with coffee kicking in just a little bit after . the booze be strong on the nose , but a bit of vanilla be there to balance it .   taste follow the nose . the booze sting be minimal consider the ABV . good balance between the sweet vanilla , chocolate , and coffee . the spice and coffee combine for an earthy finish that do n’t last long than it should .   feel be full bodied with low to medium carbonation . it do n’t stick much or leave a thick residue on the tongue , which for I set it apart a bit from other Prairie stout .   overall , quite good . I have a tough time assign number to this one , so I look back through my previous rating on various stout , and eventually decide that I have to give this one 4.25 straight through . it ’s not the good , but far from the bad , and very consistent across the board .

bottled 2018 ( could n't find date ) pour from 12 oz bottle to modify tulip 7/28/20    excellently do , I 'd previously enjoy a 14 % version ( 2019 if I be not mistaken ) of this brew on tap , and have find it enjoyable . pour as black as ink with a 2 finger thick foamy brown colored head that make crackling sound as it dissipate in average time , leave minimal spotty lacing . the smell be really complex and rich with woody note , dark rum , coconut , chocolate syrup , vanilla , cocoa powder , dark chocolate , burn coffee grind , piney accent , molasse , chili pepper and more sweet chocolate aroma . wonderfully put together , the rum and extra vanilla note kick it up a notch and make it a well version of the original Bomb ! .   the taste be where this one really excel . if you enjoy the original Bomb ! and appreciate rum , then like I this brew be for you . the extra vanilla , cocoa and coffee bring more flavor and deep component that let the sweet coconut and roasted malt tie it all together without actually be cloyingly sweet . this mask the ABV perfectly , but there be a little heat from the chilli . like the nose the combo be dynamic , with dark rum , coconut , dark chocolate , woody note , chocolate syrup , vanilla , cocoa powder , dark chocolate , burn coffee grind , piney accent , molasse , toffee , espresso , chili pepper and some minor metallic aspect . a world class stout .

12 oz . bottle date 7/7/19   pour into Aslin anniversary glass and allow to warm .   l : pour black , barely any light brown head , which do n't last very long . no lacing or cap and ring .   s : fair amount of rum and rum cask up front , along with coffee and vanilla . a peppery hint as well .   t : More rum and cask than I expect , but vanilla and coffee take over and then cocoa work its way through and last with the dab of chili heat through the finish .   f : full - bodied , not much carbonation . lot go on in this beer and it be all meld very well and balanced nicely , as neither the ABV nor the heat get out of hand on the finish and the progression of flavor be very nice .   o : they be all great , but the complexity and competence may make this the good of the bomb!s

a : pour into a snifter to a black beer top by a small tan head which fade quickly to a collar around the edge of the glass with no lacing . base on the pour this one seem pretty low in carbonation , s : smell of a lot of coffee and chocolate with some vanilla and a hint of rum . touch of peppery heat on the nose too , t : taste be coffee , dark chocolate , roasted malt , vanilla , peppery heat , some oak and rum barrel . on the swallow there be more rum barrel , chocolate , coffee , vanilla and some linger heat . m : this beer be pretty full in body with a slightly silky feel on the palate . carbonation be on the low end but still adequate while the beer have a slightly dry finish due to the ABV . o : this beer be delicious . great adjunct flavor with some nice influence from the base beer . very well balanced and really nice barrel influence without overpower the rest of what be go on either . this be definitely one to try if you can get your hand on it .

pour pitch black , quite viscous and thick . great chocolate aroma accent by some coffee and coconut . taste great . for 15 % , it be n’t as sweet as I think it would be . load of chocolate , sweet vanilla , light coffee , heat be light in the background , rum barrel age work some coconut into the finish . full bodied and delicious , a little pricy but worth try once ...   10/12/19 12 oz bottle split with Dave at Butchers Block 4.5 rating

Bottled 7/22/19 . pour at 55 degree . dark brown rocky foam briefly sit atop black liquid ; no cap retention ; barely a thin ring ; no lace ; medium leg on swirl . strong spicy green chilli , rum and chocolate ; hot boozy exhale . taste follow nose and add vanilla , oak and mild roast coffee in the middle ; rum soak chocolate mexican cake finish . silky feel , medium body , moderate minus carbonation ; warm from 15 % ABV . overall super well balanced , lot of heat from the pepper and alcohol with plenty of chocolate and vanilla to round out the whole ; and the nose / flavor stay strong from first sip to last . worthy of the premium price pay .

two of my friend recently put together a share to help I out after my bottle be steal at Dark Lord Day . I tell they it really be n't necessary , but that seem to have even motivate they more ! so we end up drink several top 250 beer , which be always exciting for I - I be stunned that they manage to grab a Pirate Paradise though . I be a very big fan of Bourbon Paradise , and a huge lover of Prairie beer in general - this be certainly a wish list item !   so , it be a little odd to say that I be slightly let down by Pirate Paradise - particularly as difficult as I 'd think it be to find and procure . strangely , it seem that bourbon seem to complement the base beer much well - which be exactly what I would not have think . Rum and coconut beer be some of my favorite - so why do n't this one work quite as well for I ?   that be probably not exactly a good or accurate statement , honestly , because Pirate Paradise be a damn good beer - but where Bourbon Paradise be almost too thick and sweet , this beer fall just a little short in those category . Rum in the nose and the taste be pleasant , but it be definitely a bit thin in that . I be also not get the coconut and vanilla to nearly the same degree as in Bourbon Paradise . quite surprising , I know .   so while I like Pirate Paradise - I ca n't help but review it in the long shadow cast by Bourbon Paradise .
