12 oz bottle , serve in a stemmed glass . pour a thick , oily dark black body , one finger white head , short retention , not much in way of lacing . Smell be sweet rum , vanilla , sugarcane , milk chocolate , a bit of sweet coconut , cocoa . it be mildly boozy , but rum be more or less always that way . Flavour be chewy milk chocolate , cocoa , a bit of sweet and oily coconut , more milk chocolate , a smooth and extended run of rum throughout , with a smooth , mild vanilla sweetness linger on the backend . mainly it be vanilla and rum mingle together on the backend , which be round out by a slight cocoa - like bitterness . Mouthfeel be full bodied , substantial , low but still appropriate carbonation , mildly boozy rum on the finish . a very good barrel - aged adjunct stout that be n't quite pastry stout level but it be an excellent stout in its own right . probably one of the few rum barrel - aged stout that I have really enjoy . I do agree that this one be a step up above Bourbon Paradise as the rum seem to work well with the adjunct than the bourbon .

2018 release .   a : Viscous black with a thin ring of fine , dark brown head . decent retention and no lacing .   s : Toasted coconut , vanilla ice cream , with moderate spice rum , cinnamon , and a bit of dark chocolate and roast .   t : Spiced rum in the forefront with light toast coconut ( light than on the nose ) , vanilla bean , a bit of cola and roast , with moderate baker spice on the backend . medium sweetness pull thing together .   m : thick medium - full body , sticky , with medium cola - like carbonation .   o : Delicious ! the barrel be nicely integrate and the coconut and rum be both super tasty .

big shout out to my buddy Donnie for this gem and my 1500 check in   look : motor oil black , little head a very dark cola like color Smell : big rum nose with hint of fudge and vanilla , the coconut come through a lot as it warm up taste : big rum up front , with a perfectly balanced vanilla , fudge and coconut taste . feel : thick full mouth feel , very little carbonation .... like drink a coconut fudge cake .

a : beer pour a very black body . very little head or lacing , as common with Prairie stout . head color look almost like a Cherry Coke . very dark red color head . look be very typical for a Prairie stout .   s : large amount of rum at first pour . as the beer warm some of the rum aromas give way to some sweet smell . Vanilla , chocolate , and coconut become more noticeable as the beer get close to room temperature .   t : very nice balance of rum flavor mix with multiple layer of dessert like taste . similar to the nose , the beer be very heavy rum and molasse in the beginning before somewhat dissapeare to give way to sweet flavor . nice amount of vanilla and chocolate mix with some coconut as the beer get warm .   m : thick full mouthfeel . many sweet dessert like beer become too cloying here but Prairie do this one right with the addition of rum . very full flavored and warming . the ABV be obvious while drink and afterwards but somewhat subdue due to the coconut and vanilla .   o : remarkable beer . only negative be the lack of head or lacing . one of the good beer I have have regardless of style . so many beer in this style go overboard with sweetness but not here . nice balance of alcohol and sweetness .

thank @Roguer Hazy , for sure . nice fluffy head , great retention . the nose burst with guava , follow by orange z , melon , mango , pineapple and , well , green note . the flavor jump off with the citrus first . hazy , opaque , pulpy ; it be a classic Tree House IPA , along with excellent head production and lacing , and nice retention . body be right between lemon - yellow and orange .   would it surprise you to hear that this beer be , well , hoppy on the nose ? very bright and fresh : orange , tangerine , mango , and bright green herb . absolutely burst . remind I of classic tg hop bomb , but without any of the dirtiness .   a touch lighter on the palate than the hop on the nose imply . Pineapple , tangerine , lemon , grapefruit peel ( primarily on the finish ) , mango .   Smooth and creamy on the palate , although not quite as full bodied as some of their other ipa . consistent with their brand , there be plenty of bitterness alongside the burst juiciness , along with a bright and semi - dry finish , really ready you for the next sip . no hop burn or astringency .   Tree House be among the leader of the NE IPA sub - style for a reason . they hop these beer to high heaven in all phase , yet always avoid any burn . the hop be juicy and fruity , but they resist the urge to stick to late- and dry - hop , completely avoid the 0 - IBU race . the mouthfeel be always smooth and creamy , evoke the Vermont master who first stand out in that fashion . the result : incredible consistency ; juicy , drinkable beer that be still identifiable as ipa ( or as beer , period , in this modern landscape ) ; ipa that , no matter how many you 've have , never fail to impress and deliver .

Matt , you be a saint . thank you again for these one .   Pint can - date 08/05/20 - pour into a teku at 38 ° F .   pour an unbelievably turbid banana cream yellow - top woth two finger of creamy white head with fair retention , leave a sheet of lace as it recede .   Nose : identifiable Tree House profile , with soft , pale , oaty malt , that signature house yeast note , and all of Green 's Galaxy influence . peach ring candy , candy papaya , ripe apricot , white guava , papaya , a hint of honeydew , a touch of pineapple , which lend a fruity brightness , and just a whisper of that super late - hop peppery note in the background .   palate : the beer greet the palate with pale , oat - drive malt which lend just a moderate touch of sweetness . ton of Galaxy right off the bat , with more peach , nectarine and papaya , and what I be guess may be Amarillo , which provide bright tropical note of guava , pineapple , and a nice candy orange note . the pineapple aspect build and provide this nice juicy acidity to counteract the malt and dank Galaxy , and then that super leafy hop cone Galaxy note of Very Green come in , bring it back to pithy , resinous hop territory , with a lovely dry , dig , slightly bitter finish with fresh grass , leafy hop , resin , citrus pith , and a slightly herbal note .   Mouthfeel / body : like many of the upper echelon of Tree House ipa , this beer be straight up fluffy , soft , and velvety plush . what make this even well , be that the soft creamy feel do n't come at the expense of drinkability . it be soft , but it be n't thick or heavy . it be actually super crisp , and do n't fight back whatsoever . effervescence be a touch on the low side , but there be enough to give the lift it need . start soft , juicy in the middle , and finish dry and resinous . great progression .   overall : this be a proper home run from Tree House . fall somewhere between Green and very Green . it retain the signature Green genetic , with a lovely fruity spin , and add drinkability . in my honest opinion , this be a superior IPA to Green , fall just short of the magic of Very Green . an absolute must try .

this thing be a beast , even more packed with all of these awesome flavor than the maple bacon be , but without the unifying and mellow barrel element of the morning wood . big thank to my homie for bring this one over for maple beer night , I have not ever see it before , but have love its two sister beer ! its as thick and dense look as it seem like it should be , near black but a high luster and some nice thick foamy tan head . it smell more like coffee than anything else , seemingly high in the proportionality than in the maple bacon , a little less smoke and greasiness and all too , and still with a high maple sweetness element . there be a lot of nuance here too though like black pepper and fresh tobacco and molasse . its as complex in the flavor too , but we be all sort of stunned at how this be nt super insanely sweet . I do nt catch a bottle date , but the coffee taste pretty fresh in here to I , and its intensity cut some of the weight of the body and the sweetness , I like its contribution a lot . the bacon part of this be a little underwhelming , less obvious in the mix than in the base beer , light campfire smoke be all , this be nt meaty or anything to I . a really intense brew , but as good as any of the wildly flavor stout these guy do . Appearance – 3 . first pour – medium brown , clear . body – dark brown / black , opaque . when hold to direct light , a very deep red - amber , translucent . no leg . head – large ( maximum four cm , aggressive center pour ) , tannish with large bubble nosily pop , go within a minute after the pour be complete , leave thin partial ring of tiny bubble , feed by effervescence . while not fizzy , the head demonstrate no tendency to last . at 18.9 % ABV , this be not surprising . lacing – none , again 18.9 % ABV . Aroma – 4 - have an almost watery raisin aroma with some weak wood and possibly bourbon in the background . flavor – 4 – the flavor be somewhat elusive , start slightly sweet and a bit fruity , without bourbon , oak , or hazelnut . the nasal raisin seem to be dominant . no alcohol ( 18.9 % ABV as mark on label ) aroma or flavor , but massive numbing of the tongue and soft palate as it warm while be hold in the mouth . alcohol on the exhale . no diacetyl , no dimethylsulfide , no hop . palate – 4 – medium , just short of syrupy , lively carbonation . final impression and summation : 4 . the appearance in unremarkable , look like any headless imperial stout . the aroma be most like Flying Dog ’s Raison D’Etre , at least to my burn - out lab nose . in the flavor I find no hint of hazelnut , oak , or bourbon , just a generic sweetness with a hint of DARK FRUIT , something I do n’t taste ( other than raisin ) until I be type this summary . Palate feel good , but I ’ve cork the bottle after one glass , so I do n’t wake up with my head on the keyboard and beer leak onto the motherboard ( incidentally , Mrs. Lizard have miraculously appear and approve the corking of the bottle for later . maybe today I wo n’t sleep through Noir Alley ! ) overall , I ’ve probably rate this too high , but it ’s from the Bruery , so , by definition , it have to be a superior brew .

2017 Release . 20.0 % ABV .   the pour be a dark brown with a distinct crimson hue . hardly any head appear , but what do bubble up be a nice ivory color . thin and space out , quick to disappear .   as be expect , this thing be BOOZY , with lot of dark fruit right away on the nose . as it warm , bourbon and oak come forth with some urgency . the booze be still overwhelming , but the subtly complex aroma that come peek through that ethanol be pleasant , and chocolate in particular become gradually more prevalent .   in the flavor you get more of that powerful booziness , but it be not as overwhelming as the nose . an aroma of booze and hazelnut . a bit of heat in the taste but with this high ABV how could there not be ? I like the mild carbonation . this be creamy goodness . I even love the aroma they put in the wax !

Palate tun thing a bit down to earth . large aromatic flavor be take over a bit , mostly through a very port and wine like body and flavor , but still a great one . soft dark cocoa , with large fruity booze quality more like brandy than bourbon . earthy touch slightly , but forgo nut in flavor in the mid palate for more berry and cocoa taste . nougat aftertaste , almost like a sticky almond but not a sweet , touch with the high booze but tolerable still . mouthfeel while silky be just a touch fizzy lack a last coating to make the flavor last and ling . tend to flirt with fizz just a hair make for a bit of distraction . really impressed , but not as nutty as I expect . dark and opaque with small tan head . rich nose with heat in the nose , bourbon , reason and sweet malt . the taste be very complex with molasse , Brown sugar , date , raisin , oak , bourbon and just a hint of nut .

have this side by side with 2013 regular Cable Car and Veritas 012 . a : be warn , this be a gusher ! we be aware of it so we open it carefully enough to lose very few of it . pour dark than verita 012 , reddish with a good white foam . s : Smell be really complex , although the cherry be not obvious . the balance be awesome . 750 mL bottle pour into a snifter .   Appearance - Hazy and murky red body . do not gush ! small white head . medium collar .   Smell - Juicy cherry . acidic , but the cherry have a sweet pie aroma . 750ml bottle 7,0 % Abv . Served chill in a wine glass . no bottle date .   CCK be one of those beer that be n't even on my want list as I be pretty sure I would never ever get a chance to taste , but thank to the endless generosity of futur123 I be actually about to taste it ! thank man , I really owe you for this one .   appearance : the cork pop out with an almighty bang and for a moment I think I would get away without a gush , but as soon as I take my eye off the bottle pink foam start to rise slowly out of the neck . thankfully I have glass ready and manage to catch it all . the beer settle a clouded red - orange ( almost peachy ) with just a tinge of pink and be top by a large pink tint head . the head retention be reasonable , but sadly it do n't leave anything in the way of lacing .   Smell : wow , there be a ton of cherry in the initial nose and far sweet than I have expect - its almost jammy . a few more sniff reveal a fantastic acidity ( a touch of vinegar ) as well as a spicy almost cinnamon bark character . as the beer warm the nose open up with a little oak and some funk ( old hay , wet wood , mold and the faint hint of vomit ) become apparent .   taste : as the nose suggest there be a ton of sweet cherry upfront , but it be balance by a nice tartness and a fantastic acidity . note include : sweet jammy cherry , some tart cherry skin , a touch of vinegar , a little oak , lightly spicy , undergrowth , old hay and a touch of leather . the finish be quite dry .   Mouthfeel : initially there be a high level of rather expansive carbonation , but thankfully it settle down pretty quickly to reveal fine bubble that complement the acidity perfectly and lead to a fantastically spritzy finish . the body be medium and offer the faint stickiness from the fruit .   overall : cable Car Kriek be a fantastic cherry sour and quite a lot well than the regular Cable car . that say , I would be really piss off if I have pay $ 750 or what ever ridiculous price this be be sell for these day .

review a bottle of the test batch for Cable Car Kriek from the lost Abbey out of San Marcos , California . major thank to Paul and Jonathan for share this rare treat with I !   score : 100   the only thing I know about the bottle date of this beer be that it predate the 2011 release of Cable Car Kriek . my buddy get a Cable car Kriek label sticker , which he put on the otherwise unmarked bottle . serve in a Cantillon stem balloon glass and enjoy on 11/16/13 . review be from iPhone note .   appearance : pour a finger - plus of white frothy head . Color be a murky red - orange color with a bit of yellow - orange fade towards the edge of the body when hold up to light . excellent lacing and retention . 5/5   Smell : Cherry , then dank cinnamon , funk , wood , dank spice , fig , raisin , wood and lemon . hint of tobacco and vanilla . lot of unexpected cinnamon present in the nose , which be ridiculously complex and perfectly balanced between all the element present . just enough funk be present to give it an add dimension of complexity without detract at all from the appeal of the other aromatic . 5/5   taste : tart cherry hit first , then cinnamon , spice , vanilla and wood . Musty funk on the midpalate , oddly reminisce of that Cantillon house character with a little bit of age . Vanilla and cherrywood finish , light lemon backbone . dark cherry note and a little bit of cocoa - like flavor come through too as the beer warm up . the cherry flavor persist throughout , and linger nicely in the finish . I love how well the vanilla flavor play with sour character without be medicinal or come across as be out of place . all the flavor here be so perfectly integrate . there be so much go on , and it all work . the cinnamon character be a nice unique twist , though it be less prominent on the palate than it be in the nose . 5/5   Mouthfeel : medium bodied , spot on carbonation ( rare for a lost Abbey beer ) . great mix of sweet and sour , with a dry finish . 5/5   overall : one of the good beer I have ever have the pleasure to consume . it be complex , robust in flavor , tart , balanced and insanely drinkable . there be a reason this be one of the most seek after beer out there . I would not say it be worth the $ 600 - 800 it command on the secondary market , but I enjoy it more than M , which cost much more to acquire . my only quip here be that someone steal the bottle from Paul later in the evening . seek this one out with confidence .   cost : $ 50 for a 750 ml bottle ( good luck find it that for that price nowadays ) .

thank to Mike and Josh for this one . a long time want and one I think I 'd have to eventually travel to CA for . much appreciated . 4 oz . pour into a lost Abbey teku .   pour a .5 finger pink , frothy head with average retention . beer be a slightly cloudy stunning pink orange . Lacing be spotty and sparse with some stringiness and thin leg . average save for the really pretty color .   Nose be cinnamon , cherry jam , light tartness , hay , and some funky , we d woodiness . clean , fruity and very aromatic and appetizing .   sweet cherry , cinnamon , red fruit syrup , lightly sweet and mildly tart in the middle . great balance . More cherry , lemon rind , and hay at the finish with a sweet and tart cherry aftertaste . really really good .   light to medium bodied with ample carbonation . Dry in the mouth and pucker go down . very refreshing . sticky and dry finish with a messy and linger aftertaste . nearly perfect .   I think Cable Car be a slightly above average American Wild but this be a completely different animal . the addition of cherry have give this beer a whole new dimension and make it clearly one of the good in the style . definitely worth the hype .

brown glass bottle serve into a wine glass at the Toronado in San Diego . pay out the ass for this ( I think it around $ 50.00 ) . if there be a beer to shell this much out for , certainly this be it . ( or at least one of they ; see my Narke Kaggen Stormaktsporter review ) . review from note take in October 2012 .   a : pour a half finger delicate beige head of good lacing , nice thickness , and brief but appreciable retention . colour be a pale peach - red . Nontransparent ; non - opaque . no yeast particle be visible . no bubble show . have the appeal of a masterful red wine or bourbon . Classy and understate . I ca n't wait to try it .   sm : Sourness , bacteria , attenuate yeast , sour cherry , lactic note , some malty sweetness , tart cherry skin , and bright fruit . exceptional and clean . promise some serious puckerworthy sourness . a moderate strength aroma . no alcohol come through .   t : Sour , with some serious bacterial note on the back end . incredibly crisp like fresh red apple yet outfit with a wonderful solid cherry body . refreshing and clean , yet lightly vinegary and even subtly wine - esque . I get the wood , but it be subtle and understate in the background . rich and smcak - your - lip flavorful . incredibly tasty stuff . masterfully complex and balanced . no alcohol be detectable . so fresh and luscious . the linger long aftertaste help I enjoy it for long . I get cherrywood as well as oak . some pear . green apple . it be get all the sourness I could ever want , but the perfect amount without feel tame . not at all overdone . clean malt lend it body but do n't intrude , let the sourness shine through . it have an incredible amount of body for a kriek , almost like a fine french cider . I be blow away . marvelously build . nicely acidic , as well . tartness be supreme .   mf : Crisp , full , and of perfect thickness . smack - your - lip delightful . smooth and wet , let the flavour speak for itself . suit the flavour profile quite well .   Dr : an incredible kriek . live up to the hype , definitely . worth the price for a special occasion . another remarkable sour from Lost Abbey . I 'd love to have this again ( or the regular Cable car , for that matter ) . the mouthfeel be n't perfect ; it lack the fragile delicacy I 'd expect in a masterful sour - but it be still lovely . few sour I 've had have such presence and flavour . the depth of flavour and layer of mastery burgeon throughout . I detect at least five distinct act in the structure : the sweet , clean open ; the initial sour apple and hint of bacteria ; the middling bacteria sourness blast ; the fade cidery sharp climax with hint of lightly spicy yeast and cherry abound ; and the lightly dry fruit cherry skin finnish . remarkable . wow . have on tap at Toronado for the 25th Anniversary Party . so excited to try this beer . I walk into SD Toronado ( the SUPERIOR Toronado of the two ) while I be on my birthday vacation and be shocked to see this sitting in the cooler . yes , it be sit in the cooler ... for all to see . no ask the bartender if they have it just to let they decide if they like you enough to serve it to you . this Toronado do it how it should be . such great service , outstanding food , and great beer selection . back to the Kriek, .. it pour a lot less " pink " than I think it would be . it be a clouded , light - red color with an off - white head . scent be very cherry - forward with some definite barnyard and musty aroma . the smell be so darn inviting , I ca n't help but take few sip of this beer immediately . the cherry be so profound in this beer , more than I expect . a good amount of oak and funk . not overly acidic whatsoever ... in fact , not very acidic at all . just a clean , funky , fruity , wild ale . Mouthfeel be medium bodied , almost puckering , with a juicy finish . sour and juicy equal amazing in my book . drinkability be very high . overall , this beer be worth every penny I spend on it . I go into the night willing to spend $ 80 on the bottle , just to find out it be $ 55 . so worth it . a phenomenal wild ale .

thank you , Tomme . DC Lambic & Sour Summit on 4/14/2012 , many thank to brad for acquire both the sour and regular version . review of regular version with parenthetical to the sour version   appearance : Major gusher , cork hit the ceiling . pour be very hazy and murky , a bit pink ( sour version not such a gusher , probably because no sugar be add to it ) smell : sweet cherry , touch of earth and funk . a bit too sweet . have this multiple time . review the most recent one I 've have @ Toronado sd ( not available anymore though :/ )   thankfully this , bottle be not a gusher . nice pop to the cork though . serve in a wine tulip . the bottle be chill down considerably and have not be move around much at all .   the carbonation be generous , but not overly so . it definitely subdue after sit in the glass a bit . the smell be of tart cherry , slight amount of funky earthy / barnyard to it .   the beer itself taste very fruity , more sour than I remember it in past bottle , and resemble more like a great american wild than the tart cherry soda it could have pass for a year ago . thank Brad , serve in a lost Abbey Teku glass because that be the way God intend . this probably go without say because the genius at Lost Abbey be incapable of get it right at all but this beer be severely over carbonate , dangerously so . lose more than half the bottle to the gush and the bottle be serve super cold and we be anticipate the gush , regardless , it be a gusher . from 04/14/12 note . big thank to Brad for bust this one out at our DC Epic Sour Tasting . got to try 2 version of this next to a normal 2010 Cable Car . the first be an unlabeled version that be allegedly dub " too sour " and not release . the second be the label version available at Toronado . I enjoy both but think the normal label version be much well , so review that one .   a - pour a murky pinkish red color with one inch of off white head and moderate carbonation evident .   s - smell of sour tart , cherry , sour dark fruit , spice , cinnamon , yeast , and some light earthy note . really awesome , a ton of cherry .   t - taste of sour cherry , tart dark fruit , spice , fruity malt , funk , floral and earthy note . taste be a little fruity then the nose . really awesome taste , super tart and fruity . perfect for I and a kriek .   m - medium body and moderate carbonation . crisp and easy to drink . really nice .   o - overall I think this be an amazing beer ; I prefer the label version and think I prefer it slightly to the normal Cable Car . a ton of tart cherry and soem light spice , this be one of the good kriek I 've ever have . hope they have this at Toronado when I eventually make it out there .

bottle at the DC Lambic & Sour Tasting on April 14 , 2012 . serve in a lost Abbey Teku .   big thank to Brad for acquire two different version of this rarity . the first be an unlabeled version that be allegedly dub " too sour " and not release . the second be the label version available at Toronado . the review that follow be of the " regular " version from Toronado . after that be some note on the unlabeled version in comparison to that one .   Gusher alert ! Holy hell do this thing explode . even after be store cold and open right out of the fridge , as soon as the cage come off the cork start push up and beer shoot out sideways several foot . thankfully we be mostly prepare , as have we not be ready I think we would have lose the whole bottle .   after all that , the beer pour a hazy and murky reddish - amber with a small off - white head that recede pretty quickly , leave just a bit of sparse lace behind .   the nose carry heavy note of cherry with a bit of nutty pit in there , though just a touch . behind that be a really nice bit of earth and some very light barnyard . the flavor be similar and bring plenty of cherry along with some light funk and moderate acidity .   body be medium with average carbonation and a dry finish . really a lot more depth to this one than with the 2010 Cable Car that we have alongside the two Kriek version .   compare to the regular version , the " too sour " unlabeled version do not have nearly as much cherry and have quite a bit more acidity . the cherry that be there seem to be more of a sour cherry , and there be n't nearly as many earthy note . this remind I much more of the Cable Car with cherry add , whereas the label version seem like a different beer . very interesting comparison . thank again , Brad .

have a bottle at Toronado San Diego .   a : a crisp look ruby color , minimal head with very fine lacing .   s : this scent would be extraordinary anywhere . wish I do n't have to wash out the bottle . fresh cherry up front with a nice wine - barrel undertone .   t : wow . arguably one of the good sour I 've ever have . fantastic cherry flavor with some subtle citrus just to throw I off . great profile blend with whatever wine barrel they use .   mf / d : incredibly smooth . fortunately we do n't get a gusher , and the carbonation be faint , effervescent , and smooth . ca n't wait to convince my friend to get another bottle !

pour from bottle into Tulip at Toronado San Diego .   appearance : pour a bright hazy red / orangeish color with about a finger width of a light pink head that dissipate there after leave by some thin lacing along the glass . thank to someone 's sister for get he one . consume next to 07 , 08 , 09 Cable Car .   a : a loud pop of the cork and a fountain of foam gush from the bottle spray the window in front of the sink . we proceed to let the foam - over pour and fill multiple glass , but we still lose a good amount of beer . this beer be the definition of ' gusher ' . this beer be very murky , cloudy , and the color of pink grapefruit . s : I get light note of funk and earthy , but for the most pat this beer be rather sweet smelling . the tartness be there and come through in the form of cherry skin and lemon z . t : Sugary . very sugary . the cherry be very sweet and candy - like rather than be fruity and ripe . in fact , you can taste the fruit addition that set this beer apart from the original , but it ’s rather ambiguous and not especially cherry - like . I get flavor of citrus , lemon , peach and prune . the funk be almost nonexistent , but there be a light sourness to the brew . the aftertaste coat my mouth and be very sugary sweet and candy - like . despite all of this , the flavor profile be good , just not what I be expect nor what I think this beer ' should ’ taste like . m : Greasy and slick mouthfeel , medium - full body , low carbonation , and lightly tart . no dryness at all . o : to date , Cable Car be probably my favorite LA beer , and one of the top 10 good beer I ’ve try . this beer , however , be just too sweet . I could barely tell it be Cable Car and not some Lindemans beer . the fruit be there by it do n’t scream cherry . despite all of this , I think a bit of age would do it some good , assume the cork do n't pop itself off , and I would definitely drink this again .

review 1598 Consecration Russian River Brewing Date : 05 November 2020 another sour today , but this one be age in wine barrel with currant . pull the cork carefully , then a loud pop , follow by mist . the beer be 48 degree , and I serve it my Stone RIS tulip . the pour create a fizzy and airy off - white head with poor retention . no lacing on the glass after the quick dissipation . the color be a combination between maroon and mahogany with brownish hue . this beer be translucent , with a few carbonation bubble present .   the aroma in the beer be vinous , fruity , sour apple , oaky , funkiness , earthy , horse blanket , biscuit , bready , and a slight hint of pharmaceutical .   the flavor be oaky , earthy , funky , lightly toasted malt , brett , sour apple vinegar , bready , a hint of floral ester , vinous , stone fruit , tart cherry , and danky .   the mouthfeel be dry , tannic , and pucker   the body of the beer be medium , medium - plus carbonation , and linger finish .   this sour be wonderful all the flavor in the beer create this harmonious blend of flavor . the wine barrel aging give the beer depth and complexity . stellar beer !

Consecration - 9/17/2015   look : pour translucent and murky medium brown . auburn and chestnut in the light . a beige colored head that disappear with a thin ring of foam around the edge of the glass . no lacing and no visible carbonation .   Smell : the aroma be floral , powdery , perfumey and musty . a lot of wood . fresh currant , cherry and blackberry . citrus acidity and a faint amount of some apple cider vinegar .   taste : sweet and sour . a hint of apple cider vinegar . some cinnamon spice . some berry flavor chocolate . some pithy bitterness . the acidity level be medium for I .   feel : very smooth and low carbonation . some more effervescence would help . not sure if it ’s flatten out a bit over time or not . sweet up front and dry on the finish .   overall : you ’d never know this beer be 10 % other than feel the alcohol . no alcohol on the aroma of taste . definitely have some red wine similarity , but also many aspect from the mixed fermentation that you ’d not expect in red wine . it ’s really delicious .

More tart to open with a bit of cheesy funk at first , follow closely by that sweet raspberry character from the nose . medium finish that end nicely tart and acidic , moderately dry . once it ’s hit room temperature the base beer shine through much more , leave a yeasty note in the finish I be n’t get before . great balanced oak character   f : medium carbonation , medium- body , medium+ acidity a bit elevated as it hit room temp   o : a delicious fruit lambic , capture the fruit well while stay true to the funky / wild part of the brew . a pinch on the sweet side at first , as it warm up that mellow with the base lambic shine through more . overall great , as I expect a delicious belgian beer
it ’s exactly what I want my fruit lambic to taste like . rich flavor that do n’t overwhelm the base beer or hide the natural funkiness . drink clean and easy , not overly tart .

pour an entitely hazed orange yellow with a huge , spongy and stable head .   burst of passion fruit , ripe pineapple and fresh cut lime , establish an exotic fruitiness from first glance . have a white bread dough undertone add to the hop inspire nose , reveal additional mango , tangerine and white wine grape .   have a soft , smooth mouthfeel to it with a fitting , compliment carbonation . this have a light to medium body with a nice , refreshing effervescence during its finish .   taste of ripe mango , luscious peach and bitter lime , accompany by an ice bonbon freshness and a noble hop dryness . the beer then develop an intriguing old cheese , ripe orange interplay with a resinous peak to it , gently balance by flowery lime and breadcrust malt . finish dry and bitter with a vivid fruit basket , light and a bit more crisp , create a great complexity on its way out .   this be quite unusual for a hazy ipa , make excessivly use of the great Nelson hop , which work marvelously well together with Citra . trade for this a while ago , as the date on the bottom of the can read 9/8/17 with " hold on to " write above it and sunshine write below it . love the name and label of this beer , down to the " 9/20/14 " on the side which be probably the marriage date reference in the description . this be a typical beer from Tree House and a typical New England IPA in the sense that be cloudy , juicy , and soft but the latter make this so easy to enjoy as the Citra and Nelson be easy to discern as they work so harmoniously together .   this have a good pour to it as the liquid look like faded orange juice , with just a bit more head present here ! it hold it be own and the lacing on the side of my pint glass be quiet extensive as well as the ring be well - define and nearly bleed down to the one below they . ton of orange juice , tangerine , cream , sherbert , and mute earthy dankness in the nose as the citrus slickness come through more boldly in the taste . Melon , white grape , and a bit of woodsy dankness could be feel in the taste as this almost feel barrel - aged but be just a result of the Nelson come through . the malt be present as this have body but it be tough to pick out any of it besides a basic doughy presence and the carbonation be sufficient enough to keep this from feel too heavy .   not a lot of alcohol here but what be present could be feel when I finish this off and lend itself to a slight warming feeling that take hold of I before I polish this off . just as smooth as the Julius or Haze , this be on par with those while have a bit more depth and earth dankness to it . love the idea of this and would love to get my hand on a more recent version of it just to see if it be the same take this time around . long live this beer , in perpetuity !

the last bottle from a beautiful trade with that_bearded_guy this summer , which I be save to pop on our twentieth wedding anniversary . split with my marvelous wife !   the 750ML bottle have one of those handy tag that rip a hole in the wax big enough to get a bottle opener in , which my oft - puncture finger appreciate . silver wax spray off & we ’re into a big , black beer with minimal visible carbonation . the nose be Willy Wonka bar , coffee , & light , warm malt . nice .   sump – Barrel Aged Coffee Stout be an odd breed of coffee stout . the coffee show as roast in the nose & only faintly in the taste , which lean into herb & dark fruit . slotting in next be plenty of cocoa , char , lovely shot of whiskey , vanilla creamer , & what taste like good old Wesley ’s Maple Syrup . the Finnish be all NIN bass , dark , driving , tasty . old school big stout thick ( not pastry chef thick ) , which raise the drinkability level .   this be a beer that be in no way , no form , no how worth the price of admission . it ’ sump plus a bit of char & whiskey . still : sump = excellent , & the BA version continue that trend of excellence . happy to have it in my mouth .

have on tap . the pour be jet black and emit strong coffee and cream aroma with a burst of rye whiskey booziness at the end . the taste be magnificently focus on the coffee yet pull in plenty of other rich flavor such as fudge , booze barrel , vanilla , molasse and cinnamon . can just chew on this beer for hour

Smell : Straight Fudge . big milk chocolate , dark chocolate . fresh roasted espresso bean , vanilla , coconut , bourbon , oak , a little pop of dark fruit . this be just a straight chocolate bomb mix with coffee and barrel . this beer smell like a chocolate paradise .   taste : right upfront I get a good amount of dark fruit and dark cherry . raisin , plum , dark cherry juice . the mid palette the beer just become a massive chocolate , coffee , fudge bomb . melt milk chocolate , rich fudgie brownie batter , dark chocolate cover espresso bean . the finish I get a barrel presence but it be n’t huge . I get a nice vanilla and coconut sweetness with a touch of sweet smooth bourbon and a woody , oaky bitterness to give this beer a balance to counter the sweetness .   feel : the mouthfeel on this beer be absurd . full and thick . chewy , but super Creamy and velvety . this beer coat every inch of your mouth and tongue and never lets go . just an absolutely perfect mouthfeel .   overall : this be an easy 100/100 beer . a perfect use of coffee and barrel . this be a beer you need to sip on to truly enjoy everything that this have to offer . what an amazing first beer to have from side project .

review be for 2018 release of BA Sump .   the pour on this be dark , like motor oil . the syrupy body do n’t leave much to be remember , with hardly any residual lace and a very thin head of deep tan foam .   the nose start with a very strong aroma of dark sweet fruit , swirl with chocolate and finish with an oakey , tobacco finale .   that initial surprising sweetness return in the flavor , this time accompany by a more present roasted malt bill and a bitter coffee finish .   the mouthfeel be smooth , creamy , and sticky , and overall you really see the coffee balance the barrel in the overall profile of this beer .

remember that Guitar Hero commercial from way back when with Heidi Klum wear nothing but a white button up shirt and sock , jam out like nobody be watch to Bob Seger 's " Old Time Rock and Roll " hold a Guitar Hero controller ?   well that be pretty much I after take one sip of BA Sump .   I do n't know if it be because I have n't have beer in a while , or because this particular drinking session happen after three - four week worth of very stressful life event , but for some reason I feel a sudden rush of incredible euphoria the exact moment the precious black liquid pass between my lip and my neurotransmitter start fire back signal try to decode the wonderment beckon my palatal and olfactory sense -- I guess this be why I be still obsess with a hobby that be detrimental to both my health and bank account ; which gift I with nothing but split headache and cottonmouth in the morning while steal my gain at the gym .   in all sincerity , ( regular ) sump be quite possibly the most coffee - forward beer I 've ever try . when I say that it be coffee - forward , I do n't mean the kind that your secretary serve you in a white styrofoam cup , lukewarm with creamer and two spoon of sugar . I mean the straight - up bold illustrious flavor that emanate out of fresh roasted bean that may or may not have be burn beyond the sixth layer of hell because you get your coffee at Starbucks . I 'd argue that the coffeeness in Sump 's coffee be more coffee than most coffee in a way a rose be a rose be a rose be not a rose , but I be probably get ahead of myself at this point so I 'll stop .   the aroma come out of the bottle be very much similar to its non - ba kin ; so much coffee that you do n't quite know whether you want to try and heat it up and drink it black , or put it in a cheap reusable plastic cup with ice , sugar , and saturate fat and serve it with a dollop of whip cream on top .   after some time and temperature , however , the command sweetness share its spot on the podium with a light hint of chocolate , and sweet cream clue you in that other element may be at play .   I have n't have a beer that be this straightforward since Weyerbacher 's Sunday Morning Stout . in fact , for those of you that have try Sunday Morning and be somewhat familiar with CrossFit : Sunday Morning be to Annie Þórisdóttir what BA Sump be to Katrin Davíðsdóttir . for those of you that do n't have a clue what that mean , they be both world class beer that I 'd drink again without bat an eye , but the latter edge out the former as a more robust all - round mesh of bourbon and coffee flavor .   in plain speak , I have yet to try a beer that come close to the perfect marriage of coffee and rye whiskey that I 've witness in BA Sump . neither flavor eclipse the other , while neither be express at less than 100 % of its expressable potential -- hell you might as well throw a scalding cup of coffee and a glass of whiskey in my face simultaneously and I 'd get all the same sensation , albeit without the masterful blending and delicious flavor .

buy on a recommendation at Blackbeard 's Crafts on Sawtelle , this one surprise I . everything in it be subservient to the cacao-- the vanilla stand in for sugar , the coffee offer bitterness where the malty stout would itself refuse to . it do really remind you of a milkshake , but not quite because of any desserty cloy sweetness . it be the viscosity , the half - and - half mouthfeel that deliver the vanilla and cacao while somehow sneak in a full 12 or 13 percent ABV when you can barely even register the burn . mine pour into a snifter with no head and barely even the sound of fizziness , and on the nose it be pure dessert-- chocolate milk or devil 's food cake . I try not to inhale too much as I drink it , because I want to catch the ancho chili and the beer in a way that the aroma do n't carry . usually , this be not my kind of thing-- I do n't like foreign flavor as a dominant element , and I like for a fine food to carry more layer , or maybe more variance between its layer . " bomb ! " , instead , wield its complexity in a way that focus your attention onto that single 65 - percent - cacao sensory simulacrum , make you wonder how this be even beer .   I want to finish by say that I respect this beer but do n't plan to buy another . unfortunately for I , this beer feel like a perfect match for some of my favorite domestic blue cheese . Rogue Creamery 's exquisite " Caveman Blue " sing in the same key as this stout , and I have no choice but to try they together .

* pour into a Teku glass from a 12 oz bottle *   the look of this beer be a very dark brown , reminiscent of cold brew coffee . this honestly do n't really have a head to it , so I ca n't really comment on the head , but there be a very thin dark drown lace around my glass .   the aroma be heavy on the ancho chilie , which be super pungent upfront . it be n't a one - note smell though , the ancho chilli serve as a backbone for an overall savory , slightly sweet , and unique aroma support by bitter coffee note and a slight caramel sweetness from the roasted malt . the aroma almost remind I a little of korean red pepper paste , but I can also see people think this also smell a bit like soy sauce .   the taste more or less follow the aroma . the taste of the ancho chilli with a mellow coffee backbone permeate throughout the entire stout from start to finish . although this beer primarily taste of ancho chilie , I be also really able to taste most of the different flavoring add to this beer . Upfront , you get the taste of ancho chilie with a mellow coffee herbalness / bitterness that be compliment with a caramel sweetness . the sweet taste of the caramel seemingly disappear towards the middle and end , which leave I with the roasty taste of coffee that be also pair with note of bitter dark chocolate and of course , ancho chilli . I could n't necessarily taste the vanilla bean which be add to this , but I feel like it serve to mellow and round out the other bold ingredient which be add .   the feel on this be medium to full bodied , have little to no noticeable carbonation , and have a moderate linger bitterness . all which contribute in make a silky smooth drinking experience . for the ABV , this be stupid drinkable and I feel like I have to keep remind myself to slow it down and sip . that be say , I could n't really taste the alcohol in this and there be n't any burn sensation .   overall , I have to say that this be definitely one of the more unique beer that I 've ever have . the addition of ancho chilli work pretty well when combine with coffee , cacao nibs , and vanilla bean , which I feel make this beer a satisfying explosion ( no pun intend ) of savoriness , sweetness , and roasty bitterness . definitely good , and definitely worth the price tag .

12 oz bottle from 4 pack , no date that I can see , but I know this fly out the door quick . Boulevard Smokestack snifter .   pour a really deep saturated orange gummy bear color with a tall creamy head that stay impressively stable at 1.5 finger and leave connected lacing . this look to be a quality beer .   Aroma be drunk grapefruit and drunk orange in copious amount . just sop wet saturate alcoholic citrus fruit . hint of ginger and chlorophyll / plant .   Flavor be palate scrub , and HUGE with ton of grapefruit , orange peel , bitter bitter mango , onion , and sawdust . the oil and resin come around a few second after the swallow , almost like a sneak attack , and turn your mouth inside out . it take about ten second , but the IBU and lupulin content be unmatched . this thing be the ultimate palate wrecker . I 've never have a beer literally go away completely , and then come back again like Soundgarden 's " somewhere " or Alice in Chains ' " rain when I die " . it perform a surprise encore after you swallow it .   feel be oily and resinous , like a bomb , the thing be the definition of a sipper , and have some crispness and acidity with moderate heat and carbonation .   overall , this beer be too much for I . I can respect it though - I 've never have this much alpha acid attack my palate relentlessly . I be expect something different , and while it be not my thing , I totally understand the hype ( unlike a few other beer ) and I can respect that . it be a massive beer , and if you like massive ipa , you 'll like this one a lot .   price pay : $ 15.99 / 4 pack would buy again : not personally , but I ca n't not recommend it   edit :   after 1 year and 1 week , I be crack the last bottle . I want to see how well it would develop as a Barleywine . it be not quite there yet , in fact the hoppiness be still very prominent , but there be a nice toasted caramel flavor underneath and it be taste damn delicious . Toasted caramel , citrus fruit , a little apricot , and some crisp Maris Otter . that be what I be get here . oxidation in the nose but not in the flavor . still very clean . fusel be there but pleasant . I hate the label but I may just buy this again and age it for a couple year . pretty dang decent after it have sit for awhile . Bottled 09.28.20 , update on 10.08.21 .

2018 vintage Consumed Christmas Eve 2020 375ml bottle   pour a nice ruby red color , translucent with a small white tan head be fizzy and dissipate quickly . Aroma be huge sourness , tart lactic acidity , with a prominent minerality and plastic like funk note . ton of fruit note as well with huge raspberry , nearly as big cherry , and even some strawberry note ( although I know there ’s no strawberry in it ) . just an absolutely wonderful aroma . taste be just an insanely huge puckering sourness . this be easily amongst the most sour beer I ’ve ever have and I love that . fruit note balance wonderfully with both sour and sweet and raspberry and cherry . some clean mineral dry character , moderate oakiness , essentially no pungeant funk note but rather all sour / tart character ; which again I love . carbonation be actually quite low , I think it ’ fair to say undercarbed , although the puckering tartness and dry finish make that low carbonation affect the product less than it otherwise would . drinkability be excellent and I wish I have more of this . overall just a wonderful beer .   3.75/4.75/4.75/4/4.5

blend 40 season 17/18 . bottle on March 22 , 2018 .   look : the beer pour pinkish / light red from the bottle . in the glass it ’s translucent cranberry juice / raspberry tea color . an ever so slight haze to it . lot of carbonation . light pink head disappear with no lacing .   Smell : the fruit be sweet , tart and acidic . sweet and sugary cherry and raspberry and tart , fresh berry . then the funk . Plastic - y and band aid note be most prominent . there ’s a faint barnyard manure note . some bitter and herbal earthiness . the fruit and funk come together as a little cinnamon spice . really nice nose . Complex .   taste : Tart , acidic and dry . sometimes the fruit jam sweetness come through on these beer , but not here . the acidity be manageable and pleasant . barely hit the jowel and never really go full lemon juice / vinegar like some sour beer do . there ’s a very slight bitterness but sour and faint sweetness be the main flavor here . what I ’ll call a musty note that pop fresh and seem to subside as the beer warm . I find it difficult to exactly describe this flavor in lambic . it lean toward the plastic - y note mention early , but it do n’t quite go that far . it ’ more musty and earthy . I wish I could find a single word to describe the flavor , but I ca n’t really find anything yet .   feel : medium carbonation and medium bodied . very dry .   overall : an enjoyable lambic that showcase the fruit while offer a medium level of funk . a solid a , 4 out of 5 in my book

product_name: Double Dry Hopped Double Mosaic Dream
product_review: 16 oz can 11 - 17 - 20 , open 1 - 10 - 21 . 2 finger off white head with excellent stay power - enough density to hang out over the rim of the glass for a minute . Sweet orange , pithy bitterness and mango nectar . full body , low + carbonation , prickly mouthfeel with some 8.5 % heat . soft but persistent bitterness in a slightly sweet finish . very good .

product_review: after be politely ask to vacate my Lyft for defecate in my freshly iron skidz , I be dump curbside in front of the gleam ray of light know as other Half Brewing . waddle in like an elderly penguin enter a good Western , I catch the attention of a beautiful bartender and order a beer . product_name: Double Dry Hopped Double Mosaic Dream
product_review: bottom of can : 2/19/19   straw golden color with slight amber hue . a fluffly and bubbly white foam keep it high . light coverage , display sticky lace .   Mosiac hop have to be one of the most diverse hop in every way . the aroma be of sweet tropical fruit , pineapple , citrus and melon . the malt be a light , crispy grain and a smooth creamy style smell , very light and golden aromatic . big time nose .   the tropical fruity hop complexity from the Mosiac be pretty high grade . the hop flavor roll on and on with multiple layer . a sharp earthy , dry texture kick in , peppery pineapple a dry citrus tone soon roll in . orange with black pepper and dry crispy pilsner style malt all mingle together for a bit until it all finish dry and hearty . a milky , smoothness happen within the malty feel and flavor that linger on as creamy , and then more orange citrus tone come back . like I say , complex , with layer .   the dry hop Mosiac approach make for a seriously deep hoppy groove in both mouthfeel and flavor . the aftertaste of fresh , dry hop keep go long after the last sip . obviously complexity be vety high concidere the quality and balance of malt / hop . the ale yeast be always very neautral and clean , which allow the hop to shine and malt to hold it all down . you would never know this be 8.5 % abv . because of the heady complexity and dry tone . the alcohol only add further depth to an already heady brew .

review # 1500 ! ! ! a massive thank go out to cmrillo for bring this one out during his own 40 Beers * @ 40 Birthday Bash ! ca n’t believe I FINALLY get to try this one ! ! ! 2008 vintage ! serve from bottle into a Mikkeller taster flute . pour pitch black with a minimal tan head . maintain excellent lacing throughout the glass . the aroma be comprise of sweet malt , wood , dark chocolate , vanilla , sweet alcohol , and roasted malt . the flavor be of sweet malt , roasted malt , dark chocolate , vanilla , wood , sweet alcohol , and milk chocolate . it have a heavy feel on the palate with medium carbonation . overall this be an excellent brew . this be another one that I be shocked to see come out at the birthday party . this be sample directly after Stormaktsporter . there be a pretty good difference in this one from the base brew . there be a lot more presence of the vanilla with an addition of various chocolate aspect . the cigar aspect I pick up on in the base brew have disappear , but what replace it in both the flavor and aroma be just plain excellent . so glad I get the chance to finally try this one and would love to do so over and over again .

pour from a 8 oz . bottle into a taste glass . 2008 vintage . thank a ton to Paulmpapp for bring this out to our whale tasting .   appearance : typical RIS look - ebony black color with a fairly thin tan head of creamy bubble slowly fade to a collar and leave a thin sheet of lace .   Smell : the aroma be very balanced and smooth . some sweet bourbon , raisin , fig , and dark roasted malt be all subtle and blended so well together . dark chocolate and a bit of espresso round out the nose .   taste : the flavor be pretty much exactly what I want out of a barrel aged imperial stout . Smooth , sweet bourbon come in first and slowly let in the fig , raisin , cherry , and roasted malt blend beautifully together . some dark chocolate fudge , vanilla , and light espresso note be in the background . the finish have a bit more bourbon and finish fairly clean .   Mouthfeel : the carbonation be smooth , with just enough crispness to excite the tongue along with the bourbon . the body be on the full side of medium and consistent all the way through . slightly sticky on the lip .   overall : clearly , this be one of the good imperial stout I have have . no individual flavor really stand out , but the flavor in concert work so well together .

750ml bottle , 2016 vintage , pour into a the bruery tulip glass . enjoy on 1.31.17 , review from Tasting Journal .   the beer pour a jet black color , very opaque and thick with a thin tan head that have no retention and yield no lace . the aroma be nice , huge charred barrel character with ton of chocolate , lightly roasted coffee , smooth oak , stone fruit with a lot of hot alcohol as it warm . the flavor be good , ton of chocolate , cold press coffee , mild acidity and light roast , vanilla bean with smooth and rich bourbon , super chewy oak , light char , linger stone fruit and very intense alcohol . the mouthfeel be okay , coating , medium body , very active texture which be a bit surprising with a smooth but very warm finish .   Verdict : a decent barrel age stout from the Bruery but I think I prefer the regular Black Tuesday . the coffee here add some acidity that just add to the harshness of the alcohol . again , with many of the Bruery beer , it be just too massive and too intense that it be tough to handle more than a few ounce .

Jan 2021 New Years Day 2019 vintage from pint growler fill at B&V. pour into tulip glass .   same as prior but this time appearance be much well . huge tan head , ton of thick lacing . same great smell , taste and feel . about as close to perfect as I can imagine . June 2018 update have a 2017 vintage from a 16 oz growler pour recently at Barrels & Vines .   very much the same as original review with cinnamon a bit more pronounced , slightly less alcohol but every bit as good as I remember . maybe even creamy than I recal . a great beer . have a few more 2017 in the cellar . ca n’t wait ! did n’t get any 2018 as it be taproom only release which be n’t practical for a SE MI beer lover .   2017 vintage ( orange ball ) . pour a dark brown with a small head that take some work . minimal lacing , low carbonation .   sweet smell with a delicious aroma I ca n't place . maybe toast coconut ( which I do n't normally like ) with brown sugar . definite booziness but very smooth nonetheless .   sweet right at the start but chocolate , brown sugar , vanilla , cinnamon , other spice combine with bourbon and oak . one of the more complex and wonderful taste I 've experience . maybe a bit on the sweet and boozy side but I love it . get well as it warm .   Mouthfeel be amazing . substantial complexity with low carbonation that suit I just right . like the taste , it get well as it warm .   overall , one of the good beer I 've ever have . definitely a bit sweet but not overdone . the sugar and bourbon alcohol mix perfectly with chocolate , spice , vanilla and cinnamon .   ca n't wait to age a bottle and drink another !

2016 vintage with the Purple Bowling Ball on the label , it pour pitch black color with a small tan / mocha color head that fade fast then normal and leave minimal trace of lacing . nose be full of oak , vanilla , bourbon , dark chocolate , molasse , brown sugar , light soy sauce , dark fruit and chocolate milk . Flavor have a lot more dark fruit , toffee and sweetness to it like black cherry soda along with brown sugar and a melt Heath Bar . it almost border on cloyingly sweet , but that aspect help hide the 15 % ABV . like the nose I get of barrel or oaky note , vanilla , bourbon , dark chocolate , molasse , brown sugar , light soy sauce , more dark fruit , cocoa powder , candy and chocolate milk . none of the coconut advertise on the bottle , but a dynamic profile that be a lot more balanced than I expect . a tad bit thin , even for a porter , and while it ’ overall a very impressive brew it ’s too sweet to drink a bomber by yourself as I struggle have it alone . a definite dessert beer to share with a few other beer lover .

review from note . pour from a 22 oz . bottle into an El Catador Barrel - aged glass . purple bowling ball ( 2016 bottle ) .   a : very dark brown , nicely opaque , with a thin tan head that fade to a ring along the side . low visible carbonation .   s : big bourbon up front , with less , but still big , oakiness . as the bourbon punch fade the coconut , vanilla , and chocolate malt show up . roasted malt , cacao , mild char , and dark roasted coffee . light tobacco as well . definitely booze - forward , but yet still not a particularly " alcoholic " smell . really nice here .   t : Chocolate and bourbon , vanilla and coconut . Oak tannin and sweetness , with milk chocolate and roasted malt . some ethanol burn , dry tobacco , and note of caramel and milder sorghum . then more coconut . a mild roast bitterness and milder hop bitterness near the end , but ultimately fail to even come close to balance the sweetness – chocolate with coconut plus the vanilla swell at the end , but some bourbon sweetness ultimately win out after the swallow .   o : a nice thick body for a porter , although this seem like a " porter " in name only . the alcohol be quite prevalent , albeit very well - hide for anything claim to be 15 % . low carbonation sensation , but seem fitting for this beer .   o : this be quite good . a nice coconut and chocolate and bourbon balance . but it be pretty sweet – and that come from a guy in Florida use to CCB , Angry Chair , and cycle stout . I wish there be just a little more bitterness here – whether from the roast or hop I would n’t care . it ’s not quite disagreeably cloying , but even split the bottle two way the sweetness be just a little more than I be look for .

2016 purple ball . sweet coconut milk . this be really sweet ; probably due to addition of turbinado sugar in addition to the coconut . slight alcohol burn on the back end . one dimensional pure coconut with a slick mouthfeel that linger . very enjoyable .

buy in 16 oz bomber   color : black as the soul Smell : Delicious . if this beer be a candle , I 'd buy a crate of they . coconut and vanilla taste : Coconut , caramel , vanilla . bourbon flavor be wonderfully subtle . sweet . Orange Bowling Ball . pour into a KBS extend tulip . syrupy almost - black body that be steadfast in its presence . mocha brown head start strong , taper down and settle into a good routine with a decent layer that clump and drift even moreso along the edge . some intermittent lacing .   very sweet off the bat and an almost burn character . some nutty / roasty coconut husk , but I be not really get any of the meat/*coconut * coconut that I be look for . fleeting touch of licorice and almost cinnamon ( but like ... candy cinnomon . red hot , not actual cinnamon sticks)drift by . interestingly I do n't feel like there be a lot of the classic PORTER flavour jump out either ... mainly the sugar and some woody / nutty husk . I be actually pretty underwhelme by the aroma .   ah , now that be more what I be look for . well , first the two thing that jump out right off the bat be that it be very sweet and there be a lot of alcohol . this be definitely 15 % . move beyond these broad stroke , we focus in and find sweet candy coconut ( think mound bar ) with creamy cocoa . blend into bourbon note of vanilla and caramel and just a faint hint of mash before commit again to its sugary beginning . Finish carry the sugar sweetness but leave the coconut primarily on the back burner , leave hint of creamy chocolate and a little bit of coffee and maaaybe char just peek in at the edge . final note bring back some of the bourbon mash .   Sticky and coat the mouth with chocolate this have a medium body that be smoothe as silk . finely effervescent , and even though it taste big ( because it be ) , it be not harsh and fold in with the rest of the flavour , so while you can tell you be getting wallop , it do n't taste hot .   this one be very very high on my radar , so much gratitude extend to @FlintB for send this along as part of NBS BIF#007 . thank Brian for spread the bounty of your home state !

2015 vintage 22 oz bottle pour into a tulip   a- pour a deep brown color with a one - finger creamy khaki head that reduce to a thin film float on top , some lacing leave behind   s- big malty nose with caramel & toffee lead the way , along with lot of dark fruity aroma of raisin & fig . undertone of coconut and brown sugar be definitely noticeable . not pick up much barrel aroma except some earthy wood   t- huge malty sweetness up front follow the nose , with caramel and sticky toffee lead the way , immediately follow by raisin , fig , date & black cherry . mid - palate bring out note of brown sugar , coconut flake , molasse & caramel candy . the finish add some light bourbon note , with oak and vanilla accent , linger of black cherry   M- heavy body with moderate carbonation lead to a creamy and chewy mouthfeel that continue into a velvety , warm finish   O- a massive beer with all of the adjunct still come through . it be impressive that it keep the sweetness manageable as well , give the abv

22 ounce bottle into a snifter . 2017 edition , have 1/6/18 .   pour dark , opaque , with no real head and some spotty lacing . smell of roasted malt , molasse , bourbon , cocoa , coffee , some coconut , light toffee . a light sweet aroma . smell great . the taste be less roasted malt than the nose , also light bourbon , coconut , coffee , chocolate , some oak , light caramel , a solid sweet note . taste pretty great , too . really smooth for the very high ABV , a solid medium to full body , well carbonate .   great blend of flavor and aroma , the Turbinado sugar and coconut star . light bourbon than I recall from 2016 , but only have a taste of that one . this be one you want to try annually , if you get the chance .

Head retention be poor . start out dense bubble on top and small almost like a nitro on bottom . quickly dissipate . typical of warm beer .   Smell : not strong . you have to wait for it to fill the the glass . very pleasant and complex .   taste 1 : when first hit the tongue it fill the mouth in a pleasant way before you even drink it in . taste 2 : pull into mouth and swirl around , nothing really change still pleasant . very little to none carbonation you do not really notice the alcohol with all the other strong flavor . just the way an RIS should be . there be a weird tingling on the tongue . the tingle be just odd and different . taste 3 : just swallow . this be the strong flavor and most satisfying . Aftertaste : the really hard one to master . they get it perfect . it linger quit awhile morph but stay quit pleasant . never to sweet or to bitter .   feel : it be kind of thin but it do not distract from the beer with such a great aftertaste .   problem : the taste be so nice and it go down so smooth I find myself drink it much fast than I should . especially for a 12 % .   I be go to have to cellar some but do not see how it could improve much . it be already as good a 2 plus year old Stone RIS .   note : from Massachusetts but stay in Minnesota for awhile .

Bottled 9.18.20 , open 12.31.20   Bomber pour into a stemmed Schilling chalice . the bomber black wax coating be amazing with a " ponytail " in the back   two finger dense brown foam cap , good retention , good lacing settle to a solid layer over a deep , dense dark cola liquid   Aroma be chocolate , molasse , licorice , char , whiff of smoky peat   taste be roast malt , char , dark chocolate   Mouthfeel be thick , velvety smooth , the char taste be mild and nicely coat the tongue . abv be invisible under this luxurious coating   great beer , repeatable

black in color with no penetration to light . there ’s a fingernail of brown around the rim and cover nearly all of the top . moderate lacing . the aroma be of smoke , roasted barley , molasse , and fig . pick up a 750 ml bottle from the Craft Beer Quick stop 5 - 27 - 20 for $ 22.99 . bottle on 9 - 26 - 19 , consume 7 - 24 - 20 .   Beer pour black with a very nice tan head that have some good hang time .   Nose be very good , full of medium to heavy roasted malt , a touch of coffee , and a touch of dark fruit .   taste be a huge malt base that lend a prevalent cherry profile , some licorice and a hint of coffee that be really well balanced by what I would imagine a ton of alpha hop . finish with a nice touch of heat that could easily miscast this brew as barrel aged .   Mouthfeel be very full and very satisfying , the way impy stout should be !   overall I have always see this as an over - hype old guard brew but I be now convince this be the real deal ! give the high abv and the nice warmth it seem barrel aging be not need but I do look forward to the BA version of this !

look ...... super thick come out of the 750 ml bottle - very dark black - 1 finger head that dissipate quickly - foam ring continue on - reddish hue in the glass - no light get through this one   Smell ...... rich caramel and burn sugar - some prune and tobacco - molasse and chocolate - slight hop presence with some floral and pine   taste ...... wow ! ! ! ! - super rich caramel - chocolate and coffee - burn wood - char grain - a bitter bite from the dark roasted item and hop - super powerful and a bit boozy - molasse and sweet syrup come in - really rich , earthy , and woodsy   feel ...... very thick and full bodied - low carbonation - still active - oily and syrupy   overall ...... this be an amazing beer - close to the good RIS I 've ever have - so rich and complex - I should always have one of these on hand for special occasion - ca n't go wrong with this one - Surly be become one of my favorite brewery in the country

pour pitch black with a tan foamy head . not a great deal of head retention , but , what be there stay around . nose have lot of booze with vanilla smoke wood char and chocolate . taste be boozy , chocolaty delight with some roast , raisin or dark fruit and have an edge to it . smooth velvety thick feel . take 5 year + on this site to finally try it and glad I do .

share this with a friend on my back porch as evening descend on Little Rhody . pour pitch black with a beautiful head of tight - bubble foam which dissipate after a few sip ... aroma be quite pronounce , little creamy and a lot of roastiness . nice so far !   taste be very roasty with some note of dark fruit and slight sweetness that never overpower . mouthfeel could not be more perfect - this be carbe just right and despite the 12 % ABV it do not coat the mouth and never becomes cloy or sticky sweet .   overall a very enjoyable heavy - hit stout , so glad I get to try this !

black with tan head . mild chocolate on top of malt with toffee , dark dry fruit , and a decent helping of American / citrus / pine / grass hop character . not too sweet , not too bitter , with a luscious mouthfeel .

2019 Version ( bottle 09/04/19 )   opaque ebony body top with an exquisite dense and creamy light tan head ; dense and sticky ring of foam descend the glass . gentle aroma of milk chocolate and vanilla . an immensely pleasing taste of cocoa and bitter chocolate ; somewhat nutty ; caramel and honey ; dully sweet with an undercurrent of bourbon . heavy , soft and billowy ; marshmallow mouthfeel ; dense with residual sugar body ; smooth velvet ; some alcohol warmth .   near perfect visual appeal , a rich yet subtle aroma , and an incredibly balanced and flavorful taste with an unforgettably thick and creamy body -- that sum up this beer . a most heavenly russian imperial stout . Hell , an exquisite stout no matter what the style !

I 've be wait a long time for a chance at Darkness . I finally pick up a bottle this summer in Durango Colorado , of all place . I suppose I could sit on it for a while , but it seem like the perfect beer for a dark December night in rainy Seattle .   it be dark , oh yeah . there be a good tan head , but it do n't last long . the taste / smell be notable first for what be not there . there be no bourbon , no chocolate , no coconut , in fact there be no sweetness at all . in an era of tarte up over sweet stout ( hello , CBS ) , darkness be refreshingly basic ... it be a very fine mix of roasted malt and hop . now the roasted malt do have some dry cocoa flavor , but this be not like drink a Hershey bar . I get dark fruit ( raisin , sort of ) , but again it be not sweet . there be a hefty dose of hop that give the beer a kick . the 12 % ABV be somehow hide .   I have the 2018 vintage . by the way , this do remind I of Old Rasputin .

January 1st , 2016 - also kick off 2016 be a beer from almost a decade ago : the 2007 Cantillon Lou Pepe . our assumption be that this be perhaps a little long in the tooth , even for a mythically legendary beer like this , but I have high hope and great trust in the belgian craftsman who have hone this recipe through generation . and it seem that my trust be well allocate , because the smell be absolutely beautiful . chocolate , cream and with a slight fruity sweetness , even the few ounce at the bottom of my glass unfurl up and out and indulge my olfactory with incredible grace and strength . but the taste be spicy , and while it borrow some of the chocolate from the nose , it express more like a mole with that kick . absolutely fascinating , and delicious , this have age quite wonderfully .

pungently funky with very light fruit note . vintage 2013 . pour quite surprisingly clear , pale pink - orange . taste note be quite light , carbonation be much like champagne .   not exactly the revelation that I have expect , but it be still quite good . still try to land myself a framboise - very excited about that beer .

2009 Sticker Cork seem to have dry out , when I open the bottle some of the beer be on the inside of the cap , the cork be all wet .   Orange color with a white head that diminish quite fast ( I guess because of the open air cork ? ) this be exactly what you want to smell from a gueuze , huge array of complexity right up your nose , funk , slight acetic acid , lactic acid . one of the deep layer flavor I 've ever have in a Gueuze , so much go in there but at the same time so mellow ! this bottle be a real treat !   we can see how Cantillon move up their game with their Lou Pepe series !

Mouthfeel be thin and effervescent .   overall , this be like the regular Gueuze on steroid . so deep and complex , but still not overwhelming . a masterpiece .

bottle at Akkurat in Stockholm . I think this be a 2011 Akkurat blend . so perfectly balanced - not too sour and not too funky . the Lou Pepe be really a step above the standard Cantillon release and that be really say something .

have this at Hill Farmstead last week . amazing funk note on this . super perfect gueuze , the funk be awesome and sour . look great . pour perfect . the taste be even well than the smell . this be the 2013 lpg .

sparkle gold , off - white collar . not a gueuze guy , I rate this below Lou Pepe 's average . but if ever dryness could coexist with full flavor , it be in this 2013 vintage . never will I pay $ 40 again for a 1/2 bottle of beer ... albeit a bomber I share . but Lou Pepe be on the " 1001 " list and this bottle push I over the top of my 502 goal ... so I guess the value have be rationalize .

a 750ml bottle at Nüetnigenough . 2013 sticker , bottle on 27th April 2015 . pour into a Cantillon tasting glass .   appearance : it pour a clear golden colour with a one finger white head that dissipate fairly quickly and leave some sparse lacing .   aroma : Apple , floral , lemon , hay , grass , barnyard with a touch of light funk .   taste : quite similar to the aroma with apple , lemon , grass , hay , floral , sour , light vinegar and funk . having have all Armand'4 last week , plus various other 3f goody , I be curious how I would feel about a 2010 lpg this week .   look beautiful clear and gold , pour with moderate carb and a bit of head . smell like tart Cantillon , rather sweet and a bit fruity . taste follow suit . delicious tartness , a bit more tart than apple cider . perhaps some wine barrel . pour a hazy golden color . Aroma be tart and funky . flavor be smooth gueuze tartness with a smooth acidic finish . taste like it as a little fruit in it . feel be excellent , very velvety . overall delicious .

2011 sticker . pour from a 750ml bottle into a Cantillon stem tulip glass . acquire in a trade .   pour a dark orange , pumpkin colored body with a big white head that reduce fairly quickly but leave a nice layer or retention and some lacing .   decant and allow to warm .. aroma of oak , funk , barnyard , hay , cedar , citrus , lactic .. aroma be potent and waft through the room , much more invite than regular gueuze , definitely more wood character !   taste be fantastic , upfront a light tartness with heavy oak , quite woody , citrus and ton of funk all mingle together , mustyness on the follow through , finish dry and funky . so delicious . medium - low carbonation , easy drinker , medium light body .   the increase wood and oak character of this really put it ahead of regular gueuze and honestly all other gueuze I 've have in the past . truly world - class .

so I be go to blend the score here . aged lpg and fresh lpg be two different animal . this be comparison of a 2010 sticker vs. a 2007 sticker . have the 2010 on 12/21/15 and then 2007 on 1/1/16 .   2010 l : look like carbonate apple juice . copper / amber hue with plenty of carb . 4.5 . 2007 l : look like carbonate apple cider . incredibly murky . 5 .   2010 s : a bit more mild than I expect . close to regular gueuze but a bit more unique . some apple , mild vinegar . that clean Cantillon funk , but a little dirtyness . 4.5 2007 s : wow , that be mouthwatere . Granny Smith apple , plenty of dirty funk , but more lemony and lactic forward . 5 .   2010 t : same as the nose . mild apple , vinegar , slightly soapy fresh Cantillon funk with a bit of dirt . 4.25 . 2007 t : same as the nose ! very apple cider like , ton of lactic mouth watering pucker , lemon , nice funk but a bit behind the lemon apple quality . 4.75 .   2010 : F : Fine , a bit thin like fresh Cantillon gueuze usually be . 4.25 . 2007 f : Awesome . creamy and thick , little bit low carb but so mouthwatering . more like a 4.9 .   2010 o : great gueuze , but not a big enough step up from the regular to justify the price . 4.25 . 2007 o : one of my favorite bottle of gueuze ever . the extra few year of aging really make a huge difference . or maybe it be just well back then , who know . worth the hype here . 5 .   so yeah , if you go for a bottle of lpg , plan on age it for at least 5 year , or grab a bottle that be already at least 5 year old . this one be about 6 year when we open it . it make a huge difference .

pour a bright and hazy yellow . a finger of soapy white head . solid retention , some lacing . a dense haze lead to minimal light penetration .   Nose be sweet peach , citrus , grass , melon and grapefruit . melon along the line of honeydew and cantaloupe . very nice cornucopia of fruit . nice sweetness with a good balance of grassy hop presence .   taste be similar . Peach , citrus , and melon , and a relatively strong weed dankness that be n't as present on the nose . also it could just be a phantom effect but I get brief moment of raspberry . medium bitterness , almost reach something on the high side of what you 'd expect on a NEIPA . mild to medium hop burn as you drink , build on the back of the throat . very mild cracker malt backbone . barely show up and be overwhelm by the fruit , weed , and grass presence .   Mouthfeel be medium to full - bodied for a NEIPA . mild carbonation . the hop bitterness and alcohol level , make this brew feel a little more harsh and bubbly than it actually be .   overall an enjoyable NEIPA . this one be a big boy . Juicy , sweet , and dank . I personally prefer Cutting Tiles , but there be still many trillium ipa to try and I look forward to future entry into this brewery .
