pour from a can date 2 day ago ( fresh ! ) into a tulip glass . pour an opaque pale orange / yellow color ( like white grapefruit juice ) with a pretty aggressive head with decent retention . scent of sweet tropical punch and candy . I ’ve be on a hazy dipa kick this summer , so a lot of they blend together but this one definitely have some unique note come through . the description by trillium say pink starburst , and I ’m definitely get some of that- really candy like fruity flavor . I ’m also get some bitter citrus and sweet tropical fruit . linger bitterness from hop oil on the palate . I have to say this one sneak up on you at 9+% because you do n’t even notice it . so many beer at that level have a very obvious alcohol burn and taste but this one be totally smooth for that ABV . my first time try heavy mettle ( I ’ve have one in the alloy series and death mettle ) and I think this one be my fav of the bunch . may not be your bag if you do n’t like the sweetness that this recipe invoke , but I ’m definitely dig it .

pint can - date 10/11/19 - pour into an RC IPA glass at 46f.   pour a turbid , nearly milky , delightfully glow pale orange hue , top with a very short head that quickly recede to a thin film and collar . a small swirl deposit some scant lacing along the glass .   Nose : the aroma be burst with ripe , succulent citrus aromas - orange juice , pomello , and grapefruit - along with a big bouquet of ripe tropical and stone fruit . lot of mango , some guava , pineapple , and a hint of papaya , with secondary note of kiwifruit , strawberry , blueberry , coconut , lychee , peach , nectarine , and a remarkably sweet , exotic fruity element that I simply can not place . the aroma be completely saturate , sweet , and fruity , and bear no earthy , musty , or funky component .   palate : the beer greet the palate with a forceful , sugary sweetness , which be to be expect from a dry - hop beer of this calibre . it be n't a starchy , malty sweetness , but rather a concentrated fructose sweetness , like ripe tropical fruit . speak of ripe tropical fruit , the flavour be burst with ripe mango , pineapple , papaya , and overripe peach , the latter be very indicative of the Galaxy hop that be cram into this . there be some bright , juicy , slightly acidic note of orange juice and grapefruit , which highly compliment the pineapple note , and also help to cut through some of the sweetness . much of this acidity be presumably hop burn , though it be restrain enough to be enjoyable , add a layer of complexity rather than be detrimental to the beer itself . there be just a touch of earthy dankness which be also to be expect from a bill contain any amount of Galaxy . I suspect the grist contain a measurable amount of oat , as the malt be clean , fairly neutral , and possess practically zero graininess . the finish be quite fruity and floral , before the sweetness gently subside , allow just a touch of resinous bitterness to peek through at the very end , before lift off , leave a clean , oaty dryness and a whisper of peach linger .   Mouthfeel / body : it be a big , bold , dry hop New England double IPA clock in at 9.3 % ABV , and it be from trillium . anyone who have have a big trillium IPA can image that this beer be just one massively fluffy hoppy pillow . the beer be soft , fluffy , creamy , and velvety smooth , yet still possess enough effervescence to lend texture and cut through some of the heft . nevertheless , this be a very stout beer , and be by no means a midday summer refresher . while the flavour profile would allow this to pair nicely with food , I think the sheer weight of it may prevent it from be the ideal mean accompaniment . also bear in mind that aside from the heft of this beer , it show little - to - no evidence of it be ABV , which could make this a dangerous little creeper .   overall : for what this beer be , it be hard to find much , if anything wrong with it . it be a wonderfully fruity , sweet , succulent double ( verge on triple ) IPA craft with the trademark uniqueness that have make trillium a cult classic . it embody everything the brewery be know for , from its top - tier hop , to the pillowy mouthfeel , all pack into a whopper of a beer , that be easy and enjoyable to drink . a true hoppy cornerstone of the Trillium lineup .

one of the good NE ipa I ’ve have from trillium . a real bench mark for the style . nice thick orange body . big white head . Smell be pineapple and mango juice . flavor follow with a sweet yet dry finish . allow you to keep come back . juicy as hell . thick but crushable . do all of the right thing for the style .

Dank , pithy , and strong , ton of melon , cantaloupe , and kiwi come through as this warm up but it be never easygoing enough for I to fully embrace . this have a creaminess and slickness to it that save it from be a disappointment but it need more sugar and tangerine from feel too heavy , as the carbonation be nearly nowhere to be find ...   no doubt that this have enough alcohol to it and it seem to complement the subtle hop burn quite well . that be n't what I be look for as this beer put the " heavy " into heavy mettle . ton of Galaxy hops ensure that this would be a dank hop bomb but in the end , this need it be rough edge round out a bit . worth a go for those who love trillium but this do n't match up with their well , and more popular offering ...

10/15/18 batch , update rating and review ... .my prior rating be 4.7 , this be the first trillium beer I ever have and it open my eye to the unique flavor that hop can impart on a beer .   what a disappointment ... a formerly magical and uniquely flavorful beer be now a heavy , overly sweet and muddle mess   look be dark .. pour yield very little head , a small ring remain   Smell : surprisingly mute , very little tropical or juicy characteristic .. I almost get a rotten citrus smell   Taste- at once sticky sweet ( which this beer never be before , despite its high abv ) and bitter . with this hop combo I expect that classic trillium magic ( and I could allow for a bit of hop burn ) , but this be just sharp , bitter and unpleasant to drink . no single fruit characteristic come to mind- it feel like a huge mouthful of extra sweet jolly rancher mix with garlic clove .. it taste thick , chewy and muddle — galaxy and Columbus hop flavor be completely bury   feel : harsh , mouth - coat unpleasantness ; surprisingly thin for such a high abv .   if this be a result of the new fermentation profile , this be a major disappointment and have confirm that trillium beer be no long for I .   never think I would have such a strong opinion about a beer

from a 16 oz can , date 10/15/18 . serve in a trillium - brand tulip . # properglassware   pour a massively murky glass of OJ with a scant finger of soft , creamy head . retention be no well than so - so , leave a pretty , creamy collar and a thin curtain of lacing .   robust nose of pineapple , weed and sexy , sweaty girl .   taste be massively dank and weedy , sort of a cross between ditchwater and bhang water . wow . give I a second here . ok . super - juicy with overripe pineapple , orange rind , sweet , sticky , dripping peach , composty melon , guava , lime and macerate ditch weed steep in sexy sweat . a little compost - melon - rind - sour - booziness linger on the palate and in the sinus at the finish .   feel be thick and juicy , verge on sticky / syrupy , medium - hefty bodied and well carbonate . drink like a mix - drink cocktail like they might serve you at brunch with a bamboo umbrella and a maraschino cherry .   whew . sample a cold 16 oz can pour into my snifter . the beer pour a hazy orange color with creamy bleach white head of 1 cm foam up and fade to a sturdy surface layer soon after the pour be complete . the aroma be the expect citrusy note of orange and some grapefruit , with also some fresh cut grass and a bit of pine sap and resin . I get just a little bit of biscuity malt bury in the beer and the high ABV be pretty well hide on the nose . the first sip reveal a silky texture with very fine and prickly carbonation . the beer dry out intensely on the swallow , but before that I experience a wide range of hop characteristic . I get orange peel and grapefruit rind with some pine sap and again the fresh grass , ( especially on the burp ) . there be a bit of sweetness , but not from malt , more the citrusy fruit note . I get a bit of peppery alcohol bite on the swallow along with some warming in my belly , but this beer could be consume quickly , which make it a little dangerous at 9.3 % . quite a nice double NEIPA , I m glad I got to try this one and would do it again if try to fulfill my hop need some night .

pour to a teku glass .   a : the body be yellow , bright , opaque and hazy with a matte finish . the head be white but show medium to weak retention and no lacing . s : the aroma be very rich on grapefruit , pineapple , resinous profile and citric end . alcohol be just a bit too noticeable . t : taste start off with a citric and grapefruit flavour that evolve to a pineapple - y fusion that finish off the presentation with a big resinous profile . in the back , a big hoppy , Mosaic and Galaxy ? like . m : body be medium to high . carbonation be good . alcohol be noticeable but not huge . bitterness be also high . o : overall , very aromatic dipa . trillium - good DIPA .

Everett from Hill Farmstead Brewing . receive in early June 2021 in Ninja box from @Roy_Hobbs . 16 oz can store at home at 42 degree . review 1/7/21 . note that I use DD / MM / YY protocol . bottom rim stamp " CANNED 05/18/21 DRINK by 09/18/21 " . serve at 53.0 degree in a hand wash and dry Jester King snifter . final temperature 60.6 degree . appearance – 4.5 . first pour – Amber Brown ( SRM 18 ) , clear . body – Black ( SRM 40 ) , opaque . when rear - lite , opaque but translucent amber brown at the edge . head – large ( Maximum 5.5 cm , aggressive center pour ) , wheat , high density initially but quickly opening , average retention , diminish to leave a 0.7 to 1.0 cm lacy crown and a thin complete cap . an archipelago of foam island resemble coral atoll remain on the side of the glass above the crown . second pour produce a dense 0.7 cm head . lacing – Fair . wide band of tiny bubble , separate into two band , with short , blunt , stalactite . see also above . aroma – 4.25 – begin with roasted malt and cocoa , no hop , no yeast , no coffee . flavor – 4.25 – begin slightly sweet with roasted malt and cocoa and a hint of coffee , no hop , no yeast . no ethanol ( 7 % ABV , as mark on container ) taste or aroma . slight gastric warming do occur . no dimethylsulfide or diacetyl . end slightly bitter . palate – 4 – medium , creamy , soft carbonation . final impression and summation : 4.25 very velvety mouthfeel . the first few swallow go from slightly sweet to very bitter with alarm swiftness , but then it seem to smooth out , just end slightly bitter in counterpoint to the initial sweetness . predominant taste and odor be roasted malt and cocoa , with just a hint of a smoky coffee on the tongue . in total , particularly good porter .

I receive a can of this famous Porter from @roy_hobb . can on 5/18/2021 . pour at 59 ° into a Willi Becher pint glass . it pour nearly black with very dark cola hue at the bottom of the glass when hold to the light , with a large , fluffy , medium khaki - colored have and thick creamy lacing . it be a beautiful pour . its fragrant nose feature dark chocolate , cigar smoke , burn coffee ground and char nut . wow , the taste be amazing ! the initial chocolate malt sweetness be juxtapose to acidic coffee ( like it be from a Jersey diner ) , and bitter , earthy , nutty char . there be also strong tobacco . the blend and balance of flavor be exquisite . the mouth feel be rich and creamy - almost stout - like - with mild carbonation , and the 7 % ABV seem perfect . Everett be highly drinkable but with excellent substance . this Porter be big and flavorful enough to pair with a fine meal of roasted red meat but you could easily drink a couple of pour casually . Everett 's 100 score be well - deserve . it be as good an American Porter as you 'll have the great pleasure of drinking .

from a growler fill at Monk 's Cafe in Philadelphia , pour immediately into a tulip glass . Overall- my favorite beer . ever . hand down . just ... unreal blend of flavor and roast profile everything be simply astonishing .

the roast profile on this beer be almost unbelievable before even consider it be limit at 7.2 % abv . bittersweet chocolate , city dark roast coffee ground , and charcoal suggest a grittiness that swirl within a medium - full body that never cloy nor remove focus from the flavor . tough to tell where roast end and hop begin , both give tremendous depth of flavor .   I be most impressed with the light smoke / kindle character that come through subtly on the finish , almost just an olfactory sensation . it really take the roast flavor and overall experience over the top . in the style , I 've have nothing that come close
smell of chocholate with some coffee flavor . this beer be definitely bitter and embody the true porter feeling . it be not sweet at all . robust , and a good portrayal of this style .

yeah , this be my first HF beer . after try it , I must admit that I understand why people consider HF the good brewery in the world . here go :    a : Pitch black ; huge , white head that linger . the head leave great lacing . against the snowy backdrop , the beer certainly look spectacular .   s : absolutely perfect . ton of chocolate ; milk - chocolate and dark - chocolate sweetness ; surprised if the beer do n't contain any lactose . burn malt give the smell a coffee profile , too . absolutely stunning .   t : follow the nose perfectly . this be an awesome beer . remarkable that a beer can be so rich without be boozy . can tell that a lot of effort be put into make it .   f : Thick and creamy . extremely rich .   o : wonderful .

look : very dark black color with a small amount of dark tan head . decent lacing .   Smell : get a ton of chocolate malt and coffee , follow by the slight hint of vanilla and some dark fruit note .   taste : Coffee be big and dominant when cold . as it warm the more chocolate taste there be and a decent amount of vanilla flavor .   feel : this have a thick and creamy mouthfeel , with a very nice dry finish   overall : this be just an excellent porter and I be love this beer .

a : pour pitch black with a mocha colored head . Head be quite creamy look with decent retention . average lacing . good looking but nothing special .   s : well , this smell like a very traditional but intense porter . there be chocolate malt , coffee note ( but not espresso ) , leather , pecan , vanilla and some very light cherry . this a dark , round and complex smell porter .   t : if the smell make I think of coffee without be espresso , the taste really put the espresso right in the front and center . there be cacao powder , vanilla , leather , cherry ( much strong than in the smell ) , oak like tannin , pecan and a little bit of earth . the balance be wonderful and with very little residual sweetness .   M : I 've never have a Hill Farmstead beer that have n't a perfect mouthfeel for the genre . this be the case here too : it be broad and round , heavy ( but not too much ) with a low and soft carbonation .   o : this truly be a wonderful beer from an incredible brewery that do n't seem to know how to brew a bad beer . the only thing I can say about this beer , and I think it be the first time I say it , be that it would benefit to have a little bit more sweetness . not a lot , just a little bit . also , with it be predominant espresso note , this beer really sit in between a stout and a porter .

Classic New England IPA look with that yellow gold color and a massive 2 finger off white head that fade slowly and leave really nice spotty lacing . trillium IPA 's keep the look at the high standard .   smell super dank with fresh weed , orange peel , tangerine , guava , fresh pineapple , mango , wet citrus hop , floral note , very light peppery spice , sweet malt , caramel and gummy bear . not the most balanced brew , but super juicy smelling .   taste as good as it smell with everything list in the description above plus grapefruit , lemon , Razzles candy , faint piney note , orange juice and fresh cut grass . the same dank quality from the nose come through with the flavor and add nice complexity .

yeah , my can of this be old - really old ( 7/21/16 ) but this be a classic and I vow to have it , along with everything else in my basement , before it burst or break . even though this be quite a bit of a malt bomb when I open it , it be n't bad and be still enjoyable to a large extent . very little sediment be pour out as well , which make the experience that much well !   not a bad pour to this as the liquid be a muted peach with a ton of cloudiness to it . the head be sufficient and there be a bit of lacing here and there after the thin collar at the top , but it be n't terribly thick or bright . not a lot of pine in the nose but there be enough orange , tangerine , and cream in the nose to keep this soft . the clementine and rind come through in the taste along with a citrus sweetness that make this quite soft and easy to drink . a mild dank hop presence come through in the aftertaste and it be no secret that this feel like a malt bomb , give how much be in here . load of wheat give this body as this be not terribly juicy nor dry from start to finish ...   just the right amount of alcohol be present too , as I feel a bit of warming but not enough to serve as a deterrent . this be a nice beer that have everything in proportion and be quite easy to quaff . I have no idea who Paul and Jess be but if they have this at their wedding , it would have be a great choice !

very solid smooth IPA . contain australian galaxy hop with peach Clementine fruit and pine . did n’t think it be amazing compare to other offering like DDH fort point but solid .

GREEEEAT Notion . love love love the PNW and GN . this be one of their good beer and every year we get the Double Stack . funny we get this in a four pack of can on drop day because we ca n't sit and have it on tap ( soooo good on tap ) . on the drive home with the four pack sit on my back seat I look at Bren and ask " can you smell maple ? I like coffee and beer so its the good of both world ... lol   cheer everyone !

BEST part of WAKING up 050619 stamp by rim . pour into a snifter .   a : black with 1 - 2 finger dark beige head with good retention and sparse lace .   s : unbelievably uncanny aroma of pancake with butter and syrup with black coffee more present with warming .   t : the flavor be unfortunately hamper by a strong bitter burn coffee note and then extract - chemical character in the finish and aftertaste . the maple be strong early and then fade . the background stout also do n't come through much . disappointing give the unbelievable aroma .   m : hide the 11 % well with smoothness but slight extract tang in the finish   o : Double Stack have good point and bad point . I have no idea when I trade for this how highly rate it be on here . sure , it be an American Imperial Stout with all the booze and heft that one would expect , but this be so tasty and wonderful that I do n't even notice how strong it be until I look at the label . yeah , this be a beast * but * it be n't just because of the booze as this have enough behind it to back up it be overt heft . of course , I think that be a wonderful thing !   of course , this have a dark brown pour to it with a thin , mocha head that do n't last long . the lacing leave behind be thin and scatter as much of the soapy bubble slide down the side of my pint glass after every sip . ton of maple syrup , molasse , and rich coffee in the slightly mute nose but good Lord , everything be amplify a few notch once I take a sip of this . really , really impressed with how this feel as the thickness , sugary sweetness , and roasted note come through in the taste . lip - smackingly wonderful as even my hand smell like fresh maple syrup once I put my glass down . if my breakfast at IHOP could be ferment and make to last for the duration , this would be the end result as I could almost taste the syrup that I pour on my pancake , as I work my way through this .   sure , this be strong and it feel every bit of the 11 % ABV that it be from the first sip down to the last one . when you have a beer that feel like pancake batter , berry compote , and fresh roasted joe all roll into one , you do n't forget it soon and that be the case with this offering from Great Notion . slightly roasted , reminiscent of sarsaparilla , and slick like something fresh brew , this beer be truly one of a kind . canned : 09/06/2019 pour : 01/16/2020   a : Pitch black , absolutely no light be get through this one . pour create about a quarter to half a finger of light tan head that dissipate relatively quick .   s : oh man , the second you open this can the immediate area around you be consume with maple and coffee . this may be the good smell stout I have ever have . there be a slight bitterness once you really stick your face in for a smell , but for the most part you can tell this be a maple bomb .   t : you be initially hit with a strong roasted coffee flavor that have a nice chocolate malt backbone to it . this evolve into a subtle maple sweetness that compliment the underlie bitterness well . I personally could have do for a tiny bit more maple that align close to what I get on the nose , but you do get a wonderful maple aftertaste though !   f : the beer nicely coat your mouth with a thickness that be pleasant without be too sticky . this be about what I would expect from a stout of this size . I could do with a tad creamy mouthfeel , but perhaps I be just drink too many barrel aged stout .   o : I really love this beer . it give the impression of be just a sugary maple overload , but the coffee and chocolate malt make it a very well balanced and enjoyable beer . while it be a pretty big beer at 11 % , it encapsulate it so well you would n't even know . every Summer , I make this frustrating mistake of think that I ’m actually go to spend the entirety of the three four high climate month crush can after can of refresh Pale ale or ipa . this misconception usually result in I do something stupid like buy multiple four pack of the same beer think that the hot weather will help I power through the beer , and make they feel enjoyable all at the same time , while completely discount such variable as ( 1 ) the fact that the human appetite decrease during warm season ; ( 2 ) my taste bud seem to get burn out from hop a lot fast in the summer ; and , ( 3 ) regardless of the season , I ’m usually too tired to drink a large quantity of beer after work , so I tend to reach for the high ABV beer than the low .   so until those three variable be somehow resolve internally , I usually find myself do the exact opposite of what I think I would normally be do in term of drink during the Summer month : instead of crush session ipa , wheat beer , and bretty saison , I end up fruitlessly try to solodome bomber of BA stout and pass out with over half the beer still leave in the glass ; or drink one 12 oz bottle of a high ABV stout and try to start another low ABV IPA and then pass out with over three - fourth of the beer still leave in the glass ; or actually finish two tall boy of an IPA , go to bed at like 12:30 am and wake up tired and hungover .   my idiosyncratic drinking habit form from my highly functional alcoholism aside , it seem like a single 16 oz can of a moderately high ABV stout be usually right around my happy spot of where I want to be when I ’m too tired to do anything productive yet not tired enough to go to sleep — lucky for I my favorite brewery have make the ingenious decision of can their most famous beer in tall boy format ; unlucky for I , it ’s so rich it ’s almost take I 5 week to finish a four - pack by myself .   when I hear that Mikerphone and Great Notion be brew beer together , I be kind of hope that their love child would be a cross between Smells like Bean Spirit and Double Stack , kind of like what EvilTwin do with Westbrook with Imperial Biscotti Mexican Cake Break , but with less spice and more maple . and much less sticky cloy sweetness toward the back . I think they end up put out some strawberry IPA which I do n’t try because well , strawberry and IPA be not two word I ever want to see in the same sentence , as well as an imperial stout with peanut butter and marshmallow because I think the bottle be only put out in Chicago , and it be only briefly on tap if ever . ⠀ ⠀ ⠀ ⠀ ⠀ ⠀ if you have n’t get the hint by I waste all this comment space while write absolutely nothing about the actual beer itself , it ’s because there ’ nothing really to write about this beer : it ’s coffee , maple syrup , pancake batter , and do . for posterity ’s sake , I will go on record and point out that the beer also contain minor note of whole grain pancake which contain half - assedly melt dark cacao chocolate chip , but maple and coffee definitely be the two incredibly bold takeaway from this beer , and for anyone to miss it they ’d have to absolutely no functional smell and taste receptor in their body at all . ⠀ ⠀ ⠀ ⠀ ⠀ ⠀ compare to previous batch however , the body have become a lot more enjoyable , and by that I mean that it feel less like syrup and more like 99 % humidity while be 102 outside on your skin / tongue . I ’ve either become more accustomed to bold , sweet flavor , or Great Notion have wisely dial down the pastrystout a little compare to their previous batch , so that even sugar averse sipper like myself can reach the bottom of the can , albeit very very slowly . ⠀ ⠀ ⠀ ⠀ ⠀ ⠀ I honestly do n’t know how I ’m go to finish the last remain can inside my fridge .

can date 8/30 ; well by 9/27 : love this beer originally two week ago , but these have on the good by date be n't jump out at I quite as much . I actually do not think it be because of age , just my palate be a little different when I do this review .   that aside , this be still a very good IPA , especially if I be patient enough to let it warm to the proper temperature from my cold fridge . the look be a quite highly hazed , near but not 100 % opaque . as with many HF beer , the head and lacing be pretty strong .   Nose be a mix of tangerine , grapefruit , and some form of sweet fruit - I want to say a little pineapple . there be a light herbal note that come somewhat as a muted mint to I , but be definitively a foreshadowing of some form of bitterness in the taste .   medium heft , maybe a little less , with a prickly carbonation bite through the soft edge . More citrus rind and fruit - tangerine , orange , and some sweet ruby grapefruit , with a little huskiness from the barley and/or other grain . not really any of the tropical fruit accent from the nose . the back end be bitter , but it have an interesting sheen of maltiness to it . bittersweet lean heavily on the first part , the latter keep thing from get out of hand . as expect , a well construct brew that bring both malt and hop to the experience .

pour a bright , completely opaque , orange color . thick , sudsy off white head form , then dissipate leave a quarter inch of foam in the glass along with plenty of sticky lacing . Aroma have note of tangerine , orange marmalade , grass , dry vegetation and a slight woody character to it .   taste follow the nose with note of citrus , orange , orange marmalade , and peach give way to a grassy , vegetal , woody hop character on the back end . clearly the Riwaka be come through on the back end . moderately bitter , mildly sweet , completely delicious . feel be moderately bodied , smooth , and pretty easy drinking . moderate carbonation .   this be a really nice IPA from Hill Farmstead - they get so much out of the hop both in the aroma and taste , its impressive .

enormous thank to Jake for this one !   Pint can - date 10/06/20 - pour into an ale tulip at 40 ° F .   Hill Farmstead - Susan   pour a beautiful apricot orange - quite cloudy , but some translucency near the top , and cap by a finger of eggshell white head with good retention , leave a tall collar as it recede .   Nose : orange . ton of orange . Grapefruit , pineapple , mango , apricot , some grass , and a rather unique herbal element . Dank , slightly earthy , even slightly savoury , like leek or some kind of wild ditchweed . planty . a good swirl reveal some lemon z , gooseberry , white grape , and a hint of passionfruit , with this flower petal botanical note underneath , all atop a clean , rustic pale malt base . quite expressive .   palate : much like the aroma , the flavour be unexpected , layer , and throw you for a loop . it greet the palate dry , with clean grainy malt , follow by nicely acidic squeeze of tangerine , grapefruit , and Meyer lemon . a good bit of pineapple , with some nectarine and ripe guava . it take a shift into Riwaka territory , with note of passionfruit , gooseberry , white grape , fresh cut grass , and a greeness , which manifest into bitterness - grassy , herbal , and leafy , and finish with a peppery bite .   mouthfeel / body : the beer be bright in every possible way . it be medium - bodied , but very crisp and fairly snappy . the signature Hill water minerality really elevate the sparkle feel , and the lively effervescence cotribute to that . there be a touch of softness , but not at the expense of fluidity . Dry , crisp , and refreshing .   overall : when you 've have a million ipa , sometimes , you focus more on the little thing , rather than the overall flavour . the overall flavour here be good , and it be an interesting combination of hop , which throw a couple of curveball , however , it be n't groundbreake . what make this beer great be not the flavour , but the little thing that come together . the perfect malt balance , the careful hop acidity , the minerality , and the flow of it all . its quality and heritage certainly show , and it be a great beer , if a little disjoint .

can on 10/6/20 ; consume on 10/12/20   pour a deeply haze , dark golden orange body top with a finger and a half of fluffy , white foam ; good retention yield a thin veil of cap , a creamy , moderate collar , and a vast array of soapy lacing drape along the wall of the glass .   Aroma open atop a grassy , flowery undertone , with a neutral earthiness guide to bright orange and subtle nectarine ; a lemony acidity amplifie over time , though a creamy texture fluff off in the distance for a naturally integrate sweetness to an soft bouquet dripping with citrus , catty tone , and flaky malt texture .   taste feature tart passionfruit in wave across the palate , accent with fresh grapefruit , musty grain , and crack peppercorn ; orange develop along the mid - palate , with a linger catty character alongside bright citrus fruit on the finish .   Mouthfeel bring a medium - light body with a fluffy , semi - creamy , moderate carbonation ; flaky malt form a pillowy crispness , become plush and effortless across the palate as a minor hoppy acidity build to a clean , semi - tart finish .   the expression of Simcoe here be beautifully temper , and though the hop profile as a whole do n't provide as much cohesion , Hill Farmstead 's signature refinement offer ample comfort ; this level character put the quality of this neipa construction at the forefront , bring attention from a more subdued profile to the overall easy enjoyment it impart throughout .

a classic from these guy that I be only finally get to drink now . it may have be a game changer when it first come out , but it certainly be nt anything new anymore . this balance of heavy dry hopping over a hazy base with some substance be now everywhere , and even the hop profile itself seem somewhat classic , more northwestern than southern hemisphere , but its the degree of refinement that have I blow away , which be more manifest in the mouthfeel than anywhere else in this now famous ipa . it be both expressively carbonate and bone dry , while also be drinkable but substantial , round medium body but fast finishing , the right element of the hop ling too , no vegetal bite or over bitter harshness . it do have some bitterness though , not all juice , and the grapefruity piney flavor , almost assuredly simcoe derive , do have some resolution , but its the between the line nuance of pineapple , papaya , and juniper that turn I on here . so alive from the tap , almost chuggable for what it be , probably ahead of its time when it be introduce , not decidedly in the middle of what s hot , but this be a quality league or two above just about everything else , include the other one the nerd all line up for and freak out about . from a flavor standpoint , its great but not revolutionary , but through the lens of quality , its as good as it get !

a : pour up a murky reddish grape hue , with a quickly recede , white , one finger head . s : immediate , cherry and note of funk and tannic oak . there be something here also that come off a bit like sugary cereal . t : surprisingly subdue , it be sour , but not brutally so , and the cherry be certainly there but I get some baking spice , what seem like cinnamon in the finish and definite ( although more subtle ) funk . there be also some other more subtle note of dark fruit and oaky tannin . m : surprisingly full , but still bone dry . o : this be an interesting beer , it be much more subtle , nuanced and complex than I be expect it to be . full disclosure , I ’m not a real kriek / Cherry sour fan , so I buy this on reputation alone and while I do n’t think my mind have be change about kriek , I do think this beer be more than the sum of its part and have some nice complexity to offer . I think the risk and often the temptation with a flavor as big and assertive as cherry be to let it do all the heavy lifting because it tend to be such a people pleaser on its own . fruit sour beer have never be my thing and it ’s still not , but I will say that if more these beer handle their subject with the grace and restraint on display here , I would be more inclined to buy they .

unbelievably huge thank to Anthony for this massive want of mine . very excited .   500ml bottle - b6 ( Feb. ' 19 ) pour into a fancy tulip at 48 ° F .   pour an almost unbelievable glowing ruby red - I be talk the Sorcerer 's Stone red . highly polished , highly reflective , mesmerise to stare at glow ruby gemstone red - clear , but not crystal . a finger of quick , loose , just - slightly - pink head build up , and then quickly reduce to a thin soapy collar . some slow effervescence can be see .   Nose : there be average cherry wild ale , and there be cherry wild ale that you can just tell be something incredible by the aroma . this be in the latter category . the amount of cherry on the nose be borderline unreal and saturated , while be entirely organic in nature . not only be this a cherry bomb aroma , but what be really impressive be how both the Montmorency and the Balaton cherry seem to translate . there be some intensely sweet , ripe , juicy Balaton character , lend an almost maraschino cherry on top of a maraschino liqueur note , burst with big , deep , dark cherry juice , while the Montmorency cherry lend that floral , fresh , tangy cherry note , with a touch of stem , pit , and even cherry blossom . there be also a healthy amount of oak , and , along with the cherry , seem to lend this subtle cinnamon spice note , with just a whisper of oaky vanillin . there be a suggestion of acidity , but it do n't singe the nose when inhale , and there be very little earthy or barnyard funk . just some wet oak , leather , old parchment , dusty attic , and a hint of brett . the cherry obscure any real serious funk or acidity that may lie beneath . there be a touch of gently toasty grain beneath everything , which be the icing on the cake .   palate : first thing , from the very first sip , it be n't brace sourness that hit , it be n't tannic oak , it be n't malt , it be sweet and tart ripe cherry flesh . the deep , bold Balaton sweetness greet the palate , give up its sweet juicy goodness , while never come across as artificial , cough syrupy , sticky , or overly sweet . this sweet cherry juice flavour unfurl to eventually reveal the Montmorency character beneath . the Montmorency be not quite as deep , bold , and saturate with juicy sweetness , but it provide a slightly less ripe , slightly fruity character , that bring japanese cherry blossom , a bit of plum , a hint of cherry potpourri , cinnamon / amburana wood spice , and a bright , natural , almost slightly unripe cherry tartness to the table . in addition to this subtle fruity tartness , the acidity lend a near - perfect degree of sour . it really be n't brace , puckering , or blind in any way . make no mistake , this be a sour ale , no question about it , but it be n't Midwest sour . there be some lemony lacto pucker , a bit less of some acetic pedio bite , and a bit more of some tart , funky , mineralic brett , lend not quite salinity , and definitely not sweat , but that classic restrained brett tang , along with some musty wet wood , a little hint of bandaid , and that classic bretty stone fruit pit note . the high degree of minerality pair with the bandaid note and the deep cherry really give this a little hint of a Kriek vibe . the tartness have a quick downward curve , allow some really wonderful oak to appear before the finish , pair with a hint of vanilla , a hint of baking spice , a hint of caramel , and a hint of brown sugar . the sourness take a far back seat , reveal some more dusty brett , and then finally , the ever - so - slightly sweet toasted grain base reveal itself , with a wonderful melding of grainy wheat and round malty barley , cereal grain , essence of cherry , and gently tannic oak linger on and conclude the finish .   Mouthfeel / body : MvB be light , crisp , and snappy by nature , though the mild to moderate cherry sweetness and slight bit of malt body push this a bit close to medium - bodied territory . effervescence be surprisingly low . it be n't flat , but rather lazy and slow . one might expect this to be a super fizzy , champagne - like experience , but that be not the case , which also contribute to a slightly full feel . soft , round , and even quite juicy upfront , the ale be not scrub , and even feel somewhat smooth . the oak in the finish provide some tannicdrying as the sweetness fade , but the ale itself be n't tannic or ultra - dry .   overall : this be a really remarkable cherry wild ale , and an absolute triumph from Jester King . the perceivable difference between the Montmorency and Balaton cherry be a work of art , and the structure , balance , and progression of the ale be nothing short of impressive . the acidity be forward , but keep in check , the sweetness make a statement up front , and then take a support role , the oak and microflora influence walk a tightrope right down the middle of balanced , and the subtle malty , grainy base beneath it all be something that I always look for , but rarely get in highly acidic ale . this be just absolutely world class .

product_name: Bourbon Barrel Aged Dark Star: Coffee Edition
product_review: cellared bottle . black with brown shading , edge , and cap . the coffee take this to the next level in both smell and taste . product_name: Bourbon Barrel Aged Dark Star: Coffee Edition
product_review: appearance -The beer be silky black in appearance with a slight head of off - white bubble . product_review: 2017 bottle drink out of a tulip on 04.04.20   pour thick and dark with a nice cream color half inch head , some of which linger around the edge of the glass for the remainder of the pour . I could n't get much aroma but it be just not a strong suit of mine - I be sure it be there . taste be dominate by strong dark coffee . as it warm , the barrel note really come out and I really enjoy it ; the sweetness be nuance and perhaps hide in the bitterness such that it be n't so much in your face as you typically get in so many of today 's pastry stout so this be a nice change . I do n't get much of the typical oatmeal stout flavor , but that also might have be mask in the roadty coffee note and the barrel taste . as I write my review , I realize this be quite a complex beer but for I , it be rather two note - dark coffee and bourbon barrel . if that be what you want - this will hit the spot - and it hit the spot for I last night . if you can get the rest of the beauty , good on you , there be a lot here ! ( and I 've get a 2016 bottle age as well ! ) cheer !

product_name: Bourbon Barrel Aged Dark Star: Coffee Edition
product_review: very good oatmeal stout , solid and tasty but a little disappointing consider the high expectation I have for this one . it ’s suppose to be rank # 3 on BA but I find it a little uninspiring . 2017 edition print on bottle . pour a thick black opaque color with just a little film of tan head and minimal scant linger lacing . smell outstanding , great dark roast coffee , dark chocolate , caramel , vanilla , malt , toffee , bourbon , oak , nuttiness and a little raisin . taste follow the nose , but not quite as rich or flavorful as I be expect . almost like a flat regular coffee stout . lacked some depth and complexity . not as creamy or smooth as most oatmeal stout either , but still have a nice velvety mouthfeel with good carbonation . as the beer warm the alcohol become a little more noticeable , both in the aroma and taste . I enjoy this one but prefer the other beer from this series .

product_name: Bourbon Barrel Aged Dark Star: Coffee Edition
product_review: pour a bark brown almost black . thick and viscous look as it pour . Finger of dense khaki colored head . strong lace .   Nose be smooth warm bourbon . sit graciously rather aggressively . roasty coffee . rich , complex , detailed . nice malt profile as well . complimentary to everything else go on here . very relaxed brew . this brew know it be the most important one in the room and it do n't have to announce its dominance . the waft of alcohol come from the glass have no problem shout it be presence on the other hand .   taste follow the nose . Smooth , woody bourbon . nice sweetness mix with mild dark fruit note . big coffee provide a layer of bold , roasty bitterness . the coffee in this be very nice . something that be n't present on the nose be a little bit of chocolate .   Mouthfeel be fullbodie with mild carbonation . velvety smooth . I love the consistency of oatmeal stout . amazing stuff .    a lot of barrel aged stout be huge , bombastic thing . like Parabola or BCBS , you get the strong malt or barrel presence , which can be do well . but here , what Fremont do perfectly , be balance . delicate , nuanced , expertly craft precision . every flavor profile come through , not one loud than the other . it be no surprise that this sit just below Rusty Nail in term of top Oatmeal Stouts . Fremont have this style on lockdown .

product_review: pour coal black with a big , beige head , soon receede to a thick lace atop the glass .   smell of dry raisin , glaze caramel and layer of milk chocolate among spicy , old oak . got an additional coffee punch to it , bring toasted hazelnut and dry blueberry to the nose .   have a soft , smooth mouthfeel among a complex body , exhibit a long last booze dryness .   taste of charred malt , which bring chocolate cover coffee bean to the palate , offer a wooden note , which then bring the spicy barrel up . have a whip cream quality , soothe the warming , not yet bite oak barrel , create a pleasant , spicy peak among coffee and coal . finish heavier on the coffee and whip cream interplay with additional licorice and sweet caramel , ampe up by a long go alcohol glow .   very well balanced , smooth and decadent stout , feature a great , subtle coffee presence .

product_name: Bourbon Barrel Aged Dark Star: Coffee Edition
product_review: 2018 edition   beautiful beer , with excellent head production for the style ( more than a full finger ) , and very good retention as well ; 10 minute after the pour , there be still a thin layer of dark foam cover almost the entire top of the ebony body , and a fairly thick collar line the edge of the glass .   the nose be promising : initially sweet , with chocolate , brown sugar , toffee , red grape , cream , vanilla , coconut , and light bourbon mash , it quickly turn sharp and aggressive , with coffee , oak , and bourbon mash . this hit all the right note , and imply that one should expect the full weight of the 13.6 % ABV to fall upon the palate .   similarly and immediately aggressive on the palate , with bourbon and coffee lead the way . Caramel , coffee , and brown sugar at first ; strong bourbon mash follow , along with oak , red grape , and molasse ; very light char and nut ; a bit of booze , assertive but not harsh ; coconut and vanilla tone ; chocolate malt .   mouth - fill body with no fizz , and while the high ABV eventually build some sting , you can really savor this one for quite a while before the swallow , allow the flavor to really wash across your tongue and palate . surprisingly semi - dry finish , with mostly dull tone of oak and ground coffee linger in the aftertaste . Smooth , creamy , and thin ( not watery ) for the style , instead of thick and chewy .   shockingly strong fruity tone from the coffee here - berry and earth inimitable to certain coffee ( e.g. ethiopian Harrar , or certain south american roast ) ; I be not sure I 've ever notice this effect in a coffee stout before . although that be not my favorite kind of coffee roast , it be damn impressive nonetheless . it also last and last , with these tone of barrel and coffee linger for a good 5 - 10 minute after the sip .   this be not quite on the level of bcbcs , but it be definitely play the same game , on the same level .

product_review: 2018 release . receive from @woemad in a BIF box . pour into a pub glass . it pour a dark walnut with cola hue at the bottom of the glass . the creamy , medium mocha - color head fade slowly leave a thin film of lacing inside the glass . it be highly aromatic with roasted malt , oatmeal , bourbon , freshly - brew coffee , caramel , nuts , cocoa , tobacco , and earthy char . the taste open with note of both fresh and burn coffee , oats , baker chocolate , burn nut , leather , and char . as the glass breathe and warm , I be notice more caramel sweetness and just a hint of black cherry on the tip of the tongue . the bourbon be clearly evident but it do n't overpower the other flavor , which be nicely balanced and nuanced . despite the burn note there be surprisingly little bitterness at the finish . this Stout have a thick , creamy mouth feel with low / moderate carbonation . there be no escape the 13.6 % ABV , which be more than just warm . sip this one slowly . savor it because it be one of the good Oatmeal Stouts you 'll encounter . thank , @woemad for the chance to drink this exquisite Stout .

from the DC brewery . their first run of DDH Mylar Bags   4pk of 16 oz can . two beer consume 3/17/21 . can on 3/10/21 . 16 oz English pint glass . as with any oh beer I review , I be fortunate that I be review all of their beer from 3 day to 1 week after can .   in short , this be one of the good hazy ipa I have ever try . great job DC for live up to one of the most famous oh beer from Brooklyn .   a - cloudy , very hazy . straw - goldish overall hue skew towards peach and apricot in color . two - finger head upon pour quickly reduce to thin head that cling to glass all the way down . Lace be comprise of tight bubble .   S - Smell be 4.25 when first pour from refrigerator . get well after warm up a tad . tropical fruit , orange oil and a hint of spiciness on nose . pleasing , but not an indication of the flavor explosion to come .   T - Boom ! let this warm just a tad after remove from refrigerator . tropical fruit , very much mango forward , hit you in the kisser right away . almost overpower , if the flavor be n't encase in a smooth , velvet glove . after the initial mango surge , flavor transition into cantaloupe , watermelon rind and pink grapefruit oil .... especially pink grapefruit pith . the oily and slightly bitter grapefruit pith be both flavor and textural .... and ling in the mouth for over a minute after swallow . under all of this be a subtle mint note that glide under the more noticeable flavor , as well as just enough hop bitterness to create tension to the fruit flavor ...... and this quality elevate this beer over the total fruit bowl experience of DDH Broccoli imo .   F - Creamy and velvety smooth up front and quite oily ( express fruit rind ) on the finish , but never heavy . dangerously crushable at 8.50 % abv .   o - my favorite oh beer I have yet to try ( up to 28 ) . oh make a lot of very high quality beer , but this one in particular be both contemplative , very crushable and refreshing at the same time . all at 8.5 % abv . I be no beer expert and my palate be not as bless as many , but after well over 1,000 beer over 30 year of drinking craft beer , this be among the 25 or so good beer I have yet to try . a world class beer and something anyone should buy as soon as they see it . get it fresh !

Jet black with a dark brown head with good retention and lacing . the nose have a lot of dark chocolate , licorice , a little anise , soy , vanilla , a little booze and plum , a little tobacco . rich and deep .   the palate open moderately sweet , with plum , dark caramel , dark chocolate and some bourbon . dark honey , buckwheat honey and licorice follow , with an anise spiciness complement the bourbon note . while sweet , this be n't cloy , favor balance and structure instead ( but what do you expect ? ) . Fruit cake , dessert like and rich , but still approachable and also uncompromise . flavor of molasse , particularly the bitterness one find in treacle , temper the sweetness . full in body , softly , creamily carbonate , this be spectacular on the palate . luscious , full , creamy and luxuriating . sweet on the finish with linger plum and tobacco to go with the leathery booze note , this be quite stellar . this beer be an old school stout barrel age in an old school way . the flavor lean heavily on the malt , especially the licorice and tobacco note , and the barrel provide a little heat but also oxidative softness to the flavor profile . impressive .   despite my limited description above , there be incredible depth , balance and poise to this beer .

I do n't normally start by state the overall impression of the beer , but Damon be quite possibly my platonic ideal of a barrel - age stout . ⠀ ⠀ ⠀ ⠀ ⠀ ⠀ this be definitely a labored metaphor , but remember the first time you try Everett and realize all other porter be child 's play compare to Shaun Hill 's magnum opus " Robust Porter " ? if there be a genre of beer call " Robust Barrel - age Imperial Stout " Damon would definitely fall right into that categorization . every little complex nuance that captivate fan of dark viscous liquid age in wooden container be amplify beyond the wildest of imagination , while at the same time strike a perfectly harmonious symbiosis .   an impossible concoction of charred oak , french vanilla , chocolate fudge , medium - roast coffee , raisin , tobacco , molasse , and jammy fig form the heavenly aromatic range associate with this tributary beer . as the brew warm up , the malt - base feature of chocolate and coffee take precedence over the more bourbon - inspire olfactory attribute of the pitch - dark nectar of the god .   I quite possibly use this phrase to the point of cliché , but the nose , as expect , be flawlessly replicate on the palate . every sip of this obsidian magical concoction scream " bourbon ! coffee ! chocolate ! " follow by quiet whisper of " molasse , dark fruit , light vanilla . " the flavor that bombard the tongue throughout the drinking experience remain remarkably consistent ; I drink this over a span of twenty minute sandwich in - between pour of a different BA stout from oh and a half - barleywine half - stout half - whatthefuck madness from WA , but the flavor remain steady and uninfluence by the impose characteristic of both brew upon revisit . I almost want to call this the Heady Topper of BBA stout , give its consistency and ungodly balance of flavor throughout the entire drinking experience .   the body be thicc like Mya 's thigh . I be about 97 % sure that this beer go to the gym and squat three plate four to five time a week . the no thigh - gap thickness be accompany by a velvety creamy initial mouthfeel which oddly feel somewhat cool and refreshing to the touch ; I might as well just start string together random positive - inspire adjective to describe this beer and I 'd probably still be in the ball park of what it actually smell / taste / feel like . gentle simmer carbonation .

immense thank you to jrc1093 for this one . I 've always want to try this little Kiwi bastard .   12 oz can - date 10/06/20 - pour into an ale stem at 40 ° F .   pour a fully hazed , but just shy of milky peach flesh yellow , top with a large finger of off - white foamy head with good retention , leave a tall collar of lacing as it recede . no visible effervescence through the haze .   Nose : instantly recognisable as a Nelson single hop IPA . Green , grassy , herbal note of cut grass , unripe horn melon rind , lime leaf , white grape , passionfruit , feijoa , lychee , leafy , vegetal wild herb , unripe pineapple , unripe mango , orange z , and a peppery twinge .   palate : as expect , this greet the palate with the same Nelson intensity as on the nose . horn melon , acidic pineapple , white grape , unripe mango , passionfruit , lychee , kumquat , and unripe melon rind , shift into some greener note of lime leaf , lime z , fresh cut grass , and a vegetal , planty root note - green , and slightly earthy . this shift into oily , resinous , leafy territory , before take on a very distinct lime z note . the beer finish with this linger lime z , complete with a firm pithy bitterness , and show some pale , flakey malt underneath .   Mouthfeel / body : for the high ABV , this drink wonderfully . all the 8 % flavor saturation , but remain crisp , fluid , and drinkable . it still have that soft , fluffy New England texture , but it be never sticky , sappy , or heavy . effervescence be moderate , but very fine , lend a nice fuzziness . there be that signature racey Hill minerality to it , which compliment a wonderful touch of hop acidity .   overall : a truly fantastic display of Nelson - so on - point , it almost serve as a Nelson caricature , in the good possible way . densely saturated , green , leafy , and vegetal , with all the uniqueness inherent to Nelson . the base beer be so classically Hill Farmstead , which only serve to elevate the experience with an impressive display of quality and craftsmanship . Balanced , polished , and refined , shine everywhere you could want a Hill IPA to shine .

12 oz bottle , pour into a stout glass at ~40 degree F and allow to warm during consumption . bottle date be October 2020 , and I purchase this out of a walk - in cooler at a bottle shop this very weekend .   l : pour your typical impenetrably dark stout color , and form a massive , fluffy head of tan foam with excellent retention .   s : straight up maple fudge . as in almost exactly what one expect to inhale when walk into a fudge shop in the northern US or Canada . really hope they make this again . coffee , chocolate fudge , vanilla , maple , bourbon - just everything to make KBS even well . do n't skip this one if you see it . worth every penny .

l - motor oil . dark as black , but with a brownish hue . minimal head , but the ring of lacing that be leave be crimson tan in color .   s - burst of milk chocolate up front that quickly turn acrid as the milk turn dark and we be leave with raw cocoa bean . there be a sweet maple / honey blanket over the whole thing and even some peanut butter richness . by far the most aromatically diverse of the KBS variant .   t - such richness . wow . undulate between sweet milk chocolate and roasty bourbon woodsiness . on one side of the coin be vanilla extract , maple candy , and dark cherry fruitiness . on the other be fudgy tanginess and that core KBS barrel acidity . fantastic contrast . viscous jet with a finger of sepia froth that do n’t ling ; fresh baked brownie on the nose with hint of bourbon , fig , blueberry and coffee ; german chocolate cake , date , maple cream candy , espresso ground , cigar smoke and whisky barrel to finish with a bitter , tannic linger ; medium to full , chewy , mild heat .   4 4.5 4.25 4.25 4.5   the name say " maple " and " fudge " and that ’ what ’s doin’ here . a monster fudge nose - but cakey , not ganache or truffle - lead into a pile of sweet 70 % dark chocolate in the body . what ’s more impressive be the maple , which be not pure rock candy but more along the line of butterscotch or coffee candy , maintain a delicate presence rather than just ferment out . what ’s not work here ( as kovergas say ) be the coffee and the barrel . the coffee be there , but play like an acidic high note rather than a well integrated part . and the barrel just underwhelm : some wood , little bourbon booze , no vanilla . it ’s balanced and nuanced , as be all in this series - these be always a pleasure to drink , and suffer only in comparison to each other .   well than CBS for smooth maple character , but still do n’t beat the original KBS .

simply slather with Mosaic hop character , the uniqueness of Melcher Street New England style IPA by trillium do n't stop with simple brewing technique , but rather a double dry hopping addition of the coveted hop for extra tangy , green and fruity complexity .   the double Dry Hopped Melcher Street pour with a standard yeast extract appearance on a goldenrod backdrop . as a rich ivory froth build on top , the perfume of succulent tropical fruit , citrus and herbal note swoon the nose . the taste jump right out with a shortbread type of bready sweetness that hinge on light caramel , honey and a slight cakey texture .   and then the true and radiant character of Mosaic hops shine on the middle palate and once the sweet maltiness begin to recede . strong overtone of passionfruit , under ripen orange , gooseberry and lime show off the unique charm of the hop with a tangy , green fruit citrus and tropical medley . trend peppery , botanical and nearly tangy , a grass fill late palate shed the light on sassafra , white grapefruit , green tea , hemp and verbena .   medium bodied and carry a moderate bitterness , the smooth but dry ale linger medium long on the finish with the discernible taste of tropical fruit rind . an alcohol spice of gin and juniper last nearly as long as the hop bitterness even though a linger of bready malt hang in tow .
