2017 vintage enjoy in the first day of 2019 slightly hazy pale yellow with a very thin head . some funk on the nose but quite clear compare to other gueuze . the taste be sour with mostly lactic note and no acetic note . Funky bretts , the raw wheat be very present and quite smooth . quite dry and with a champagne - like carbonation . a unique Gueuze . refine compare to other example . have it a lot of time after that both on tap and in bottle . what strike I the most be the balance of the beer . have it fresh you 've get a perfectly refreshing drink . have it a room temperature and you 've get a wonderfully complex offering .

bottled 16 June 2017 : pour clear gold color with a 2 + finger white foamy head that seem like a cloud on top of the brew , dissipate slowly and leave minimal spotty lacing , most of which slide down quickly .   smell of barnyard funk , wet grass , a muddy trail and then honey , toasted grain , fruit note like peach , lemon z and a very acidic juice like grapefruit juice or sour orange juice . complex for sure , but everything be mute and even with the funk , fruit and earthy note interchange with each whiff . I get floral note as well after a few minute .   taste of tart fruit like sour white grape , green apple , lemon z , red grapefruit , orange peel and then come funk and what could be brett , along with yeast , dry flower , peppery spice , rise pedal , honey , wet cardboard or musty bread , some more trail funk like the smell of wet animal hair and then a dry trailing fruity aspect . it be very complicated and bounce between tart and funky , but the malty base bring sweet grainy note it that cut the sourness and allow more fruity flavor to come through . hard to put my finger on everything that I taste as it be mostly what be list above with flavor that resemble ginger ale and white wine . very easy to drink consider the tartness at point . this be a style I need to explore more to build up my appreciation .

rr beer be incredibly difficult to find on the East Coast , especially in PA , where ( accord to one source ) they be randomly distribute . be very excited to discover a few dusty bottle date 050118 at Waywood Beverage in Kennett Square , PA . open on 1 - 10 - 20 and pour into a champagne flute .   a : clear straw gold . rocky white head that settle quickly . some lacing remain after let the beer open up for a minute .   s : strong lactic sourness . vinous white wine note follow by golden raisin . initially detect a sweet citrus ( tangerine ) aroma . apparent oak tannin on the nose .   t : Carbonic bite follow by golden raisin , citrus and lactic acidity . the acidity be not as sharp as I have assume from the aroma - its actually far more restrained and well balanced , like a sparkling moscato or chardonnay .   m : the combination of high carbonation and tannin create a full mouthfeel despite the thin body . some linger silkiness , perhaps owe to soft water ( pure speculation ) .   o : very well rounded flavor profile and balanced body . this be an elegant and quaffable beer , with just enough funk and acidity to be rustic and refreshing and not toilet stall and corrosive .

thank to westcoastbeerdude for send this particular bottle ! 2015 vintage 375 mL bottle ( I believe the bottle date be 8/3/15 on the label ) , and consume on 2/1/18 . pour into a J. Wakefield OG teku glass .   a : beautiful light gold , and be crystal clear until the last 1/3 of the bottle be pour out - then moderately hazy . a good amount of visible carbonation , but the white head stay small and fade quickly . a pretty beer for sure .   s : Dry Brettanomyces funk , stone fruit and apricot , and mild dry white wine . cracker malt and a mix of citric and lactic tart . mild oak tannin . it ’ a dry funky Brett , rather than fruity and pineapple .   t : Brett funk , sour lemon and citric acid . lactic tart and barnyard . dry apricot . french oak dryness as well . cracker malt , dry white wine . some sweet fruity ester and fleshy fruit in the middle . more dry Brett funk , citrus rind , pineapple , and tart juicy fruit near the end . ultimately finish dry with the french oak tannin and more stone fruit .   m : a light body and low alcohol flavor . the carbonation sensation be a touch on the low side but not so much as to detract .   o : very good . the oak be a worry for I – I do n’t always appreciate the french oak flavor . but everything play so nicely with each other here – balanced , nuanced , and complex . not overly vinous , not overly funky . while I do n’t think there ’ apricot or peach in here , that dry flavor pull through with the citric acid and lemon and add quite a bit to the flavor profile . really enjoyable , but likely not my favorite of the " -tion " series .

12 oz bottle pour into a snifter . no date on the bottle , but I know it be at least a few year old at this point .   a : black pour . a little bit of a beige head struggle to form and ultimately fail . little to no lacing . not all that concern for a barrel aged beer of its strength .   s : the chile be much more forward on the nose than expect , and that ’ the first whiff emanate from the glass . heavy dose of roasty coffee next , follow by a fat fudgey chocolate smell . chocolate sauce and german chocolate cake . roasted malt . Oak and whiskey come out more as it warm .   t : in taste , it ’ the massive tide of chocolate that hit first . ton of hot fudge sauce , chocolate truffle , german chocolate cake , fatty nib , etc . lot of vanilla too , mingle for a malt milkshake impression . Nutty and roasty coffee bring in a mocha flavor . lot of whole chile taste too . the heat be extremely mild , but the flavor be big and ride to the forefront for a bit . Oak and whiskey be actually the quiet component , surprisingly , but that sweet whiskey flavor do round thing out nicely . smokey coffee and a tingle of chile heat on the finish .   M : rich in body with a bit of heft . chewy and mouth - coating . velvety . low and gentle carbonation .   o : a bombastic beer overall , and a bit of a roller coaster ride . rather than meld into a cohesive whole , each ingredient basically take a turn reach out and slap you right in the palate . it ’ big , sweet , and straightforward . even a little busy , if I ’m be honest . that ’s not to say it be n’t good- on the contrary , I really do enjoy it . if you ’re a person who like a nice " pastry stout , " you ’ll likely love it . I think it ’ a solid enough beer , but its brutish approach and bold , hedonistic flavor that vie for attention rather than coalescing ca n’t touch the more carefully compose and elite barrel - age stout . very good , but not great .

Smell : initially I get a good amount of spicy green chilli . a lot of chocolate . Dark Chocolate , milk chocolate . you get some Barrel note , sweet vanilla , toast coconut , smooth whiskey with a hint of oak . also get some caramel and dark malt that come through as well .   taste : this be a lot sweet and Maltier on the palate . right upfront I get massive amount of butterscotch , carmel , and chocolate syrup . the sweetness from the chocolate and malt carry through the beer . in the mid palate you get milk chocolate , sweet vanilla , dark chocolate , and smooth medium roast coffee , almost like a cold brew coffee in the way that it be not very roasty and it be extremely smooth . the beer finish with a hint of green pepper spice , whiskey , toast coconut , a kiss of oak and more of that hershey chocolate syrup . as I mention the beer be sweet on the plate which be really nice . the malty butterscotch sweetness linger on in the after taste as you feel a nice linger warmth in your chest . the beer also have a ton of chocolate which be awesome .   feel : medium bodied . a really nice creaminess , a perfect amount of carbonation , which help the beer feel a little full , which be a good thing because the beer be on the thin side for a Barrel Aged Stout . still the carbonation and creaminess make the beer just glide across your palete , which in turn make this way easy drink then it should be .   overall : an awesome beer that really hold up great to the Barrel age process . the Barrel add a big sweetness and nice boozy presence . in the end though this be only slightly well then the none Barrel aged version , I would say there almost equal , which be ok because both the BA and non BA version be top notch world class offering . do n't worry if you ca n't get your hand on the BA version , because the regular will do just fine .

pour from a 12 oz bottle into a Teku glass .   pour a deep brown nearly black body with a one finger light brown head that reduce to leave a ring of retention and no lacing . Mouthfeel be rich and thick with low carbonation .   a solid brew , good flavor but do n't get much spice .
from the bottle , it pour black as pitch as coal with virtually no head . Vanilla , bourbon and alcohol in the nose . the mouth get the same and more flavor as well . great flavor !
every sip taste different . but every sip be phenomenal ! never guess this be 11.2 ABV ! so smoothe . Caramel bite really make it . bourbon not too strong . the hint of vanilla . I be in love !
very dark appearance with minimal tan head . Aroma be a nice slightly sweet caramel with a touch of spice . taste be also a slightly sweet caramel with a little spicy heat .
bomb be an acquire taste for I , but the BA version be dynamite . it mellow out the heat from the pepper and add a smooth barrel finish . this be really a solid beer .

review from note . pour from a 12 oz . bottle into an El Catador Barrel - aged glass .   a : dark brown to black , and opaque . a thin tan head fade fairly quickly atop a low level of visible carbonation .   s : really nice on the nose . Whiskey and chili , chocolate and coffee . sweet malt mix with vanilla and oak . note of dry tobacco and toffee and Bit - o - Honeys . awfully good .   t : Chocolate , chili and coffee up front . the whiskey heat come next , with significant oak and vanilla flavor . Caramel , more vanilla , and cacao nibs . Tobacco and some roasted malt add some bitterness . More chocolate and coffee with mild but definite chili heat in the hang .   M : the body be heavy , though not as thick and glass - staining as Hunahpu . low carbonation sensation but fine for style . alcohol presence be actually pretty restrained for style , but it remain warm as it go down .   o : this be really , really good . the barrel compliment this beer more than I expect . this all really work well . nice chili flavor without a ton of heat . definite barrel presence without overwhelm the multiple adjunct . excellent .   note : I knock down my " overall " rating a little . I have a second bottle that I review , forget that I have already do so . I do n't care for the second bottle nearly as much , with an estimate BA rating of 3.95 . I decide to enter in the taste note from the " well " bottle , and leave the give score alone . but the Overall be decrease as there may be some bottle variation here .

pour into a snifter . like most other big Prairie stout , a black pour with a minimal tan head which fade to a ring . there be a pretty strong aroma- the Ancho chile jump out at I , but chocolate and whiskey be there in the background . the taste be complex : there be a hint of coffee present , but whiskey and chocolate be most prominent , with caramel malt , vanilla , oak note , and a touch of cinnamon following . the whiskey be extremely well - meld with the rest of the beer , and be present mid - palate through the finish . the chile be somewhat mute , compare to the standard Bomb ! , but provide a nice warming heat at the finish . the beer be full bodied , incredibly smooth the entire way through , and a touch boozy on the finish . pretty incredible . huge fan of Prairie 's stout , but this one surpass my expectation and blow I away .

Viscous and opaque dark brown out of the glass . prominent chile and spice on the nose , with faint whiskey and cocoa . not much coffee . the taste follow closely . very similar to Bomb ! but with an add dimension with the whiskey barrel . to their credit , this do not overwhelm the beer . full - bodied and smooth on the finish . a nice improvement ( hard to believe ) to the base beer .

bottle : pour thick from the bottle , like many Bomb ! beer I 've have . it look almost too thick to generate much head , which it do n't . a thin brown veil of bubble fizz away quickly . a thin rim do resuscitate and fade easily .   molasse early , chocolate espresso bean with a hint of whiskey later . at time there be also a little cherrywood like tang .   Taste also have a little tang to it . the main flavor in this version lean a lot more towards chocolate than other . maybe it be the note from the barrel aging that bring it out a little more . there be actually a candy bar aspect to this with marshmallow and light undertone of toffee .   Chewy , full bodied feel . a little alcohol burn more than chile pepper bite .   come across as a nice after dinner drink . it could easily replace a coffee or light liqueur mixed beverage after dinner .

pour pitch black , no head and thick lacing on the glass . Aroma have vanilla , pepper , oak , bourbon , spice , cinnamon . taste be cinnamon , vanilla , roasted coffee , bitter chocolate , oak , maple syrup - ish sweetness , bourbon finish with pepper that sit in for a long time .

Citraquench'l be a long - time whale . I buy two pack today in Durham , NC . can on 7/1/2021 . pour into a pint glass . it pour an opaque , tangerine color with a half finger of foamy , milk - white head and thick , soapy lace . its smell feature bright lemon , lime , grapefruit , tangerine , and some delightful , floral note . wow , the taste be something else ! the Citra offer huge , sweet citrus : lemon , lime , orange , pineapple , and ripe honeydew melon . it just pop . it be amazing that all this flavor come from a single hop . the mouth feel be moderately creamy with near perfect carbonation , and at 7.1 % ABV it be readily drinkable . overall , Citraquench'l be everything it purport to be and more ! it be absolutely delicious . one of the good New England ipa I 've have the pleasure to drink . just terrific !

1pint can date 3/25/21   golden murky yet luminous haze , no floatie , three finger fine white head , full lacing curtain and cap . strong pineapple , orange , grapefruit , guava , yeast , seashore aroma . thank to Hopelessly0 for the trade on this one ... even with the can be around 7 week old this be incredibly enjoyable and flavorful , which speak to the quality of this brew .   incredibly fragrant ; juicy and ripe tropical fruit waft all over the room !   taste be creamy and pulpy - almost creamsicle - like despite the absence of lactose here . this be one of the more enjoyable neipa I 've had so far - really satisfy pulp flavor of orange / tangerine and grapefruit with just the right amount of pith and bitterness , and perhaps a slight earthiness ... overall mostly tropical citrus and pure sweetness ( not syrupy or thick , just naturally juicy - which be just the way I like it !

appearance : opaque yellow - orange with a finger 's worth of dense white head .   Aroma : Citra citra citra . very nice .   flavor : Citra citra and citra again . so delish ! thank go out to russpowell for this brew .   16 oz . can can on : 11 14 2018   my first from this brewery .   pour into a Tree House glass a pretty nice cloudy yellow / orange color , pretty nice carbonation , with a pretty nice thick / creamy one - finger plus white head , which also leave some pretty nice sticky lacing behind . the nose be hoppy , malty , with a pretty nice citrus complex ( orange , tangerine , grapefruit , mango , guava , pineapple , peach ) , nice little diesel like . the taste be pretty nice , hoppy , malty , with a pretty nice citrus complex ( orange , tangerine , grapefruit , mango , guava , pineapple , peach ) , nice little diesel like . medium body , ABV be hide pretty nicely , with a nice little dry / bitter finish . overall , a pretty tasty brew . on tap at the brewery . get there early to get a park . my favorite draft IPA to date , smooth and power - flavor with excellent finish . great staff at Heist let I sample other without ask . high recommendation ! also get some 16 oz can for my homeboy as I live 259 mile away

pour from a three hour old crowler .   pour a hazy yellow with two finger of white head . smell of citrus , orange , pineapple , grapefruit , faint herbal note . taste follow to a tee . juicy sweet citrus balance with a bit of grapefruit . medium bodied , super smooth . overall an outstanding beer . the good all Citra IPA I 've have in awhile .

on tap at Southern Grist . bright yellow haze with a fluffy white head . Huge Citra aroma . all citrus and berry with no catty note . the taste stand up to the nose . great and bright citrus Notes with a faint underlie dankness . Bready malt . just outstanding .

part of the wonderful deluge of midwest goody send my way by @fbarber during NBS BIF # 13 .   gorgeous pour . body trap light . completely dark . lovely finger of soft dark brown foam . quite the beaut .   Nose have lovely rich velvety espresso with vanilla and milk chocolate and sure enough there be a hint of raspberry layer in there as well . invite .   the berry be much more prevalent here , begin at the first sip . it start off as just kind of a general berry / fruit sweetness that build alongside the other component I will get to in a moment to reveal a jammy decidedly raspberry note . we 'll come back to this later . the build alongside this have silky espresso and dark chocolate as well as a hint of vanilla and spice and oak from the barrel . this bring we back to the raspberry . you know how raspberry be actually kind of tart alongside their juicy sweetness ? it be one of the great thing about they , be they offer a balance and a range of experience , and that present here . the finish have some bitter from the coffee , and a bit of pucker that feel like the raspberry tartness join the oakiness of the barrel and a bit of alcohol astringency ( that work well in this situation to accentuate the other flavour list there ) to give it a little ' ooh ! ' to the finish . really enjoyable .   body be velvety smoothe , and that tart finish I descibe above fade to leave behind some of the dark chocolate bitterness and a slight reminder of the alcohol contain therein . would not descibe it as hot , but it be n't shy about it be double digit ABV .   I be really enjoy this . Raspberry and chocolate be such a natural seeming pairing , but I feel like I still do n't see it quite as often as I 'd expect , in beer . I think it really really work well here , and be grateful to have have the opportunity to try it . thank Frank !

2021 release . great smell of raspberry jam right upon crack the can . duale raspberry and cocoa powder on the palate , with a shot of bourbon as a chaser . excellent barrel character . good leg for 12 % ABV , but slightly thin than expect .

appearance - pour into a sampler , the beer be a murky deep black color with a dark tan head .   Smell - Raspberries be strong in the nose , pair with a definite bourbon presence .   taste - Raspberry be tough to capture in a beer . the raspberry seem fresh , without overdo it or make it seem artificial . the sweetness be balance by roasted malt and a little bourbon sting . the finish be slightly warm , though never overly sweet .   Mouthfeel - before there be slushie with gob of fruit puree , Haymarket make a nice thick stout with fruit .   overall - I enjoy this beer as the raspberry be well present and not artificial tasting .

pour black with a finger of mocha head . smell of dark roasted malt , dark chocolate , dark fruit , vanilla , light barrel . taste be dark chocolate , huge fresh raspberry , vanilla , barrel , dark fruit . full enough body , good carb level . overall an excellent fruit stout !

5/2/19 ( Chicago ): $ 12.47 12 oz . can prepaid purchase for January 2019 Haymarket brewery release , can 12/28/18 and pour into snifter . black pour , carbonation prevalent , tax head quickly dissipate live fine lacing . this release be 12 % abv and label a barrel age stout with raspberry . Outstanding Stout ! slight fizzy carbonation , somewhat thin texture for a stout , nice and easy smooth drinking . Glad I pour this on a cold and rainy May Chicago evening .

2018 vintage ( Jan 2019 release ) .   a : pour a viscous black with a finger of dark brown , dense , foamy head . excellent retention and some line of lacing .   s : dark cocoa and raspberry , cinnamon , bourbon , and oak , mild roastiness and a hint of anise . very appealing and well balanced .   t : Raspberry be a bit more prominent , with cocoa powder , sweet dark molasse , and hefty roastiness . finish with moderate puckering tannic sensation . the roast , tannin , and sweetness be a little too prominent and throw it out of balance .   m : full bodied , thick , with mild carbonation . very mild alcohol warmth .   o : smell great but the taste be not as well balanced and so drinkability suffer .

pour a shiny pitch black color . thick velvety dark mocha color head dissipate slowly and only partially . a good 1/4 inch of velvety foam remain on the beer . thick , viscous almost fudgy when pour into the glass .   Aroma have note of dark roasted malt , tobacco ash , hint of tart raspberry give way to a warming bourbon and oak aroma . note of vanilla , dark fruit and some light earthy pine hop note .   Taste have note of dark roasted malt , a light tart fresh raspberry flavor with some piney hoppy note on the back end . as the beer be consume you get the bourbon , oak , charred oak and vanilla note come through as they warm the palate . the barrel character here be well balanced within the beer profile overall .   feel be thick , fudgey , and incredibly smooth . very mild carbonation - just enough to keep it from come across as still . semi - dry finish .   overall this be about as good as a fruit stout can get - absolutely lovely beer .

I be not generally one for fruit stout - adjunct in stout should be restrict to vanilla , cinnamon , coffee , nut , and whatever that be n't a fruit . but , Clare 's Thirsty Ale be on the top 250 for year , so I have to try it .   usually berry adjunct come across as medicinal to I , except in sour - but this seem to be something of an exception . the raspberry be pungently present in the nose , but somehow do not have either a syrupy or astringent presence in the taste note or mouth feel . there be also very low acidity to the berry , which be impressive - raspberry almost always impart just a bit of acidity . not so here , which be nice . the beer be fairly creamy in mouth feel , with load of chocolate , and be quite smooth . no small feat for such a high ABV . there be definitely heat to the beer - I drink this on an empty stomach and find myself stumble a bit . oops . still , not booze to the taste , just a bit of heat in the chest .   I see exactly why this beer be so respected . I think I actually prefer it over Jam the Radar , particularly as regard format . pretty impressive .   thank you to Franfab , who provide I with this can in the Newbies Winter blue BIF !

pour an effervescent jet black with on finger of caramel color head . so - so head retention & lacing , plenty of viscosity   s : chocolate , rapsberrie , fig . fade a touch once warm . Boozeyness then surface   t : Raspberry & dark chcoclate , raisin , roastyness & barrel dryness up front . more dark chococlate , barrel dryness & raspberry as this warm , a little raisin as well . finish with rapberry sweetness & tartness , a touch of breacing booze & barrel dryness , plus plenty of dark chococolate   mf : fairly chewy , moderate carbonation   pretty darn drinkable for the style & ABV , but enough heft to command respect

Tan head . black color . 2018 vintage .   Raspberry tootsie pop dip in bourbon . Fudgy with raspberry and other berry show . light tartness , but not anything that make it not stout like . on point with backyard and bramble rye . full bodied . really enjoyable .

32 oz growler pour into a snifter   pour deep black in color with a creamy khaki head that have decent retention . smell of raspberry laced fudge , dark chocolate , caramel & vanilla . taste follow the aroma , but the raspberry be n't as strong . it manage to pop through note of dark chocolate with some jam - like note . the finish bring out a hint of peppery rye and oak . medium - heavy body with moderate carbonation , creamy mouthfeel and finish .
very dark appearance with slight tan head that dissipate quickly . Aroma be slightly sweet raspberry . taste be very smooth pleasant slightly sweet raspberry .

be look forward to try this one for a long time and be stoke to have finally get the chance . this be a really neat and sort of unexpected beer , strange to name a strong barrel age stout thirsty ale , like it imply easy drinking or high volume beer or something , but this be anything but , and it would take a special kind of thirst to want to drink a ton of this one . a rye whiskey barrel age imperial stout with raspberry , and a wonderful one at that . I go back and forth on the fruit stout , sometimes they get way too sweet and candy - like with the chocolate in the malt and the fruit sugar , but the raspberry be as tart as they be sweet in this , so while it have some residual sugar and raspberry jam quality , its also really natural tasting , clean , and fairly acidic from their tartness . its amazing how forward the fruit be in such a dense strong dark beer . sure there be still plenty of dark malt in here , its intensely roasty with a coffee quality to it , and there be some barrel char and earthy wet wood as well , but the summery brightness of the berry lighten it all up and really define this beer for I . rye be a smart choice for barrel too , its less sweet in this manifestation than bourbon would have be , and the dense slightly spicy rye character make the grain base seem particularly interesting to I . light vanilla too , but it be nt desserty so much . dark cocoa , a little bitterness , and whiskey , along with old school raspberry jam in the finish , its just delicious and about as well do as something like this could be . this remind I of an excellent raspberry stout I have from hardywood park a few year back but with the barrel , but other than that beer , quite original . worth the hype !

thank Ryan for share a mini growler of this liquid . pour into a tulip . 2014 vintage ( Woodford Reserve barrel ) - very nice incorporation of the base stout , raspberry and barrel note . the raspberry add a nice sweetness and jammy note to a really well do BA stout .

always tough to balance fruit with barrel aged flavor but this one be harmonious . huge fan of rye barrel flavor already so this templeton barrel be right up my alley though I be not a huge raspberry fan . however this work . nose be literally a chocolate cover raspberry with subtle sweet rye barrel note . Dessert beer start with a little booze barrel on the finish . great beer .

black thick beer pour into a snifter . minimal carbonation . lot of chocolate raspberry on the nose . bourbon follow by the sourness of the raspberry but wonderful balance . a little thin on the mouthfeel but minimally

2016 on draft December 2016   look - medium thickness with minimal head   Smell - straight raspberry and chocolate . very little barrel taste - heavy raspberry . very sweet , however , the chocolate mix in nicely too . minimal barrel   feel - below average thickness   overall - an overall excellent beer , however , the " Baby Backyard " rating seem a bit off to I because there be almost no barrel presence and the berry flavor be overly potent . that say , it be still an excellent beer , but I be not willing to crown it at this point .

l : pour a thick onyx and mocha stream with a 1 cm sandy head and moderate lacing s : dark chocolate cover raspberry t : incredibly decadent - silky milk chocolate , cacao nibs , and ripe raspberry burst on the palate ; the barrel be well integrated and provide a substantive base for the beer f : medium thickness with a velvety / smooth mouthfeel and ample carb o : man , this be dessert in a glass and well execute . while the caliber of beer be on par with Backyard Rye , I be not sure I fully agree with the comparison give the different fruit / flavor . nevertheless , this be an elite stout and probably the good raspberry stout I 've ever have . absolutely worth seek out - hope they offer this for growler fill again in the near future . cheer , Haymarket !

pour from a 32 oz growler into a snifter . mild carbonation , dark brown with slight ruby edging . big berry note on the smell with mild barrel presence . berry on the forefront of the taste , barrel be very mild . smooth syrupy feel , alcohol be disguise well . exceptional beer .

this be like a sweet version of Backyard Rye . perhaps the big surprise of the night at a recent tasting . certainly worth try or seek out if you be into fruit chocolate truffle flavor in your stout .

Haymarket be the type of place that I assume exist more commonly before the craft beer boom ; a place that make awesome beer , but somehow manage to stay under the radar ( possibly due to how close it be to Au Cheval and every other trendy restaurant in the area ) .   see this beer on tap necessitate a trip to Haymarket , since it be rare to get a chance to try the stuff . pour a beautiful dark brown with just a hint of red from the raspberry ( think of a beer mix with wine ) . the nose be similarly fudgy with berry .   really the only bad thing I have to say about this beer be that I wish it be a thick beer . the taste itself be delicious , with lot of raspberry flavor for a beer this big , and the barrel treatment serve only to round it all out . honestly , I be not sure a thick mouthfeel would help , because a large part of the appeal be just how much raspberry you get on the front end ( which may be lose if the beer be thick ) .   I be not sure this be the " good " BA stout with fruit as an adjunct , but I think it may do the good at actually portray a berry flavor . this be like a chocolate stout mix with jam . Awesome , and right behind the absolutely glorious 22 month BA Indignant , my favorite Haymarket beer .
huge raspberry , fresh dark chocolate , cocoa , light roast , sweet , some bourbon   unlike the fruit bcbs variant , the fruit be super up front and not really integrate .

pour a clean , half hazy orange yellow color with a medium bodied white colored head that lace the glass nicely on the way down . smell of sweet toasted malt , nice mix of floral and citrus hop at the end of the nose . taste of sweet toasted malt and a nice mix of floral and citrus hop . not too heavy on either , very nice mix . crisp , slightly dry , perfect amount of carbonation . this be an excellent beer !

really hard to beat , quintessential IPA that merge the classic bitter west coast style with the softness of neipa .   this review be base on a can purchase from the brewery 8 day ago , with a stamp from 10 day ago .   look : the look be probably the least enchanting , but still stellar . mild haze , but not too thick . base on this alone , I 'd assume tasty but not this tasty . walnut wood with a bit of glow . really nice lacing on the glass , but head disappear rather quickly .   Smell : Grapefruit juice , maybe a bit of tangerine . Fuck do this shit smell dank and delish .   taste : More grapefruit , but a pine needle slip into the juicer and contaminate the grapefruit juice in the good possible way .   feel : medium carb , but smooth like honey . not smooth like the over - fluff beer that be dominate the east coast right now , just right .   overall : easily the good beer I 've have in the last year , maybe more . the double Fuzzy be great when you be in the market for a tad bit more gravity ( and have a bit more time to recuperate the next day ) .   if you be drive by New Haven , check to see if they 've brew it / can it . the gent at the brewery say they brew it every month or so and usually run out of can within a few day . well worth the 15 - 20 min detour from i95 if you be pass by .

from a 4 week old tin . pour a translucent orange hue , top with thick off - white head with good retention , recede to a film of lace .   Classic citra nose . tangerine with zesty orange peel , grapefruit , malt . fragrant and very hoppy . sweet malt entwine with massive citrus note follow the nose : mandarin , grapefruit , meyer lemon lead to more tropical note of melon , papaya and mango . the pine resin flavor dominate the finish .   Medium body with nice effervesence and good mouthfeel .   in summary : a great example of the NEIPA style . big on the hop but remain balanced and concentrate a lot of flavor into a beer with a relatively modest ABV .

big thank to jrc1093 for this one !   12 oz can - date 12/18/20 - pour into a Spiegelau IPA glass at 38 ° F .   pour a murky , stain ruddy orange hue , top with three finger of dense , foamy , off - white head with excellent retention , leave a sheet of lacing as it slowly recede .   Nose : citra out the wazoo . massive fresh Citra hop aroma , with orange peel , orange pulp , grapefruit pith , pomello , orange creamsicle , mango skin , drippy , resinous , raw green hop , and a touch of yeast - drive bubblegum , all contain within a simple , grainy pale malt base . explosive and insanely hop - forward .   palate : the beer greet the palate with grainy , slightly toasty , flakey pale malt , with a bit of underlie sweetness , parallel to huge hoppy citrus note - orange peel , grapefruit pith , pomello , and a touch of lemon . there be a tropical touch of luscious mango , and a hint of melon , follow by a big grassy green note , and a subtle overdrive dankness . there be some pretty noticeable minerality that sparkle through as well . the finish see the pithy note take over , lend a resinous , chalky - dry bite with a bit of linger oily bitterness .   Mouthfeel / body : the beer be pretty fluid and drinkable , with a crisp medium body . effervescence be fizzy and ample , but very soft and tame , and pair with the unusual minerality , it really lend a bright crispness . the heavy dry - hop , fluffy malt , and hop oil lend additional softness and body , but the finish dry out nicely with some dig bitterness .   overall : a brilliant showcase of Citra hop that somehow manage to cram an explosion of hop flavour into a 6.2 % ABV package . it find balanced between single IPA drinkability and double IPA saturation . there be a lot of Tree House flavour similarity here , and tge beer manage to borrow trait from multiple IPA style and sew they together here to create something that feel hyper - refined , while still be incredibly bold .

pour from a bottle ( 2018 vintage ) into a sort of chalice ( 2020 BBT glass )   l : pour a dark caramel brown with a mild dark khaki head that fade after a bit less than a minute . abv - appropriate leg   s : ton of dark fruit , sweet , some abv heat but not much . get fig , raisin , date , dry cherry , toffee , caramel , dark chocolate . a rich but somehow light nose , not overpower and certainly not cloy . fruit note and caramel lead right out of the fridge , chocolate come out more as it ’s warm   t : follow the nose well , great fruit with a good amount more chocolate than the nose . rich note of raisin and fig open , with wave of dark chocolate close behind , those cherry note as well . get less of that caramel / toffee sweetness on the swallow than the nose suggest . that dark chocolate / bake chocolate come through very well , build and carry through the long finish . a moderate bitterness that I figure be combination of the hop work off of those chocolate note . for the abv this be very drinkable - no burn , some warmth   f : medium- body , medium- carbonation . do n’t have much barleywine experience but this fit what I know - drinkable , light body with a bit of heat   o : still getting aquatint with barleywine but this be certainly delicious . bold aroma with a swallow to back it up , rich fruit with a combination hop / chocolate malt bitterness

on tap at Pelican Feb. 27th 2021 in a snifter . look wise , the beer be solid opaque black with a light tan head and a gorgeous , albeit thin , crown . the nose be incredible , rose , tulip , floral grass and clover , marry with rich oat and barley malt . the taste be mollasse forward , sour caramelize apricot and plum , rich smoke cacao and cinnamon , raspberry tartness to sharpen it , roasted raisin and soda bread , end on a long , very draw out vanilla blackberry sweetness that linger strongly against the palate in the back for up to 20 minute . the mouthfeel be , obviously , luscious , rich , oily , and silky , while finish a touch wet .   Absolutley incredible beer . truly magic flavor , buy on sight thank I later . impeccable dessert choice !

a 2015 vintage - consume for the 2021 Online Barleywine Tasting   pour a ruddy , rusty mahogany brown - sit muddle in the glass , with very little light penetration . a frothy , almost boil cap of loose caramel bubble fizz around before quickly die down .   Nose : I can smell this from several foot away . this be absolutely massive dark fruit - uncanny aroma of prune , madjool date , dry turkish fig , dry cranberry , fruit leather , apple cider , concord grape skin , black cherry juice , cranberry - apple juice cocktail ... the fruit complexity be insane - dark , juicy , and unbelievably deep . there be leather , saddle , dusty oak , old library , irish malt whiskey , California laurel leave after a rain , wild peppermint , and some toast sugar . very intriguing .   palate : MoaS greet the palate with a balanced malty sweetness pair with an immediate , but subtle and restrain bright fruity acidity . ferment apple , date , dry fig , then ton of burn toffee , burn sugar , toasted pipe tobacco , black treacle , and even a bit of stouty roast . big bourbon barrel presence , with splintery oak , char , and spirit . definitely some oxidation here , with some sherry - like character , and it become clear that laurel note be also a product of that - lending this interesting sort of minty / camphoraceous element that my NorCal hiking enthusiast ba be definitely familiar with . there be another odd oxidize note that be very difficult to describe , but it be n't exactly delicious , and I find it be highlight a bitterness in here - a burn quality . the finish see that bitterness grow , with the bright fruity note fall back , reveal some earthiness , along with more barrel , tobacco , and oxidation .   Mouthfeel / body : this one be certainly full - bodied . it be n't syrupy and viscous like today 's hype stout , but it be a chewy , heavy , slick ale - with a low degree of effervescence that be there - but diesnt fully push through the weight of the ale . it dry out , become more fluid , and tighten its grip with a splintery dry finish . some stickiness definitely leave around the lip .   overall : there be a lot go on here . the aroma i d simply divine , and unlike any barleywine I 've encounter . it be complex and beautiful . unless this be a naturally bitter barleywine , I think the oxidation have hurt this one a bit . while it add complexity , there be just this unusual tannic burn thing go on , and it detract from the overall character . I can see a beautiful barleywine in here , and everything surround that character be enjoyable , but perhaps this be one to enjoy fresher ? I 'll definitely have to try to sample a new bottle . finish all this may be a challenge .

I be able to get in on a case buy a couple year ago . this be an amazing barleywine ! pour dark brown to black in the glass . have a sweet front and backend and hide the alcohol very well . it ’ a great beer to sip on the beach with a fire and watch the sunset . one of my favorite by Pelican Brewing . if you get a chance to be on the Oregon coast , this be a must see location for any beer lover ! you wo n’t be disappoint with the beer or venue !

beer # 1500 be an absolute masterpiece ; 2020 vintage , on - tap in Garden City ID and serve in a teku .   a : very dark mocha - color body with clear bronze edge that barely show light ; khaki - color head be small and fade to a consistent ring around the edge of the glass .   s : the nose on this be absolutely full of caramelly fig and raisin , this be dark fruit for day . the caramel sweetness lead to impression of toffee and molasse and rich caramel malt . there be a present vanilla , oak , and spirit character , as well as a ghost - like kiss of spice .   t : the palate follow the nose beautifully with an addition of some chocolate note that round this brew out with delicious , full - palate sweetness ; dry dark fruit , caramel & toffee & brown sugar , leathery dryness , mild dark tobacco sweetness , wonderful bourbon character with no real alcohol burn , though your palate know you be drink a big beer .   mf : sweet , big body on this one . Viscous and sticky , though also smooth and silky . just wonderful .   o : love that I be able to try 5 oz of this one and not be stick with another 17 oz ; this beer ( and style overall ) be something I really appreciate in small dose . this be incredibly well - craft , and though I expect it not to live up to the hype , it be absolutely delicious and worthy of its ranking .

finally tick off a true classic . dark brown hue body , nearly black . Toffee , caramel , vanilla , touch of dark fruit . deep chocolate and toffee sweetness , layer in a damp oaky embrace . full bodied , good carbonation , butterscotch all the way through .

I have this on tap . no idea of its strength until afterwards .   this pour a murky oil black with cocoa foam . incredible aroma . Jammy , raisin and stone fruit , some maple and wisp of tobacco . long linger finish . the abv be imperceptible even as it warm . amazing beer .

bottled 11/19/18 . pour at 56 degree . fast fizzy tan head sit momentarily upon a deep amber / brown liquid ; almost opaque with some clarity at the edge ; no cap retention , ring or lace ; thick leg sheet the glass . nose be sweet dark fruit , malt , round alcohol and bourbon . taste be prune , sugary raisin , caramel and toffee ; light roast malt , bourbon ; molasse and oaky middle ; no bitterness leave from hop ; boozy sweet finish . some heat in the mouth with mild burn on tip of tongue ; slick smooth feel ; medium full body ; low carbonation ; face flush warmth from 14 % abv . overall , I really like this beer as there be intense layer of flavor , and it be port - like in sweetness , alcohol and feel ; moderate plus malty sweet finish with plenty of fruit and barrel note ; highly recommend .

dark but vibrant chestnut brown , fill to 8 ball black , with a moderate tan foam fizzle out to a short ridge collar .   first impression be really caramel forward , like salt dark caramel ice cream , very close to mimic a local favorite from Jeni 's , which have a delectably char brown sugar and dulce de leche character to it . the body be smooth and viscous . there be a little toasty nut and a semi - bitter barrel char , but this be mostly in the english vein , be sweeter and more luxurious .   a solid whiskey booze come out at subsequent sip , while a soft but crackly fizz lead into a semi - dry swallow that be also semi - sticky on the lip . there be hint of dark fruit , but they be not so dark as prune -- maybe a little more figgy with red grape , or even aspect of red wine or port .   Toffee , nougat and candy nut aroma develop as it warm , add layer of decadent complexity to this wonderful experience . at the same time , contrast milk chocolate and black pepper also develop , moreso on the palate .   for my money , this OG barleywine whale be still hit on all cylinder .

22 ounce bottle , 2018 vintage , 11 - 9 - 18 stamp on the bottle . serve in a snifter , the beer pour a dark brown color with about an inch tan head that stick around for a little while . there be also a decent amount of lacing . I like the aroma a lot , the brew smell like brown sugar , caramel , molasse , vanilla , bourbon , oak and dark fruit . taste be similar to the aroma , with brown sugar , vanilla , dark bread , oak , caramel , bourbon , raisin , fig , molasse and plum flavor . it be a little boozy , and with a nice linger sweetness in the finish . mouthfeel / body be medium / full , it be coat and a bit rich with a moderate amount of carbonation . overall I think it be a pretty good english style barleywine and a pretty good beer in general , I know I 'd buy this again in the future if I get a chance to ! $ 24.99 a bomber .

two 22 oz bottle pick up by my wife 's good friend at Belmont Station in Portland , Oregon . serve in a Samuel Smith imperial pint glass . 2014 vintage 22 oz bottle pour into a snifter   a- pour a deep amber brown color with some copper on the edge , one - finger foamy off - white head eventually disappear completely   s- classic english barleywine aroma ; malty sweetness with bold note of caramel , toffee , dark cherry , rum soak raisin , fig , fruitcake , brown sugar and sherry . earthy undertone of leather , along with a good amount of oaky bourbon that stand its own with the other aroma   t- sweet and malty flavor explode with caramel and toffee , follow by note of pipe tobacco , burn brown sugar and black strap molasse . mid - palate bring out some dark fruity flavor of booze soak raisin , date , and fig . as it near the finish , the barrel really start to come through ; plenty of barrel juice with an oaky backbone that add light note of vanilla and enhance the caramel note . linger of bourbon , toffee , dark fruit & booze   M- medium - heavy body with moderate carbonation lead to a creamy and viscous mouthfeel that continue into a slightly warming boozy finish   O- at 5 year old , there be only slight hint of oxidation , this be drink beautifully right now , one of the standard of the style

2017 vintage . pour from a bomber into a PAA Dino tasting glass , this beer pour out clear and caramel on the downstream . it form in the glass with much more darkness ; I ’ve see stout that be n’t as dark . a pinky width crown form of butterscotch colored bubble . 4.75   the nose carry in the warm bourbon along with barrel aspect of very dry oak , leather and dark fruit . layer of sweetness show with fig Newton cookie , caramel and maybe slight molasse . 4.25   the taste bring thick caramel , like caramel chunk mix with dark fruit like raisin , date and plum while the strong background consist of the barrel note of warm bourbon , dry oak and leather . 4.25   the barrel bring a huge dry out effect on this . so dry at point that it ’s like lick a freshly empty barrel . full body with a coating stickiness . the alcohol have a kind of sting to it in the very back that surprise I for be a two year old vintage . 4.25   overall , this be an enjoyable barleywine . one where the barrel play a huge role . 4.25

garnet - tint dark brown with a half finger of short - live tan head that quickly settle into a nice , soupy crown .   huge toffee , some fig , raisin , leather and vanilla - forward bourbon in the aroma .   sweeter fruit in the first sip than expect : huge cherry , plum , fig , raisin and a touch of apple . it ’s join by load of toffee and vanilla bourbon . rich caramel chocolate . a hint of coffee . a strong alcohol bite . nice bitterness in the finish . absolutely wonderful beer and one off of the long time want list for I , who would have guess it would take move to idaho to find one ? ! in any event , its worth the hype and the year of froth for one , a decadent barleywine experience with lot of barrel character , a ton of malt richness and layering , but not as over the top heavy and sweet as some of these can be , as it have a great maturity , lot of wood , some tannin from the oak , and enough barrel char and booze to keep it from be diabetic . pretty deep amber color with some head from the bottle , dense but not sediment , and high shine in the right light . aroma be awesome , slight oxidation over sweet concentrated grain sugar , molasse and maple note , some soy sauce , high end bourbon , vanilla , burn wood , toffee , creme brulee , and a fruity mix of dry apple , raisin , and holiday fruitcake . the enormous alcohol content make no effort to conceal itself either . the flavor have a ton go on too , sweet date and molasse , a little more of the soy thing , lot of woody maturity and a ton of whiskey , vanilla and honey note from it , some bitter char that s need for balance here , and a whole ton of booze , but its warm I from the inside out in the most pleasant way . this be a monster , even if the body be nt as big as some of they , its a slow sipper and one to cherish and savor . I see why this have become sort of a cult follow beer , its a prime example of the style and be wonderfully barrel aged . worth every penny !

2018 - 11 bomber open slightly chill . pour hard to a tulip , which after taste , should really be a chalice . aroma of vanilla and caramel can be smell two foot from the glass ! color be mahogany / chestnut brown , with a two - finger tan head that burn down to a tiny ring with scant lacing . first sip be full of vanilla , caramel , oak barrel , malty barley . the bourbon be very subtle but stay present for awhile . as it warm , there ’s a bit more bourbon bite up front and dark malt on the back ... not cocoa type of malt . slightly warm . mouthfeel be medium , perhaps a little thin than I d like , but overall very nice . five more on a shelf , so we ’ll see how time affect they . BWIL !   crack another bomber at the 1.25 year mark . the nose become more subdued at a distance , but still pull in caramel and roasty char with the schozzola in the glass . very dark burn caramel color . no head . very still when rest , but do kick up some carbonation on a swirl . flavor be all still there . the mouthfeel have improve to what I like more , i.e. , thick , syrupy , heavy oomph that align with the ABV . some dark pit fruit on the back bring more balance to the caramel sweetness . still an excellent beverage !

2012 : a little smokiness . malty and sweet . super good .   2014 : my very first my first mother of all storm - sweet and smooth .   2015 : a little sharp than 12 . Malty and sweet . still excellent .   2018 : Toffee , sweet , smooth - terrific for a fresh barrel - aged barleywine .

appearance : this beer pour an opaque black with burn sienna around the edge when hold up to the light . a light brown , two finger , fluffy head with tightly pack bubble nearly disappear with a thin ring around the edge of the glass . no lacing on my snifter as I drink the beer .   Smell : the first thing to hit my nose be syrupy sweet honey right out of the fridge , morph into toffee and caramel as the beer warm . smooth bourbon note of vanilla . a deep , dark bready malt profile with dark dry fruit aroma of raisin and some bright plum .   taste : this beer be beyond reproach . the malt profile of the Barleywine , the bourbon , and oak distinctly shine through as separate entity , all while meld to create the perfect marriage of flavor . it be the Mother of all Perfect Storms as these various flavor come together . this be not a beer try to be something else , like so many be .   complex and multi dimensional . on the tip of the tongue be sweet dry dark fruit include raisin and date . follow in the middle by milk chocolate and cocoa powder , vanilla , toast coconut and smooth bourbon . after the wave of this storm subside I ’m leave with a long finish of a semi - dry , oak - forward beer with a slight alcohol hint . not love this , but as the beer warm it really open up nicely and these mid palate dry and woody note phase out and it become a perfect marriage of sweet Barleywine , bourbon and oak . a hint of alcohol to remind you it ’ a 14 % beer but never distract .   mouthfeel : low carbonation . super smooth . warm on the palate and in the pipe . sweet and sticky residue leave on my lip .   overall : this beer be a gem . plain and simple . one of the good , if not the good bourbon barrel aged barleywine I ’ve ever have .

Vanilla bean be strong with caramel , milk chocolate , roast barley , spicy Bourbon , medium toast oak and spicy cinnamon note . I guess it just lack creaminess and be lightly frothy instead . fairly slick and oily but not syrupy . the carbonation be moderate and it finish with moderate alcohol warming and some heat from the pepper .   remind I of a walnut , caramel and chocolate cluster and I be impressed by how much the walnut be express in the final brew . the flavor be where thing really balance out nicely but the body could be just a bit creamy if I be be honest .

blend 2 , magic ! the good of the side project little bottle I ve have in year I think , its not as sour as so many of they have start to become , maybe its because its fresher , but the base beer be old anyway , so I m not really sure . more likely its just balanced out by all this fruit , just an absolute load of the blackberry , this be fruit heavy as they get , and all the berry seem necessary to balance a rather intense and complex base beer , this be really good , worth the hype , although maybe just a little raw and unrefined in the bottle . its a deeply stain blackberry color , but have a lot of haze and murkiness to it , some particulate in there as well , look almost like fruit skin , ca nt complain about authenticity , but the beer do nt quite sparkle , even though its bubbly enough and hold its airy white head rather well . aroma be blackberry and blackberry jam , could nt be more obvious , and there be nice tang and funk here too , lot of oak , red wine , light fruit vinegar , and raw wheat , really impressive and interesting , and the boldness of the blackberry be as intense as I ve ever know it in beer ! my mouth water like mad to taste it . the berry be as prominent in the taste , crazy maturity , woodiness , and juiciness as well , even the less enthusiastic beer drinker around our table be impressed with this . the fruit and the sour be great together , the complexity be enormous , and the fruit be sun ripen and real as can be here . not all that acidic , I could easily drink the whole bottle myself , which be nt always true of their beer , and the bretty part seem well developed too . great carbonation on this and some solid blackberry linger . one of the good I ve have with this fruit , truly wonderful beer !

review # 1200   amazing russian imperial stout - very happy to be able to get a hold of one of these . 10/16/18 date print on bottle so this one be over 18 month old . pour a thick rich jet - black color with just a little tan head and some spotty linger lacing - not quite as creamy as I be expect . huge aroma of rich dark roast coffee , dark chocolate , toffee , nuttiness , caramel , vanilla , bourbon , oak , malt , maybe a little faint cinnamon . taste follow the nose , great balance and richness . very complex and excellent depth , the bourbon really hit you gently as the beer warm . smooth , silky , luscious mouthfeel , just the right amount of carbonation . become a little more chewy as the beer warm - very nice . an outstanding beer .

thank to joplamp for this one , from the recent can - can BIF . 12 oz bottle ( package 5/18/200 pour into 14 oz teku . pour the expect solid black color , with less than 1/4 inch of tan head that quickly dissipate , and leave no lacing .   sweet vanilla and bourbon at the front of the nose , with some oak , but the base beer flavor be very muted . just a touch of alcohol heat .   very similar on the tongue , but the roast aspect of the base beer show a bit strong .   the body be thin than I look for in the style , but be smooth , and have a finish that start sweet , but dry out after a few moment .   drinkability be good , no issue , especially for 13+% brew .   overall , a nice beer , certainly , but not one that particularly stand out from other example of its ilk . worth try .

Oak , fudge , and hint of vanilla weave in and out , however they never seem to gain their footing long enough to keep a consistent balance . while I love all the individual component , I just seem to be get too much roasted malt and bourbon .   body have a good viscosity , smooth with a carbonation that be present but not too sharp . soft mouthfeel overall , with a linger stickiness and fair amount of mouth - coating . warm booze down the hatch , the feel of this beer be definitely one of its strong characteristic for I .

Alan , thank you so much for this one .   2019 vintage - 375ml bottle - pour into a Zinfandel stem at 45 ° F .   with a loud , forceful * POP * of the cap , Juicy pour a slightly foggy deep burnish orange - amber hue - rather dark , form just a razor - thin collar with some slow lazy rise bubble .   Nose : my goodness , this be strike . this be a mandarin orange - freshly peel and squeeze until the juice begin to run . not naval , not Cara Cara , not mineola - mandarin - join by gooseberry , white grape , Meyer lemon , apricot , gingerbeer , green apple , cloudberry jam , all swirling amidst some subtle barnyard funk , wet hay , petrichor , cellar stone , wet leave , wine - soak oak , old book , some zesty acidity , and these immensely complex perfume note . this may be the single most impressive aroma I 've encounter . my first ever 5 on anything . I do n't hand those out ...   palate : juicy greet the palate with that soft , restrained Hill Farmstead tartness - citrusy - with a noticeable malt sweetness behind it . there be almost some IPA influence , with juicy flavour of grapefruit , pineapple , fresh grass , gooseberry , white grape , and some serious sauvignon blanc influence . mid - way , the subtle acidity fade , reveal some grainy malt , and a musty , overripe dankness emerge . the bright fruity note begin to give in to some grassy character , orange pith , lime leaf , and some bitter peach pit . some resinous Nelson hop character emerge , still bacle by some lemon z , and then vinous wine cask , tannic grape skin , and lightly bitter hop resinous waft through the finish .   Mouthfeel / body : the ale be medium - bodied , with a touch of weight to it , despite its small size . effervescence be ultra - fine - on par with champagne , but much , much soft . some dry tartness up front , fade to semi - dry with grain poke through , and then finish mostly dry , with some tannin and resinous hop oil cling .   overall : this be a truly spectacular example of what creativity , nuance , and new boundary can achieve . this farmhouse ale display a rare quality of not really have an equal - as in , nothing really compare to it . it be a saison , but it have some pale ale spirit , but it Nelson - hop , with theae heady , exotic element that pair seamlessly and beautifully with the wine barrel , and everything about it be so perfectly round and soften , like a river rock smooth by the water of time . one of those rare , inspire bottle that just sing in harmony .

375ml undated bottle from the most recent release .   pour hazy copper with a half inch head of white with a vigorous pour . minimal retention or lacing . surprisingly low carbonation for the style . light note of cider vinegar , grape must , wine barrel , and wet hay in the nose . light body with a slickish , thinnish mouthfeel . vineous and tart on the palate with undertone of Burgundy , citrus , and apple . finish fairly dry with some linger tannin , red fruit , and grapeskin .   nice beer but proper carbonation for the style would really help the aromatic and mouthfeel . not really get a " juicy " impression either .

2016 vintage ( bottle ) at the brewery a : pour a mostly clear copper color with a quickly recede fizzy white head S : suggestion of pepper and funk , with an understated tartness , there be a sharpness in the nose that suggest cheese though not as much as in other beer of this ilk t : pull back a touch , definite funk and tartness but surprising mild , with a clean biscuity malt profile , follow by some hint of lemon and apple , definite hint of pepper as well , this beer sit comfortably somewhere in between a classically define saison and a farmhouse ale , neither malt heavy nor funk / sour heavy , as it settle out , some of the tartness die down M : definitely dry , but with a fullness that linger on the tongue o : excellent but not revelatory , definitely live up to its name in the juicy department , not my favorite kind of farmhouse ale , but great for what it be . balanced , and immediate in presentation , allow for the nuance to drift gradually out from under the more prominent and define note .

12 fl oz bottle seal with silver pressure cap .   bottle on 10/10/2015 .   pour into HF wine stem .   appearance : opaque golden bodied beer with an orange hue . 1 full finger of white head . head drop down to a thin cap and eventually no head at all .   Smell : great nose on this beer . big white wine aroma . Juicy hop just like the name imply .   taste : very white wine forward ; white grape , lot of oak , and lot of white wine tannin 's . light tartness . light bitterness from hop ; melon rind , lemon z , lime z , green apple , and pineapple . general fruitiness from the hop as well . earthy character from brett most likely . hill farmstead 's signature funk be present . lot of nuance and layer here in this beer .   mouthfeel : medium bodied beer with low carbonation . finish be moderately dry and this easily make up for the low level of carbonation . the beer do feel a little heavy because of the low level of carbonation , but the beer also see extensive time age in wine barrel ( two year accord to the label ) .   overall : Glad to have finally try this beer . be a long time want . while this bottle of Juicy be two and half year old it be still an enjoyable beer . I usually do not care much for hoppy wild beer , but Hill Farmstead make this a beer that be very enjoyable . the white wine character be so big in this beer and it pair quite well with the flavor of the hop . this beer have several element about it that remind I quite a bit of an authentic belgian lambic , but Juicy definitely have an american spin to it .

slick oily black with a seemingly headless , smooth silky surface that slowly develop a thin mocha film and a bubbly collar .   the aroma of spiked dark mocha pair well with the charred oak and sophisticated bourbon that come with the excellent age Hill Farmstead have do here . fire roast marshmallow and vanilla add a new level of decadence , while some spice , dusty cinnamon emerge as it warm .   unbelievably deep , complex and luscious flavor of toast coconut and nougatty yet dry and char roasty wood mingle with some spicy , black peppery bourbon , while the cacao and cinnamon come out as light accent on the back end , with mocha become more apparent at room temperature .   Slick , smooth and round , the carbonation serve to thin it out a bit with a crisp sort of crunchiness , as the swallow become a little warm and then sharply dry .   Jesus Christ do they really know how to improve their base beer with bourbon barrel aging -- i'm not sure any other brewery do it this well . I do n't really like Geneaolgy , yet find GoM to be great . the same be true for twilight of the Idols , yet this be a complete knockout for I . normally my preference be often the opposite at other brewery , so major prop , yet again , to HF .

2016 batch , hard to tell what month due to a smudge on the date stamp . the honey be still a standout , lend a natural sweetness and floral aroma as a counterpoint to the base porter 's roasted bitterness , and dry out the finish . the earthy , nutty coffee be less obvious on the nose but still show up on the palate , alongside an obvious , but not dominating , bourbon and oak character from the barrel . moderately full body with an exceptionally smooth mouthfeel .
very dark appearance with slight tan head that dissipate quickly . Aroma be a pleasant bourbon and coffee blend . taste be also a pleasant mild blend of bourbon and coffee .

Bottled 9.21.16 , almost a year old . pour from a 500mL bottle into a hill farmstead tulip . purchase at the brewery .   pour a deep brown body with a nice , frothy three finger head that reduce to a ring of foam and leave spotty lace . Mouthfeel be rich but not too thick , sweet and decadent . medium - low carbonation .   a real winner from Hill Farmstead . this release be drink great , complex yet balanced with ton of flavor and a good bourbon presence .

' 16 batch , I think .   this one pour a dark silky look black , with a small head , and just a little bit of lacing .   smell just absurd- honey , bourbon , maple sugar , oak , vanilla , fruity coffee , dark chocolate , etc .   this be one of the luxurious beer I 've ever have . there be just a ton go on here , and everything be in perfect balance and harmony , which be impressive . the coffee use here be not bitter in the slight , with fruity and chocolatey overtone , like chocolate - cover cherry . from bottle . near black . dark head dissipate to slick . Smell be elegant . good , clean malt . surprised this be n't BA . have a rich caramel and vanilla element . sweet and smooth . HF feel never disappoint . great beer .

12 oz . bottle pour into tulip ( " manifest on 3/26/21 " print on bottle neck )   l : turbid yellow , almost like pineapple juice , top with a thick head of white foam almost an inch thick that stick and lace some ; keep a full collar of foam and most of a skin ; it be about as " craft " look as it get   s : a strong pineapple - grapefruit aroma hit you as you pour ; green onion , green grass , sweet onion also mix in , but the oniony note be more a suggestion than anything , for it be mostly a grapefruit bomb ; some orange , very sweet , perhaps a bit bready , but the barley malt seem to be add sweetness more than add an actual bready note ; it be as close to perfect as it get , the only tick against it be that it might be too sweet for a hop - head 's pleasure ; at time the sweetness subside a bit and allow for a full connection with the green / citrusy hop aromas ; if a green onion candy exist , it would smell like this   t : much earthy than the nose , slide into a grapefruit peel flavor as oppose to grapefruit ; still , it have enough sweetness to keep from become dirt bitter ; in fact , there be so much malt in there that the hop never get crazy bitter   f : thick but juicy , medium - to - light carbonation , the effect be almost cask - like , perhaps a bit crunchi than that but it be get a nice soft - crisp mix   o : if the flavor follow the nose a bit close , it would be arguably perfect ; as it be , it be a tasty brew with a deft touch by the brewer get load of hop flavor into the liquid without it become so bitter it rip off your face ; personally , I 'd like a bit more bitterness , but I be also not complain and will put this one high on my list of american ipa when I need another hop fix

I m a big fan of Mephistopheles and give it a 5/5 , and put some bottle away for special occasion . I ’m go to have to do the same with this because I ’m so impressed with the experience . luckily my local store have a stock of many bottle and I ’ll probably buy they up , even though they ’re on the expensive side .

12 oz bottle of Batch # 3 , courtesy of BeerloserLI , that be bottle on November 14 , 2016 , that I 'd stash and afterwards forget about . Kinda wish I have remember it early .   pour into the glass , this be be an opaque , super - dark brown , virtually black . about an inch of tan foam be present , although it mostly vanish quickly . not surprising when you consider the abv .   Boozy nose , but not overly bourbony , if that be a word . what boozeiness there be actually remind I more of rum . there be a nutty aroma , with a whiff of milk chocolate as well . the coffee seem to have die out at this point .   Dark malt and booze and milk chocolatey sweetness up front , pretty evenly balanced . I be kinda suprise how much alcohol there still be after 4 yr .   medium body , with a fairly creamy mouthfeel .   nice nightcap on this cold mid - November night . while the coffee have fade , it be still a bit of a booze - bomb after 4yr . curious how long you 'd have to lay this down for it to mellow ! regardless , thank , Brian , for a shot at this at a time when it be n't reliably available in my neck of the wood .

sample a 12 oz bottle from 2016 bottling . say 17.5 % ABV on the label . sound like a winner for I ! the beer pour into my snifter a dark coffee brown color with no light pass through . a surprisingly robust fluffy to spongelike head foam up 2 cm and hang around as a sturdy surface layer . surprised there be this much head for a high ABV brew with 4 year in the bottle ! the nose on this one be .... boozy ! I get some dark baker chocolate , black coffee , and a lot of bourbon and general boozy heat . there be also a bit of dark fruit , raisin and plum mixing and also some molasse note . definitely a big complex beer . first sip reveal a light body than I expect and fine , gentle rolling carbonation . texture be kind of slick as it hit my mouth and slide down my throat too easy . but there be also a sticky coating on my palate after each sip . oh and round out the physical trait , be some warm booze . this kick in right after the swallow and linger in my mouth and down my throat to my belly . yup big boozy beer ! flavor be malt and malt , I do nt get any hop character here . I get dark chocolate and brown sugar up front . this move to some molasse and bourbon in the middle and finish with more bourbon . I think the coffee flavor have fade out over time . definitely no hop character on the finish either . this be a really nice sip beer and seem just fine after 4 year in my cellar . I be amazed at the head retention on this beer which be still a sturdy surface even at the end of my consumption . very nice , would buy again !

I get sweet bourbon booze on the nose more than anything . on the pallet the booze be more reserved ( or enough for I at least ) and still very sweet . I be not get a lot of coffee anymore , but I be sure compare to the base stout it be present . it be sweet for sure . more sweet than other coffee stout but not a pastry stout . overall a great beer but not the world class beer it be rating say it should be versus new coffee stout . I think it be also a bit unfair give the age for I . need to try a fresh one to be fair .

Nose be oak and bourbon , hint of dark fruit , and maybe caramel or toffee ? this have aroma more like a barleywine or a belgian Dark rather than a stout . not get any coffee though unfortunately .   taste be oak barrel and bourbon right up front , which transition briefly to coffee , then toffee / caramel and mild chocolate . so the main thing I be notice here be , this do n't taste like a stout . huge caramel note . bright , fruit flavor and hoo boy the sweetness . it would make a peach jealous . like a natural cane sugar soda . but as quickly as it be there , it fade on the swallow . no stickiness , no cloying . coffee be minimal , bitterness be minimal . alcohol be present but not hot or overwhelming . this just taste like a barrel age Belgian .   Mouthfeel be smooth with very mild carbonation . easy drinking . light . as I say before , not too sticky or cloying . sweetness restrain itself a good degree .   overall , I think the amount of time have be too much for this one to bear . maybe 1 year would have be fine but two have take it be toll . an enjoyable brew . I would love to have it fresh to see what it be like , but this be a little past it be prime . very mellow , subdue . perhaps too much so . but that be what happen .

very muted in aroma but be a well balanced smooth stout that be dangerously drinkable at 16 % . I get flavor of chocolate espresso , bourbon , and dark fruit .

bottle date 10/27/17 into pint glass . pour an encouragingly inky black with a negligible head . initial impression be incredibly smooth , sweet milk chocolate , espresso , bourbon , and roasted malt . mouthfeel be silky - smooth - almost literally oily . alcohol - all 16 % of it - be quite well hidden . finish be smooth and sweet . a lot of BBA stout be over - the - top in the bourbon department . not this one . even the coffee be understate . admittedly , this would be too sweet ( and too potent ) for frequent indulgence . but it be just perfect for the occasional indulgence .

good but become too sweet as it warm . lot of coffee and chocolate but the sweetness overwhelm . Booze be well integrated and surprisingly well hidden . Glad I try but I prefer other over this one . the steep price kinda suck as well .

can date 2 - 18 - 21 . GLBC tulip .   a : pour a bright , crystal - clear orangey - gold . one finger white head dissolve quickly to a 1/16 skim of foam that last . tiny stream of carbonation come from the center . look how I want and expect a DIPA to look , except not much lace to speak of .   S : immediately when I crack the can open I smell the hop from a foot and a half away . smell sweet , tropical , piney and floral . more tropical aroma than I expect , actually . pineapple , mango . hyacinth ?   t : initial burst of lightly sweet tangy hoppiness , crisp , crackery malt center on mid palate with the hop begin to express themselves , turn at the end to a big , brash , bold explosion of dank , floral , " high note " hop . the slight hint of alcohol be detectable on the finish , blend in with that bold , linger floral hop bite .   m : this beer really stand out in term of feel ; it be supremely crisp for something so big . never cloy , and for as bruise as it should be for this ABV and IBU , it be remarkably drinkable . do n’t get I wrong , it ’ a bruiser of a beer , but it feel remarkably light on the palate for the style . not astringent at all . pretty low carb , not much of the " fluff " I enjoy from ale . hard at this gravity .   o : I ’ve say it before and I ’ll say it again , I be too old to be drink beer like this . it be a big , potent , relatively clean hop wallop if that be what you be in the mood for . tropical and floral , not oniony or garlicky , or too piney on the palate , which be good for I . although there be a good , crisp , clean malt presence , this beer be totally out of balance in favor of hop . although the alcohol be well hidden , it be noticeable on the finish and this will impair you on the first beer ( esp . in a 16 ounce can ! ) perfectly to style .   I come , I see , I conquer . More than anything , the craftsmanship of this beer make I want to revisit the other Fat Heads beer I have n’t have in a while , and to try some of those I have n’t have before .

I be normally not the big fan of traditional american ipa ; however , this be one of the most balanced and flavorful . pour from 12 oz can to a traditional pint glass .   l : Clear and clean amber color with a short head . not much head retention , but look great in a traditional pint glass   s : fairly aggressive smell that let you know exactly what you be in for . Aroma hit you without a deep sniff in the glass . Most of the aroma be a resinous hoppy smell with some more subtle tropical fruit   t : so balanced ! for 100 IBU , the beer be not overly bitter . the beer be pack with fruit on first taste which transition to a piney resinous finish that balance the tropical fruit flavor . I be really surprised how the bitterness hide within the beer , but be still present throughout . this make my drinking experience extremely pleasant . for such an aggressive beer , it be extremely approachable .   f : clean and moderate mouthfeel . carbonation be moderate .   live up to the hype ! great beer , and my new go - to American IPA !
