trade for this a while ago , as the date on the bottom of the can read 1/24/17 with " how about no " write below that . it be easy to see how this would be trillium 's flagship offering as this be quite heavy , dank , and tasty at the same time , while be a good example of what an American Pale Ale should be . even though this can be two year old , it age well and have very little sediment in it , as the flavor hold up quite well over time !   this have a nice pour to it as the liquid be a quietly radiant apricot with a fair head top it off . a thin ring of lacing be leave around the top of my pint glass as the faint collar be the good residue that I could find . a few soapy section remain as I work my way through this but it be disappointing for something that be quite enjoyable . lot of bright stone fruit , peach , wheat , and white grape could be find in the varied nose as the taste have quite a range of flavor to it as well . light wood , citrus pith , and a subtle earthiness could be find on the palate as this warm up as I enjoy the nuance of this beer . moderately slick and lightly carbonate , this feel like Hawaiian Punch in the aftertaste as the tropical and juicy note linger on my tongue once the liquid fully go down ...   not a lot of booze to this as this truly be an American Pale Ale and not an IPA that go by another name . balance in body , there be little sediment in the liquid or at the bottom of my pint glass once I finish this off . certainly enjoyable , this be n't a standout beer but have enough go for it that the hype be n't entirely unjustified . fan of trillium would be wise to see this out although it be certainly not a hop bomb or full of dankness . instead , this be a beer that anyone could easily embrace , since there be enough to like about it from the get - go !

16 oz can - Double Dry Hopped version   pour a small finger of white head into my willi becher glass , a little soapy look , dissipate quickly . good initial lacing . body look like orange juice . Meh , look ok I guess .   Nose be pretty juicy , load with grapefruit , some mango . Dank , piney hop ling underneath the fruit . small amount of creamy wheat present as well . pretty nice job of stay balance between traditional hop aromas , and fruit . not an " american pale ale " by any mean , as their website say , regardless , smell pretty good .   Flavor be good , but do n’t quite have that crisp refreshing punch I ’m look for . a little under carbonate , and while the hop be there , they do n’t help make up for the lack of carbonation with any real mouthfeel contribution – drink like juice . as for actual flavor , mostly those dank piney hops come through . Grapefruit be a secondary flavor , mango be not really present . I ’m glad the hearty hop note be the one that be shine , yet it be still miss something - perhaps a little watery in some area . at time , it ’ hard to differentiate between poor mouthfeel , and flavor . definitely not a sweet NE style , which again , be good . taste good , but have its issue .   not much else to say about mouthfeel that have n’t already be say , under carbonate , a little watery , bitterness do not linger , not too sweet . overall sub par .   the drinkability be very high , it ’s not a perfect beer , but it ’ very tasty and unoffensive .   Appearance turn out decent I guess . Lacing be patchy to say the least , but well than nothing .   overall it ’ a tasty brew that hit home with the right flavor , but it be a little derail by a low carbonation and watery taste / feel .

a - hazy pineapple juice look with a nice head that dissipate quickly S - big tropical punch of sweet fruit aroma with a slight sweet malt background M - Thick and pillowy but also quite peppery and effervescent t - sweet deception with a smooth and last bitterness o - really great beer . the peppery flavour be a little harsh on the sense .

pour a murky orange that glow like a dragonball when hold up to the light . snow - white foam top out at just over a finger after a modest pour , and retain well . Aroma be orange , tangerine , papaya , and pineapple form a smashing , but not brutal or harsh , tropical fruit display . it smell a little sweet . Toasty biscuit , wheat , and bread malt note help bring down the sugary citrus rush . flavor profile be papaya , tangerine , orange , and mango with a hit of toasty biscuit , and bready malt note . mouth feel be medium - thick with a fuzzy , near - on - velvety texture at the onset and then thin out on the tongue . it have a middle of the road consistency . overall , a flavorful American Pale Ale , although it really drink like any other NE IPA just with a little more malt at the forefront . knock down 1/4 of a point for that . the malt balance here help counteract the sugary hop pull most NE ipa carry , land this one at a very favorable balance .   serve in a 12 oz snifter from a 16 oz can .

from the 16 oz . can which be can 09/13/18 . sample on September 27 , 2018 .   Murky , milky looking light amber - yellow in color with a linger and modest white foamy head . some lacing .   the aroma emit vibrant character of grapefruit juice , pineapple , citrus , and tropical fruit . there be a mellower toast pale malt barley grain presence .   medium to full body .   Fruitiness lead to pungent bitterness in the flavor . still a sweet start and a linger bitter finish . I could drink a few of these back to back .

pour from the can into a Spiegelau IPA glass , sure why not . Canned July 24th 2018 .   quit a good soapy three finger bubbly head that dissolve and pop with quite a bit of gusto . opaque dark lemon yellow to hint orange body color , not quite full turbid character but also with a nice glow .   very nice aromatic nose . light malt with a touch of crispy brown sugar , mix with a very noticeable tropical hop angle of mostly pineapple . soft possible sensing body , with an excellent sugary quality that be n't overbearing . quite nice .   Palate be very solid . light body even for a pale ale , but just flirt with wetness in mouthfeel and inch to a chalk aftertaste . base flavor be very good , a rich light almost crusty character with mix pineapple and touch of light pine . finish about the same aromatically but go almost weak mint and earth rich on the aftertaste .   very solid new age pale , stay in both ground place , but also flirt with a little baby aspirin as well . very drinkable and still enjoyable .

pour a hazy peach coloration with a small , fizzy head . Smell be initially quite lovely , with hoppy , juicy tropical / citrus fruit note of mango and passion fruit with a hint of pineapple and tangerine , but take on a light cat piss note as it sit . taste be very bright and hoppy , dominate sweet , juicy tropical fruit note of mango , passion fruit and pineapple and with zesty citrus note of grapefruit and tangerine . there be a light dankness and a hint of pine to this as well , almost no malt presence detectable though . finish with a light bitterness and very mild hop burn . soft mouthfeel with a medium body and carbonation .   this be the quintessential NE style Pale Ale and I would say that it have an amazing juicy hoppiness , mouthfeel and depth of flavour for a Pale Ale , but be this even a Pale Ale at 6.6 % ABV ? nonetheless , it be still an excellent beer at a relatively low ABV . the balance of sweet tropical fruit , zesty citrus fruit and dankness / pine really be outstanding here .

the first thing I say when I taste this beer be " pineappley goodness " , and I 'll stick to that . the overwhelming flavor of this beer be certainly what you notice , but behind that , it be actually pretty balanced . I think it be a bit less hazy than most of the recent " New England - style " beer , but I get why this be their main APA , and I 'd bet it be one of their two or three big seller too .

date 5/9/18 on the bottom of the can , 12 day since brew .   pour a nearly opaque straw - gold with a finger and a half of compact white head . aroma burst out of the can as soon as I crack it open . first note of the nose be of spice ; pepper , coriander and cumin . this be follow by ruby grapefruit pith , black licorice , honeydew and a selection of over - ripen tropical ( mango , apricot , pineapple ) . taste follow the nose with the over - ripen fruit and spice , but also bring in some dankness , pine resin and pale grainy malt . body be a smooth medium- with low dryness and a medium- hoppy bitterness . another great IPA from Trillium , perfectly balanced and smooth , great blend of hop that give mix of pungent spice , tropical fruit and hoppiness .

CANNED on 05/09/18   pour an opaque peachy haze top with a pillowy layer of white foam . fragrant tropical hop saturate nose ... mango and apricot slices , grapefruit , pine needle , and a faint leafy herbal spice . Peach , mango , zesty citrus , pine sap , and a general fresh hop earthy greenness . smooth and frothy , fairly heavy for an APA , but stay drinkable thank to a super crisp finish . good stuff ... essentially an IPA .

have a few of these on draft the other day at the Tinker 's Son in Norwell for eight dollar a pop ! I prefer this to Congress Street , less of the mango taste . would buy if I see in can , but not for $ 8/.

Flavor be rich dark toasted malt , whiskey , caramel , dark chocolate and oaky vanilla . medium body with moderate creaminess ; light carbonation , but silky mouth feel . wow , I be a bit in shock . this be one a number of nearly ten year old stout I find in the back of the basement . Most be drinkable , but all be clearly over the stage of improvement from age . not this one . I be n't even go to review it due to its age until I taste it . although the near still pour be expect from great age , the aroma and flavor be outstanding . there be little or no oxidation nor other over - age flavor . the malt , chocolate and whiskey be all nicely integrated and fresh tasting . Whiskey be at a perfect level . I now wish I have continue to save this for the " special occasion " it be set aside for , this would have be an excellent bottle to share . I see that I pay a lot for this in 2012 , but it be well worth it and now I wish I have n't pass up other more recent version due to the price point . this be a worthwhile splurge that hold up superbly . extra point for taste so good at 8 year old .

I believe the aroma may have suffer some with five year of age , but the taste and mouthfeel really shine on this beer . the boozy character add a nice balancing quality to the thick , rich sweetness of this imperial stout . I be sure the honey greatly add to the feel and taste . I must admit that this have be around for a few year , but at nearly $ 35.00 a pop , I be n't too keen on take a stab at this . in this case , I probably should have suck it up and go for it . chance be I 'll be check out some of their other version , plus there be some new version of the Eclipse stout that be now call my name . oh , the humanity ...

product_name: Imperial Eclipse Stout - Elijah Craig (12 Year)
product_review: nice look beer with a nearly opaque color and a nice foamy tan head that linger . whiskey , coffee , cocoa , and caramel on the nose . the taste be a bit too much whiskey for I , but there be a nice sweetness and roastiness from the honey to balance thing out . not overly cloying , but essentially two dominant aspect ( whiskey and honey ) that battle it out . definitely not subtle .

product_name: Imperial Eclipse Stout - Elijah Craig (12 Year)
product_review: have a 2017 bottle pour into a Teku and savored . pour a little more viscous than most other beer , which I regard as a good sign .   it pain I to do it because I appreciate the effort that go into this beer , but I rate it a category below " world class " .   this be a big , complex , and great beer , but it aim high than it achieve . the 3 main component of this beer be plainly evident immediately upon drink it : imperial stout , honey , and barrel - aging . this do give it a lot of complexity , especially as IS be complex to begin with and then you add honey and BA . but one flaw be that these 3 element do not combine together to create something new . they exist side by side .   another fault be the use of honey , which do n't work as well as you would like . I love honey . especially on hot biscuit where its cloy sweetness be the perfect foil to the starchy biscuit , especially with butter . with this beer , you get just the cloyingness , without really balance anything . the honey also add a definite silkiness to the mouth feel . some people no doubt really like this silkiness , but I 'd rather not have it .   I ca n't help think that the use of a different , more caramelized sweetener might have work considerably well in fuse together the IS and BA flavor to create something really special . something like maple syrup or brown sugar instead of honey .   on the plus side , they hold the honey back enough so that it be not a sweet beer ; it finish with a strong and excellent bitterness . it have a world class finish , but then I remember the cloy honey flavor and that the BA flavor do n't seem to add much , but just go along for the ride , and I realize there be room for improvement .   I hope to be in Truckee in December to try one of these on draft , but I be not currently plane to acquire more of this one .

product_name: All That Is And All That Ever Will Be
product_review: 16 oz can pour into a snifter .   a : black on the pour with two finger of brown head . retention be good , lace manifest in broken ring .   s : nose be heavy on the chocolate . Brownie batter and a generous helping of Hershey ’s chocolate syrup . fatty nib . bit of woody roast and earthy hop . berry - like fruity note . nutty coffee .   t : follow the nose . chocolate all over the attack . cocoa nib , brownie batter , chocolate syrup in a big way . sugary lactose . that berry fruitiness come through taste like a raspberry tootsie pop . pervasive background flavor of nutty coffee . quick flash of earthy hop , and woody and roasty malt flavor poke through now and again . perhaps some subtle cola . roasty and Chocolatey finish .   M : rich and thick in the mouth . coating and almost syrupy . ton of residual sugar . carbonation be ample but gentle , and fluff thing up a little .   o : might be an unpopular opinion , but this be just too sweet for I . Tree House have a penchant for take all of their dark beer well onto the sweet side of thing , and some fare well there than other . here there be just not quite enough hop , coffee , or black malt bitterness to bring it into any semblance of balance . it do finish dry than it start , but it be n’t nearly enough to save the drinkability . you get ta have a serious sweet tooth to enjoy beer like this , and unfortunately I find that I tend to favor balance and dryness as oppose to a candy - bomb like this . it taste like chocolate syrup and sit like 16 oz of chocolate syrup in the stomach . look like sweet sell though , so maybe I ’m just an old grouch now .

More of a sweet floral / herbal than you would expect . 16 ounce can into tulip glass , can on 9/24/2019 . pour fairly hazy deep golden amber / light orange color with a 2 finger fairly dense and fluffy off white head with fantastic retention , that reduce to a large cap that last . thick foamy lacing cling on the glass , with a fair amount of streaming carbonation . fantastic appearance . Aromas of big red grapefruit , tangerine , lemon , lime , peach , pineapple , apricot , passion fruit , papaya , mango , honeydew melon , guava , blueberry , gooseberry , citrus peel / rind , wood , mint , peppercorn , pine , honey , cracker , toasted biscuit , light caramel / nuttiness , and herbal / floral / grassy earthiness . damn nice aroma with great balance and complexity of citrus / fruity / tropical / earthy hop , honey , and bready malt note ; with big strength . taste of huge red grapefruit , tangerine , lemon , lime , peach , pineapple , apricot , passion fruit , papaya , mango , honeydew melon , guava , blueberry , gooseberry , citrus peel / rind , wood , mint , peppercorn , pine , honey , cracker , toasted biscuit , light caramel / nuttiness , and herbal / floral / grassy earthiness . Light - moderate pine , citrus peel / rind , herbal , floral , woody , grassy , peppery bitterness on the finish . linger note of grapefruit , tangerine , lemon , lime , peach , pineapple , apricot , passion fruit , papaya , mango , honeydew melon , guava , blueberry , gooseberry , citrus peel / rind , wood , mint , peppercorn , pine , honey , cracker , toasted biscuit , light caramel / nuttiness , and herbal / floral / grassy earthiness on the finish for a while . fantastic complexity , robustness , and balance of citrus / fruity / tropical / earthy hop , honey , and bready malt flavor ; with an awesome malt / bitterness balance , and no linger hop astringency after the finish . fairly crisp finishing . moderate increase dryness from linger bitterness . medium - plus carbonation and medium - full body ; with a very smooth , creamy / bready / grainy , and sticky / resinous / rindy balanced mouthfeel that be great . mild increase warmth of 9.5 % after the finish . overall this be a fantastic dipa . all around fantastic complexity , robustness , and balance of citrus / fruity / tropical / earthy hop , honey , and bready malt flavor ; dangerously smooth and easy to drink for the big ABV , with the moderately bitter / resinous / dry finish ; not overly aggressive . Amazing Simcoe , Citra , Galaxy and Mosaic profile . extremely vibrant , juicy , dank , and earthy hop ; with a nice sized honey and bready malt backbone . minimal residual sweetness with crisp resin dryness . a highly enjoyable offering , and outstanding style example . love the hop profile as expect .

Drank from a 1 pint , 6 fl . oz bottle purchase at Cambridge Wine & Spirits , Cambridge , MA serve in a tulip   Spectacular appearance . the nearly crystal clear , medium amber body be top by an immensely tight and fluffy , three - finger tall , bright white crown . large swath of thick , drippy lacing stick along the glass and last until the drink ’s end .   the aroma be really entice and contain a medley of pungent , fruity hop note . an intense , generic tropical fruit quality come through big from the get go . really fragrant and sweet . as the beer sit , I be able to pick out ripe passionfruit note . some peach and apricot appear as well . Citrus be also detectable . Orange be most noticeable . there be a dry , powdery yeasty quality too . later , the yeasty note intensify , as do the orange . Bit of candied orange peel as well .   the flavor be definitely more citrus forward than the nose . Juicy orange note dominate . load of pithy citrus rind too . Grapefruit appear mid palate and intensify as the beer move along the palate . More rind - like pith and bitterness on the back end and in the finish . big piney , resiny hop note linger after the swallow . somewhat sticky .   terrific fluffy , light bodied mouthfeel . the liquid contain a fairly aggressive , large bubbled effervescence that turn creamy and smooth on the palate .   Emerald Grouper be a solid West Coast - style IPA with a tropical fruit - forward aroma and a citrusy , resiny flavor profile . do it belong in the BeerAdvocate Top 250 however ? definitely not . these sticky , honey - infuse ipa be all the rage ten year ago but , frankly , they seem a bit date now .

October 2008 vintage . strongly color from the cherry but it have a murky , dark garnet color which be n't the most appetizing . minimal carbonation and no real head or lacing . the cherry have surely mellow over time but they be still very much present and seem to have a more earthy flavor , presumably from the addition of the Schaerbeekse cherry . acidity be very strong and it be quite puckering at time but never get over the top . a nice beer but it do n't quite live up to my expectation .

Bottled 4/28/2010 .   a : pour a deep cranberry juice red with a minimal soft white head that fade into a last collar . s : musty attic , damp basement , and old oak barrel be prominent . the cherry add a mellow sugary sweetness with tannic note of cherry pit and skin . mild cheesiness , faint tartness . t : sweeter , juicier , and fruity than I expect from the nose . cherry be fruit juice - like , but not cloy . the musty wood and light wheat base follow , with flavor of honey and earth in the finish . the tartness be very mild with just a kiss of bright acid . flavor remind I of wildflower honey . slight grape . wheat and interesting yeast profile come through more as the beer reach room temp . m : medium - light body , smooth and slick mouthfeel with a slight amount of gritty tannin . dry finish , low acidity , low carbonation . o : four and a half year old have do this well . not as tart or funky as I expect , but very woody with an interesting floral honey sweetness . very delicious .

a- a beautiful deep intense red with a tall pink head that keep a thick outside lace . a truly beautiful look ale .   s- seeet cherry , raspberry , and peach . a very rich funk that instantly make your cheek pucker . there be also a slight smell of cough medicine but not as poignant .   t- follow the nose exactly . the taste be sweet and sour . sweet cherry and raspberry . then the sour sit in . completely take over the taste bud . the medicinal taste be definitely present on the back end but it be n't bad .   m- sour as hell ! probably the most sour beer I 've have . full body as well . from a 750 ml bottle to a tulip .   a - a normal pour produce very little head ; just a thin pink cap that fade quickly to a collar . the beer be raspberry in color and slightly cloudy . nothing spectacular to look at , but it suit the style .   S - the aroma on this old ( 2011 ) bottle be subdue compare to some lambic , but I still smell a good bit of sour cherry . other scent include champagne , cider vinegar , and a light dose of earthy , barnyard funk . acidity be moderate to low for the style .   t - the taste be flush with clean acidity , as well as some mostly - dry oaky funk , and more of that lovely sweet / sour cherry taste . it be very balanced and impress with its focus rather than outright sourness or fruit flavor .   M - the feel be slightly heavy than some lambic style beer with an assertive but smooth carbonation that really compliment the flavor . perhaps the good " feeling " lambic I have ever have .   o - what a great beer . it sound stupid , but the smell and flavor be so simple and clean that the beer almost become more complex as I try to locate all the little subtle aroma and nuance that make this beer taste so good . unlike some true belgian lambic , I find this beer to be approachable , as well , i.e. , not hugely sour or funky or hard to appreciate . the mouthfeel be also nearly perfect for the style .

currently # 185 in the top 250 beer list . my first trillium beer ... i'm rather excite .   can : acquire at Trillium . 1 pint formt with a minimalist white label and a standard pull - tab .   8 % ABV . " double IPA . "   served cold and fresh into a nonical pint glass .   HEAD : ~1 cm in height . off - white colour . not as dense or thick as would be ideal . ~8 minute head retention . leave no lacing as it recede .   body : turbid dull orange . haziness be obvious . I see no yeast / lee within . nontransparent as a result of its turbidity . lack the vibrance and life I 'd expect in a world - class imperial IPA , but it be certainly entice in a general sense without look unique or special . I do have to wonder if filtration would render it more attractive ( I reckon it would ) .   appear well - carbonate .   aroma : tropical fruit be the main note I be get . Guava , passionfruit , citrus z , mango , subdue pineapple , tang . the New World ( Galaxy , it seem ) hop aroma edge out the more classic hop aromatic for dominance . not piney , grapefruity , oily , resinous , or overtly bitter .   suggest a fruity imperial IPA with no trace of hop bitterness or alcohol . not the India Odwalla Ale aroma I 've come to anticipate in wilfully turbid ipa , which be a plus . do n't seem yogurty or milk sugar - redolent ( also a plus ) .   aromatic intensity be moderate . I detect no off - note . lack overt yeasty or malty note ( save for generic pilsner malt / wheat sweetness ) .   TASTE & TEXTURE : mysteriously light on the palate , tend almost a bit thin in spite of its medium - bodied presence on the palate . have a very brief flavour duration as well .   Juicy ? sure , but not full - on India Odwalla Ale thankfully . Mango , citrus z , pineapple , pale malt sweetness , orange pulp . somewhat shallow , actually , lack the hop pungency and depth of hop flavour one would expect in a world class imperial IPA .   what it do well be disguise its ABV devilishly well . Hop bitterness be n't present at all , but the erasure thereof seem to come with the tradeoff of lose hop pungency ( my main issue with this Johnny - come - lately turbid { i}ipa trend ) .   well balanced generally speak , but not dial in to ideal harmony . not the most complex imperial IPA out there either , but it be not simple - just want in term of intricacy .   have a pulpy yet thin feel on the palate . could have a fresher juicy taste . frankly , I think the hop profile could be well . well - carbonate . somewhat refreshing . not oily , gush , hot , boozy , astringent , harsh , rough , or scratchy .   overall : I be not sell on the nascent imperial IPA trend , but this be one of the well execute expression of the style I 've have recently . it flirt dangerously close with India Odwalla Ale territory give its juice - like flavour profile , and be it slightly boozy it would invite comparison to a well - make Screwdriver , but I enjoy it for what it be even if it be nowhere close to world class level in my book . not a beer I 'd stand in line for or spend $ 16 + a 4 500ml pack for , but to each her / his own . probably well describe as a black barley liqueur , the Black Tuesday brand do n't need much tinker , try or adventure . its a most utopian beer all on its own . but the marriage to rum barrel offer a kiss of even great succulence and charm . and to think- most folk be simply happy that its not Monday anymore .   pour the same abyss - black with an onyx sheen as the standard Tuesday , the stout also look like an oil slick with a menacing purpose . as a dainty espresso crème mount , the beer swirl with sticky legging of brandy proportion . Espresso , chocolate , coconut , vinous fruit and spice rum fill the nose with opulence while a backbone of black - strap molasse , maple and bittersweet chocolate saturate the palate , seemingly of brownie batter in taste and consistency .   the full brunt of flavor be know as the middle palate mount , saturate each and every tastebud with extreme espresso , molasse , chocolate , walnut and hint of roasty smoke . port wine , sweet rum , and madeira offer up a savory umami meatiness to balance the sweetness and add salinity . its spicy finish be mildly tart with red wine yet smoothen with vanilla and heavy cream .   massively texture , chewy and silky- the lavish texture hinge on cloying , but its milkshake consistency wrap the tongue in its heavy coat and be patient to relax . the beer 's extended flavor be indefinite and unyielding- warm with sweet booze , very much a digestive like fine liqueur .

got this one from Claaaark13 a while ago . thank again man !   from a 750 into a snifter bottle on   appearance : look like all the other Black Tuesday offspring . a very transparent , thin , and relatively light brown pour yield a thin , loose , bubbly , off - white head with lousy retention . head quickly fade to a thin ring , which eventually vanish as well . light bistre brown body , clear , with no real carbonation evident . look flat by the end and absolutely no lacing at all and it be much too thin and transparent for the style as well . very disappointing look .   smell : quite sugary , which be no surprise . lot of rum , oak , vanilla , toffee , sweet cream and booze . some nice brown sugar and molasse from the base beer come through as well . definitely a sugar bomb , but very enticing .   TASTE : sweet and alcoholic . sweet molasse and brown sugar from the base beer show up first , with flavor of oak and sweet rum join the party up front . definitely sweet but very flavorful . lot of alcohol at the swallow with toffee , oak , vanilla , sweet cream , brown sugar and molasse , and a nice dose of sugary rum as well . desert in a glass .   palate : same as all the other BT brew but maybe a little less abrasive , which be nice . otherwise , medium body and medium level of carbonation . prickly on the palate , not as smooth as hope , go down okay with a big burn at the swallow and finish very sticky . lot of heat linger as well . could definitely be creamy and smooth , but other beer at this ABV have be bad .   overall : this be really decadent . very sweet of course , and definitely boozy for sure , but the aroma and flavor be like a sweet desert lover ’s paradise . this one be perhaps less abrasive than a lot of the Bruery ’s Black Tuesday variant and vintage as well , which help the overall experience . I really enjoy this one and it might be my favorite incarnation of the base beer since the ' 09 first come out all those year ago . thank again for this one Claaark13 . would love to drink this again at some point .

$ 17.46 ( include shipping)/500 mL cork and cage bottle ( $ 1.033 / oz ) from Tavour , Seattle , WA . review 2/23/19 . " BREWED JANUARY 25 , 2018 " at top of rear label . store at 42 degree and serve at 54 degree in a hand wash and dry Jester King snifter . appearance – 5 . body – dark brown / black , opaque . head – large ( maximum 6.3 cm , aggressive center pour ) , tan , medium density and rocky , average retention , diminish to an irregular three to five mm ring and a rocky partial layer . head retraction leave behind thick , wide band of lacing as well as isolated island . lacing – excellent . this produces mark three - dimensional band of lacing , consist almost exclusively of tiny bubble . ring be connect by thin column . first pour – dark brown , clear . Aroma – 4.25 - initially sweet chocolate and roasted malt with some " dark fruit " , shift to wood . wood remain the predominant odor for the remainder of the serving , although some bourbon appear as it further warm . flavor – 4.25 - begin with light chocolate flavor follow by a bit of caramel and some " dark fruit " . allow it to warm in my mouth allow the alcohol ( 13.5 % ABV ) flavor to stampede forth . no diacetyl , no dimethylsulfide , no hop . palate – 4 – full , creamy , soft carbonation . impression and interpretation – 4.25 – overall , a very attractive and aromatic brew , with the appearance approach perfection for a Russian Imperial Stout . the nose be complex and exciting while the taste also demonstrate more complexity than I can articulate – I will leave this to someone with well taste bud . overall , just one damn good brew !

750ml bottle . batch 1 . serve in a Side Project stem glass on 5/10/2015 .   appearance be pitch black . perfectly contrast with the Side Project lightbulb logo . beautiful . two finger brown head with appropriate retention time ; disappear into a very thin collar , no film . no lacing .   smell of tart cherry up front , fresh out of the fridge . it do n't smell as sour as I be expect it to be after one year in the bottle . moderately acidic but not vinegary or lactic . after a few minute , thick chocolate fudge come out ; literally like chocolate fondue . the cherry be still strong at this point , make for a nice chocolate cover cherry aroma . Oak , a bit of vanilla . the whiskey start come out more as it warm , as well . Smoky , sweet , robust whiskey ; a nice complement , never quite emerge to the fore . overall , to sum up the full extent of the aroma in one sentence- tart cherry cover in dark chocolate with a bit of vanilla essence and oak ; mellow whiskey in the background . fair amount of acidity , but not particularly lactic .   Flavour be equally complex . initially , tart cherry , dark chocolate . so like in the nose , chocolate cover cherry . not particularly sweet . small amount of vanilla be present , as be a moderate vinegary acidity . as it warm up , the oak and tannin seem to combine with the acidity to give a vinous flavour , like a Syrah ; in my mind , it seem to impart a lot of red wine note into the flavour ; I suspect this be due to the combination of the oak tannin and the acidity . Whiskey be there , underneath all of this . no heat , but a subtle char be noticeable towards the end . a very complex beer that seem to evolve with minute change in temperature , finally reach its peak at room temperature . even more cherry come out at the end . it be really a fascinating drinking experience .   the body be rich and substantial , which you 'd think would be strange for an awa , but it be substantial without be dry or creamy . smooth with good carbonation . different flavour follow each other in wave as they roll over your tongue , leave a pleasantly tart , oaky and mildly sticky aftertaste without any kind of heat .   overall , this be one of the more unique beer I 've have the pleasure of drink over the last 3 year . when I think about American Wild Ales and how they compare to their old world counterpart , I tend to find that most herald example of Wild Ales seem to be lack in complexity by be so boldly acidic . Cory King have somehow take the genre to another level by create a beer that be bold in every way with plenty of acidity yet nuance with a great array of different flavour that make each sip a new experience in of itself .   ---------------------------------   750ml bottle of Batch 2 . serve in a wine glass .   pour a dark black body with a hint of brown depend on the lighting . one finger tan head that dissipate fairly quickly . not altogether too different from the original batch . smell of dark chocolate , cherry , oak , vinegar , fudge . the level of acidity you can smell and taste be remarkably similar to one - year old Batch 1 as above , which surprise I . Flavour be very similar ; chocolate fudge and chocolate cover cherry , oak , vinegar . the cherry be n't as prominent as expect . the flavour pop nicely , with a nice tart 8/10 acidity that be quite sour but not bracingly so . no off flavour . as the beer warm , it bring out a little more of the chocolate and less of the cherry ; it evolve quite a bit just like its predecessor do . Delicious . Mouthfeel be noticeably thin than the original batch , I feel . there be still a fair amount of body , but perhaps I be compare everything to Maman which I have the same day . good carbonation , with a nice residual , slightly fizzy , chocolate fudge and acidity on the backend . overall , it be not quite batch 1 as far as body go , but the flavour remain excellent and one of the more unique beer I 've have .

M- light and highly carbonate on the tongue , this feel like a traditional lambic or wild . the dark malt that give the beer its dark color and some dark flavor really do n't translate to a creamy mouthfeel . still , this be spot on for the wild ale style .   overall , this be a great beer , but not as phenomenal as I be anticipate . I be really hope for more of a dark malt presence to compete with the cherry , but this be still a great beer .

bottle into a taste glass , review from note . thank Aaron !   a : hazy deep gold body under a finger of white froth . mediocre retention and lacing , which be well than I expect for the style . pretty nice .   s : Intense . huge citric acidity be front and center , with wave of lemon , lime , grapeskin , and passionfruit . some sweet grape and melon note emerge as it warm , as well as more than a hint of vanilla oak . excellent .   t : even well than the nose , with immense flavor and complexity without any loss of balance . sour fruitiness up front , rich oak underneath , and a long , tart , dry finish with a lovely vinous aftertaste . wow .   m : substantial body with light , soft carbonation . lively enough to keep it from be the least bit sticky , but not too prickly . solid .   o : amazing beer , and probably my favorite side Project to date . huge thank to Aaron for host the share with this and so many other wonderful brew .   cheer !

much thank to a good friend for share his bottle with I a few week ago . enjoy out of a green 375 mL bottle but I be not able to catch the bottle date ( if there be one ) . pour into a small belgian - style tulip glass .   Appearance ( 4.5 ) - pour a hazy golden color that remind I of the color of an egg yolk , but with more note of orange and amber go on than what you 'd expect . the head be about a finger at most and a fairly stark / snow white in color . it do n't last long before fade to a ringlet around the edge of the glass and just a faint swirl of foam across the surface of the liquid .   Smell ( 4.5 ) - there be a few key element present which all combine quite nicely . of course , there be a fantastic lactic acidity that make my tastebud pucker slightly in anticipation before ever take a sip . but alongside that , the vinous characteristic of white wine and oak , with even perhaps a hint of vanilla . and finally , there be a subtle hint of white grape tartness that be different in nature from the bacteria - base sourness that be clearly present . it add a depth to the sourness that might not be there without the fruit . I ca n't wait to dive into this and drink it .   Taste ( 4.75 ) - the flavor do not disappoint , with all of the element that present themselves in the aroma push through in equal part . Woody , musty oak and lactic sourness lead the way , induce a nice satisfying pucker and refreshing tartness . as with the smell , the inclusion of the wine grape give a bit of juicy sourness that balance nicely alongside some funky , yogurt - like characteristic . the finish be where the chardonnay come through , with crisp granny smith apple and white grape linger on the palate .   Mouthfeel ( 4.5 ) - medium - bodied and moderately carbonate , with a linger dry finish that entice the next sip .   Overall ( 4.5 ) , a fabulous beer , and my first in the Biere Brut style , although I ca n't imagine that this take could be consider typical . it be amazing to I just how sourness as a flavor profile can screw with one 's perception of ABV level in a beer . this one certainly do n't give away it be 10 % abv , and I 've have other sour beer that be burst with flavor but only have 3 - 4 % abv . I would gladly drink this often if it be easy to get . a fabulous and unique offering from Side Project .

F- wheat , lactic acid , oak , a bit of funk , white grape must . this taste an awful lot like Fuzzy but without the peach , and plenty of white grape . this do not deliver a lot of actual white wine character , but rather more of white grape must . that be actually what I seem to prefer , and it be remarkably tasty . that be say , it be also quite tart , similar to how tart Blueberry Flanders be but not quite to the point where it be a turn - off .   M- medium bodied , silky crispness be very refreshing . the tartness start burn up your jaw immediately . very tasty with a lot of nice depth to it . easy to drink , even with the tartness .   O- Delicious stuff . I enjoy this one a lot and continue to expect this level of excellence from Side Project , because they keep deliver these hit one after another .

2019 vintage   pour from the bottle a deep golden brown and sit in the glass an inky , jet - brown verging on black ; top with a small khaki froth that recede almost immediately to a slight collar , a few paper - thin island of cap , and sparse strand of lacing .   Aroma open with level , sweet tone of oaky bourbon barrel , vanilla , rich chocolate , and caramel , become increasingly roasty lead into light tone of smoke malt , toffee , and cherry skin .   taste feature a litany of fudgy bourbon note , toffee , and oaky barrel upfront ; sweet , smoky malt peak over the mid - palate into the finish of now semi - sweet campfire and vanilla bean touch ; light bit of maple imbue every aspect of the profile .   Mouthfeel have a medium body and low carbonation guide to a silky , slick mid - palate ; slightly creamy all - around ; a soft warming team with a bare minimum alcohol presence into the finish while a minor roasty bittering come through on the exhale .   this be a good imperial porter that be both temper and hinder by a more passive barrel presence lack intensity . along the way , the maple interact awkwardly with the roasty bitterness of the porter base as well , but do n't delay the beer from take its sweet , smokier , and lightly bitter form . solid overall , though unfortunately a bit too complacent and safe for my taste .

a 2014 bottle from the reserve collection at Jackie O ’s production brewery serve in a snifter .   Look- a dense black with a little less than a finger of dark mocha head . surprised that there be virtually no lacing with this one .   Smell- ton of vanilla , maple , and bourbon with a nutty aroma mix in . the barrel do n’t really dominate like I expect .   Taste- I ’ll start by say wow ! the vanilla and bourbon mix be fantastic . the hazelnut and chocolate be there , too . the maple have mellow with age but probably give some of the sweetness .   Mouthfeel- light carbonation with a creamy smooth finish . the subtle sweetness hang around with every sip .   Overall- a great offering from Jackie O ’s . not certain about this be a porter but it be still great . definitely worth the trip .

Drank from a 12.7 fl . oz . bottle purchase at Craft Beer Cellar , Belmont , MA serve in a snifter   Dark cola brown appearance . slightly thin in body than I anticipate . the liquid be cap by a small , bubbly , khaki color colored crown that quickly drop to a frothy collar . tiny dot and streak of lacing stick along the glass .   the aroma be really malty and robust . nice melding of caramel and roasted malt . slightly sweet . a bit nutty . bourbon note come through big time . Super boozy but not excessively so . a subtle wet paper - like quality also detectable . touch of smokiness too . zero maple character however .   the flavor profile be basically a toned down version of the nose . big and malty . this definitely have an " old school " imperial porter - like quality to it . the beer be anchor by a robust caramel and roasted malt base . Boozy , bourbon note appear in the center and intensify as the beer move along the palate . More roast and linger booze in the finish . like the aroma , there be absolutely no maple character .   the mouthfeel be somewhat disappointing . slightly thin for the style . the liquid contain a larger bubbled , moderate effervescence that froth up on the palate .   I have find most of Jackie O ’s porter and stout to be pretty disappointing , and Bourbon Barrel Black Maple be underwhelming as well . both the aroma and the flavor profile be straightforward and devoid of any maple character , and the mouthfeel be quite thin . I remember this brewery ’ beer be highly covet a few year ago . either they have get significantly bad with time or people ’s palate have vastly evolve .

apparently , I have never review Second Fiddle . that be weird to I , because I first have it probably seven year ago when I first visit Fiddlehead and they have tap it just before I have arrive . of course it be fantastic then , live up to my expectation in every possible way , but every time I 've have it since then ... I must say I 've be kinda let down . this batch , however , be from 5/14/21 , and be definitely the high - quality can batch I 've have ! it easily eclipse every prior SF iteration I 've consume , and thus I believe it be a fitting entry for a review .   the pour be , honestly , way clear than I remember . Mango and tangerine with hint of guava combine with West Coast pine and grapefruit funkiness ... it just jive super well . this be definitely the good and most cohesive batch of this beer that I have personally have since they start can it . it be bring I back totally to the first time I try it ! lemony note and subtle tropical fruit element come out as it warm ... so glad I get another can . notice the different art / design for the can and wonder if maybe it bring with it a change in recipe or some kind of refinement . not 100 % sure but feel that way to I so far !   Flavor be super clean pine with biscuity malt bring up the backend , bolster by superb undertone of mango , guava , and passion fruit alongside some hint of tangerine / tangelo and herbal grassiness . man , this be drink so great right now ! I be sure it be 11 day old have more than a little to do with it , but I be re - impressed by this brew ! have a few " meh " experience with it over the year since , but this be give I the feeling that they know exactly what they be do and what may be necessary to bring this brew into the modern realm . love that it do n't seem like they give in to trend and make it a hazy DIPA . it be just a superbly craft , pine - y , citrusy , slightly - tropical IPA from New England , trend be damn ! ! hope to keep track this one down over time to see that they keep the quality intact ...

this be a beautifully make dipa that I just do n't like very much . beautiful bright amber , with a dense white head , and expect haziness . the aroma be bright , like smell mint , but very subdued and without any specific aromatic character , except for dankness . the taste be also bright and cool ( mint - like ) , but without any distinct malt or hop flavor that be appeal . ( the flavor actually exist for a brief moment , but disappear immediately into a clean bitterness that erase any impression of what you have just drunk . ) the body be more like an IPA than a double IPA , which be n't necessarily a bad thing . I be sure this will appeal to those who be look for a clean , refreshing blast of alcohol , but I be look for more aroma and flavor in a DIPA .

1 - 2 month old can pour into a tulip .   fully opaque , almost apple cider coloring , but I would n't really call it " hazy " by modern definition . fluffy initial eggshell head with a couple sip ' worth of retention and some nice , sticky , splotchy lacing . almost look like a saison . definitely clean and crisp looking . perhaps this be a more traditional Vermont hazy ?   Aroma profile be a nice blend of coast , with ton of semi - sweet fruit juice but a nice blast of bitter , pithy citrus and pine resin . there be a dank , almost funkiness in the mix -- start as an almost sweaty gym sock aroma but gradually become more overripe fruity . it may sound strange , but I like it , whatever it be -- add a nice degree of complexity to the hybrid IIPA base . berry , tangerine , tropical fruit , stone fruit , grapefruit , pineapple -- it be a great fruit salad , but none of it be overly bold or potent . just a pleasant and mouthwatere smeller .   taste initially follow pretty closely , but this one be much dry than I expect . Citrus , tropical fruit , grape , and berry up front , then a huge blast of grapefruit pith and lemon rind . good piney twang with a big mineral note . I keep wait for some residual sweetness to flow in , but it simply never do . this one have ( un - sugar ) grapefruit all over it . extremely drinkable and well make , but note very layered or nuanced . the dryness and grapefruit definitely remind I of Alchemist ipa , but this one be n't quite of the same quality .   soft and silky like a modern , murky hazy , with a nice bite of carbonation along with the pithy twang . coat the tooth and tongue really well , with the pine resin come back to the forefront .
